title: "Do it yourself..." custom JavaFX 2.x controls
summary: Every frontend developer knows the problem, the project you are working on requires a control that is not part of the standard library which raises the question...“How to do a custom control myself ?“ This talk will show you one way you could choose to create those custom controls in JavaFX. The internal structure of a JavaFX control with it‘s different parts like control, skin, behavior and css file will be explained. In addition the differences between a Java Swing component and a JavaFX control will be shown to give the audience with a Swing background an idea on how to convert existing Java Swing components to JavaFX controls. In addition it will be shown how one could get an existing design converted into a control. Therefore a small control will be created in a drawing program and afterwards be converted into code using different approaches like SVG to FXML, FXG to FXML and FXG to Java code.

title: SIMBA: secure your Java Applications fast and easy
summary: SIMBA stands for Security Integration Module for Business Applications and is an User Access Management system that can be integrated with any business application.  The main purpose is to secure your application fast and easy and make security more accessible for developers who are not security experts.  SIMBA has lots of advantages over the standard big security tools: customize your security based on your entry points, easy user management, no configuration nightmare (any developer can do this), distributed deployment, lightweight,... and of course the price.  SIMBA is a Belgian OWASP open-source project.

title: Start me up ... in the Cloud
summary:
Cloud is such a change that transforms the way we do software development. Enter the Cloud-age, free from middleware, IT and infrastructure worries - just business needs and developers to implement them. 
During this talk, we will discuss the major changes Cloud is introducing to our jobs, as a huge step to even more agility. We will also demonstrate them : we will (try to) create the new Google / FaceBook / Twitter success-story start-up - no guarantee we succeed - with only one developer and the awesome capabilities of a PaaS to free our imagination.

title: Modularizing a JavaEE application
summary:
Building a modular JavaEE web application presents some strong challenges, especially when working on sizable enterprise applications. The development model is usualy monolithic. This makes it hard to extend the application.

Hear how the ever static war as well as the usual configuration files like faces-config.xml or web.xml are built/generated at runtime using the different jar from the server, thanks to a templating/fragment model.

Developers also use an extension point model that makes possible this level of modularity. Each jar can contain a part of the war, the necessary java code needed for this war, the application server configuration files or the properties files used for internationalization.
Going further in the modularity/agility issue, the developers use a modifed version of tomcat's default class loader which offer hot reloading of their Java code. This also makes the reloading of extension points, fragments and templates possible.

title: ElasticMQ: what is it, and how does it work? (Or: Scala/JGroups/Netty/Squeryl in practice.)
summary:
ElasticMQ is a message queue server, with optional journaling, replication and an Amazon-SQS compatible interface.

The first part will cover ElasticMQ as a server. I will explain the model of sending and receiving messages used both by SQS and ElasticMQ. Then I will show how to run an embedded server e.g. during tests. There will also be a live replication demo with a cluster of ElasticMQ servers. You will see that no message is lost even when an accidental kill -9 occurs.

Second part will be a case study of the technologies used. ElasticMQ is written in Scala; I will show examples where Scala was especially useful (e.g. the Cake Pattern). The libraries are also interesting: JGroups is a really easy way to implement replication; Squeryl offers type-safe SQL queries; and Netty is the way to build an asynchronous HTTP server. These will be short intros so that you feel encouraged to play at home. 

The project is fully open-source. You are encouraged to fork at: https://github.com/adamw/elasticmq.

author.speakerBio:
I am one of the co-founders of SoftwareMill, a company specialising in delivering customised software solutions (http://softwaremill.com, "Extraordinary software as a standard"), based on Java, Scala and JBoss technologies. I graduated from the University of Warsaw, receiving a Master's Degree in Computer Science. I am also involved in some open-source projects. Firstly as the founder and lead developer of Hibernate Envers, a Hibernate core module, which provides entity versioning/auditing capabilities; Envers is also included in JBoss AS since version 7.0.2. Secondly, as the founder of ElasticMQ, an SQS-compatible messaging server written in Scala.

Moreover I work on several small projects around static analysis (using JSR 308 - Typestate Annotations/ Checkers Framework and FindBugs), and some CDI/Weld (not always portable) extensions, like autofactories or stackable security interceptors. I am also interested in improving the ways we use Dependency Injection, and some simple electronics using Arduino/RaspberryPi/Lego. When not working, I enjoy hiking in the mountains (summer), skiing (winter), playing tennis and since June 2010, spending time with my daughter.

I have been a speaker at numerous conferences, including Devoxx, Jazoon, Confitura, JDD and Herbstcampus, as well as on Warsaw, Poznan and Riviera JUGs.

My blog: http://www.warski.org/blog

title: 7 Things: How to make good teams great
summary:
Developing a product over years is a tough job. It is hard for the team to stay excited on a day to day basis. So how can you improve motivation and innovation of agile teams and still keep the focus on building a great product?

I want to share with you how we at Atlassian used an agile approach to become one of the most successful developer tool companies in the world. This talk will cover topics like FedEx days, 20-percent time, keeping distraction away from developers, lunchtime talks, dogfooding and much more.

title: Developing portable PaaS applications
summary:
In demonstrating how the Java cloud library jclouds makes it easy to work with cloud services in a simple, portable way, we've written a bunch of applications that run on many of today's Platform as a Service offerings, including Google App Engine, CouldBees RUN@cloud, RedHat OpenShift, Cloud Foundry, Heroku and DotCloud. 

In this session, we'd like to share our experience in developing and, just as importantly, managing portable Java PaaS applications. We'll set the context by identifying some pointers to help you decide whether a public or private PaaS makes sense for your application, or whether an IaaS solution in a public or private cloud might be more appropriate. We'll then compare PaaS APIs, provided resources and replacements, and discuss ways of separating your core portable business logic from your "PaaS binding". 

Finally, we'll look at "live-from-IDE" development, continuous integration and deployment options and touch on monitoring and application management in a multi-PaaS setup.

title: Behaviour Driven Development on the JVM - a State of the Union
summary: Behavior Driven Development (BDD) is an increasingly popular variation on Test Driven Development, which helps developers think more about what they are testing, in terms of "executable specifications" rather than conventional tests. But there are dozens of BDD tools for the JVM out there: how do you know what to use, and when? In this talk, we will look at the various BDD tools available for Java developers, both in Java and in other JVM languages. We will look at the pros and cons of the various tools, and learn which might be best suited for your team. Finally, you will discover the relationship between behavior driven development and automated acceptance testing, and why you probably need both.

title: Improve your Java code, functional-style - Now!
summary: Functional programming is all the rage. Functional programming can undoubtably produce cleaner and more expressive code. But why switch to Scala or wait for Java 8? In fact, there are many ways to dramatically improve your code quality using a more functional style today! This talk will discuss how techniques such as functional programming, fluent APIs and other clean coding practices can make your code more concise, more readable, and much easier to maintain. But, more importantly, you will learn about libraries such as LambdaJ and Google Guava that make this possible today, with your existing Java code base!

title: To ATDD and beyond! Better Automated Acceptance Testing on the JVM
summary:
Test Driven Development is a game changer for developers, but Automated Acceptance Testing (ATDD) is a game changer for the whole team! More than just a testing technique, Automated Acceptance Testing is both a collaboration tool and a vital step on the road to Continuous Delivery.

In this talk, you will see a real-world demo applying practical ATDD techniques to real-world projects using JBehave, Selenium 2 and Thucydides. Learn how to write better and more maintainable automated acceptance tests, and see how a well-designed set of automated acceptance tests can also be a powerful documentation and reporting tool. 

See how tools like JBehave and Thucidides can help you structure your acceptance tests and generate powerful documentation, with narrative feature descriptions, screen shots, test coverage, and project progress reports. 

And learn how product owners use ATDD and Thucydides to drive, coordinate and document releases.

title: Software project estimation techniques
summary:
Estimating software development effort is unavoidable in commercial software development. It’s also hard. This talk will help you understand how to develop effective estimation techniques, how they relate to different kinds of projects, how everything and everyone will conspire to make your estimates turn out to be wrong, and how to deal with that. This a practical talk for working programmers, based on real projects, not a theoretical discussion.

Outline:

* Business context - why you make estimates
* Estimation - how you do it
* Verification - identifying bad estimates
* Communication - why estimates are misunderstood
* Improvement - how to make better estimates

Whatever your development methodology, agile or not, you still need good estimates. Meanwhile, methodology discussions and the introduction of new methods both focus on selecting which processes and practices to use on a software development project, and rarely address the details of how you actually implement those practices.

title: How to write functional requirements
summary:
A hard task for any programmer is deciding what to build, which is why software development methodology addresses requirements specification. These days, you could be forgiven for thinking that everyone, or at least everyone else, uses Scrum and just writes user stories on sticky notes. The reality is more complex, and in practice the industry uses many different techniques and levels of documentation, varying from none at all to detailed written specifications. 

This talk covers a range of functional design styles and practical techniques, as well as the fundamental question: doesn’t being ‘agile’ mean that we don’t need written requirements?

* What a functional design is
* What it contains: what to write
* How to write it: gathering information
* Documentation techniques: user stories to detailed specifications
* Diagram techniques: models to mock-ups
* Tools: word processors & wikis

This a practical talk for working programmers, based on real projects, not a theoretical discussion.
wikiPageName: How to write functional requirements
wikiTitle: How to write functional requirements
smallTitle: How to write functional requirements by Peter Hilton

title: The myth of the on-site customer
summary:
Although agile software development methods advocate putting the customer (e.g. Scrum product owner) in the same room as the development team for the duration of the project, this is isn’t usually remotely realistic. This presentation describes four real-world case studies of customers who weren’t ‘in the room’, how this compromised agile software development, how we communicated with the customer instead, and why agile software development techniques still had something to offer.

Case studies:

# The customer who had already written a functional specification
# The customer who we didn’t see for the whole project
# The customer who didn’t know that the team was using Scrum
# The customer who emigrated to Australia during the project
wikiPageName: The myth of the on-site customer
wikiTitle: The myth of the on-site customer
smallTitle: The myth of the on-site customer by Peter Hilton

title: OSGi for the Earthlings: Meet Eclipse Libra!
summary:
This session had been presented on EclipseCon 2010, JavaOne 2011, EclipseCon 2012, JavaOne 2012  and will be updated for the new functionality prior to Javaone and Devoxx. The talk offers a wide variety of live demos showing the capabilities of the tool set. 

Libra is an open source project under the Eclipse Web Tools Platform Container Project. It provides standard tools for OSGi Enterprise application development and in particular tools that integrate the existing WTP and PDE tooling so that OSGi Enterprise applications can be developed with both tooling at the same time. Libra also will enable users to work with tools for better experience in the Server-Side Equinox scenario.

The goals of the project are:

http://www.eclipse.org/libra/

title: Software development for smart busy programmers
summary:
Good programmers are smart, busy and want as much time as possible to work on cool stuff and write good code, to they gravitate towards agile software development. However, although agile methods improve on traditional processes, they neither replace the need for basic techniques or teach them. This presentation teaches the essential practical techniques that you need whatever method you are using, agile or not: 

* essential project documentation - telling stakeholders what you’re doing
* functional design - communicating requirements to programmers
* software development estimation - making cost predictions
* essential system documentation - avoiding being on-call for ever.

Writing everything down up-front is easy (but a bad idea): the art of being agile is knowing what you can leave out while still addressing all of a development project’s issues. This session teaches you how.
wikiPageName: Software development for smart busy programmers
wikiTitle: Software development for smart busy programmers
smallTitle: Software development for smart busy programmers by Peter Hilton

title: DevOps Padawan
summary:
As I joined CloudBees as Support Engineer, I discovered an incredible company managing thousand servers and a Cloud platform with a reduced engineering team. I then was introduced to DevOps spirit and tooling, and I discovered a awesome world of power. 

I'm still just a DevOps Padawan, but want to share with you this awesome feeling of getting things done the right way

During this session I'll expose CloudBees internals : how we run Jenkins in the Cloud, how we monitor and manage it, how we provide as many slave you need to build your software, and how the team is organized to improve the platform and do it well. 

May the DevOps be with you

title: JavaScript for Java Developers
summary:
Some developers have an impression that JavaScript is a second-league interpreted language with the main purpose of making Web pages a little prettier. But JavaScript is a powerful, flexible, dynamically typed language. JavaScript functions are the first class citizens that can live their own lives. But mastering JavaScript can present a challenge to Java developers who quickly find themselves in the Wild West Land of dynamic programming.

Why you may want to learn JavaScript? 

First, learning how things done in another language makes you a better Java developer. 
Second, HTML5 becomes a new buzzword and adding JavaScript to your skill set make you more valuable software developer. You may not know the best kept secret – any HTML5 project is about learning some new tags, APIs and CSS,but mainly it’s about writing JavaScript code.

The goal of this presentation is to introduce you to this interesting language highlighting the differences with the Java way of doing stuff.

Yakov leads the Princeton Java Users Group.

title: Parallelism in the JVM, from scratch to ForkJoin
summary: The tools available in the JVM for writing code that run in parallel have improved over the years. From directly handling threads to abstractions like the executor service and now the ForkJoin framework much has changed. This talk will walk us through the analysis of different parallel versions of a simple algorithm (merge sort) and the related pros and cons.

title: Tale of an AOM-based application
summary: The Adaptive Object Model architecture has been around for a few years now and we've put it to practice in our applications. The added flexibility turns volatile requirements easier to deal with. On the other hand, database migration between versions can be harder requiring new tools. Through this presentation we would like to share our approach to it as well as the resulting benefits and difficulties.

title: Develop Hybrid Mobile Applications for both iOS and Android Devices with HTML5 and Java
summary: With the rapid advancement of HTML5 support in the mobile operating systems, developers can now leverage HTML5 and JavaScript to build rich, compelling mobile application user interfaces that mimic native applications. However, business logic and data services would typically be coded using JavaScript or native (e.g. Objective-C) code – neither are ideal for most Java developers. In this session, we will discuss a new framework (Oracle Application Development Framework Mobile) that enable developers to declaratively create HTML5-based user interfaces using JavaServer Faces-like components. For business logic and data services, developers can either declaratively define or code in Java to create these service components. The exact same modules and code would run on both iOS and Android devices. Furthermore, the framework integrates PhoneGap to provide strong device integration, which allows Java developers to create powerful mobile application across different device types. Includes demos on iOS and Android.

title: Android Custom Components
summary:
Android comes with many built-in components, but some tasks are best accomplished by rolling your own.

We will start from a simple example of enhancing the TextView class, and finish with a complete custom view with its own size measurement, drawing function and custom attributes. We will also discuss the best practices for custom views. What is the different between a custom view and a fragment? How about a compound control? When to use which?

By the end of the session, you will know not only how to create reusable custom components, but when to use them.

title: Building Living Web Applications - An Introduction to HTML5 WebSockets
summary:
Take your desktop and mobile Web apps to the next level with true, real-time connectivity. Learn how to build real-time, multi-user interaction and collaboration into your Web apps using HTML5 and WebSockets. Whether you want your app to be a real-time retail experience or a fast-paced MMO, you’ll learn hands-on skills to turn your mobile apps into live apps, by building peer-to-peer mobile apps, mobile-desktop interaction, and even turning your smartphone into a Nintendo Wii-style remote control.
Be sure to bring your smartphone or other mobile device to participate in this interactive experience.

Before joining Kaazing, in various product management leadership roles Peter was responsible for Oracle's portal product strategy.

summary:
In this hands-on/guided demo session we walk through the steps of building a Rich Internet Application from scratch, leveraging modern HTML5 Web development concepts. You will use enterprise messaging directly in the browser to build highly dynamic, responsive, and scalable Web applications. Come to this session to learn how you can mix and match Java Message Service (JMS), JavaScript, and HTML5 to build incredibly responsive Web applications for desktop and mobile devices.
The presentation uses a browser-based HTML5 editor and a cloud-hosted WebSocket server.

title: Asynchronous processing in Java EE 6
summary:
The talk will present the various changes around asynchronous processing in Java EE 6, mainly in Servlet 3.0 and EJB 3.1. I'd say these changes are one of the most useful ones in Java EE 6 and it's hard to believe so few people use or are aware of them. The presentation's aim is to change it!
It's assumed to run a demo to show the topic live on stage.

Jacek Laskowski has been into Java Enterprise Edition (Java EE) specification and its ecosystem for many years and will surely be spending some more to come. He’s a member of the Apache Software Foundation, and a Project Management Committee (PMC) and a committer of Apache OpenEJB as well as Apache Geronimo open source projects. He’s recently been very interested in functional languages and the decision to study a few ones – Clojure, F#, JRuby and Scala – shapes his current self-learning activities. With Clojure it's much easier and hence it's often referred to as "a small library for concurrent programming".

title: Mobile Java with GWT, Still "Write Once Run Everywhere"
summary:
Once JavaME had ruled the mobile world. Times have changed and JavaME is not really preferred on any modern device today. Android rise pretty fast thanks to large developer community of Java.
However in real world Android is not alone! Many mobile devices running iOS and Blackberry are also exist in mobile universe. 
HTML5+phonegap apps promised a magic silverbullet for write once run on all devices approach via several frameworks which in the end offered painful javascript and css development. While GWT offers a great Java to JS compiler and debugger, MGWT introduces native looking widgets both on ios, android and even blackberry. Also with the addition of gwt-phonegap projects, now you can code native looking html apps which can use native apis only with regular Java without coding a single line of html+JS.
This talk had been highly rated at Android Dev Days Istanbul and Ankara also still waiting for approval to be on JavaOne 2012.

title: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
summary: High performance is of critical importance for the success of any web site, particularly when catering for a wide range of device capabilities and network latencies.  However, before considering performance the site must work reliably across all required devices.  In recent years many of the approaches adopted to achieve high performance rely on the excessive use of JavaScript or techniques supported by only a limited set of devices.  These approaches lead to reduced reliability and support across different devices and higher testing and maintenance costs.  This talk will describe multiple techniques used to progressively enhance performance for web sites without reducing device support.

author.speakingReferences:
Speaker at Future of Mobile - London 2012
Organiser and Speaker at Mobile Web Meetup
Regular Speaker at Betfair
author.speakerBio: James Bloom is the technical lead of mobile web team at Betfair. He has 13 years experience developing web based distributed enterprise systems in a wide range of industries. In his current role, he has focused on building high performance mobile web sites that are designed to run reliably across a wide range of devices with sophisticated progressive enhancement. He has also focused on high quality sustainable delivery through fast feedback loops in agile, continuous delivery, and a very high level of automated testing across a wide range of devices.
author.name: James Bloom

wikiPageName: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
wikiTitle: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
smallTitle: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance by James Bloom

title: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
summary: The key to a successful mobile site is high performance and reliability across a wide range of device capabilities and network latencies.  However, the mobile web is a hostile environment with support for HTML5, JavaScript and CSS varying widely across browsers and devices.  This talk will explain best practices to build high performance mobile sites that work across a wide range of devices and capabilities.  The focus will be on lessons learnt at Betfair while rewriting the entire mobile web stack and how we used techniques to maximise performance and reliability.  After discussing the problems faced in mobile the talk will explain how adaptive techniques can be used to provide progressive enhancement.  This will be followed by an explanation of why and where performance bottlenecks occur and how these can be solved.
wikiPageName: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
wikiTitle: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
smallTitle: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair by James Bloom

title: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
summary:
What do you get when you combine JavaFX and Scala together on top of a Cloud architecture? The most highly scalable platform for Java client development, leveraging the UI richness of JavaFX, elegance of Scala, and scalability of a multi-cloud platform.

We will demonstrate a 100% open-source cloud application built on the jclouds platform using a JavaFX front-end written in Scala. This is an ideal platform for cost-efficient cloud use, since JavaFX lets your client's processor and GPU do the heavy-lifting while you access a lightweight set of REST APIs in the cloud.

We will discuss multi-cloud deployment, writing effective REST services, and building rich user interfaces on top of the common foundation on the Java platform, so you can easily write end-to-end applications leveraging your existing development knowledge and platform. 

By the end of the session you will have learned to build an end-to-end client cloud application from the ground up!
wikiPageName: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
wikiTitle: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
smallTitle: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud by Andrew Phillips

title: Hacking the Java compiler for fun and profit
summary:
For Java developers who want to work with the language and platform they love, the last two years have proven to be ground-breaking ones. Java SE 7 was released after a long five-year and brought many new features to make a Java programmer’s life simpler. Such features include reduced generics syntax, safe file handling, making large numbers etc. 

However, wouldn’t it be fun to be able to add your own favourite features to Java?

In this tutorial, we give an introduction to hacking the Java compiler by showing you how to implement a relatively simple new language syntax feature: the Elvis operator.

You will learn:
- how to download and build the Java compiler source code
- how a compiler works and an overview of the Java compiler architecture
- how to modify the Java syntax and grammar
- how to implement the Elvis operator as a feature of Java
- how to test your implementation

title: ThymeLeaf, a natural HTML 5 templating system for Spring MVC (and other frameworks too)
summary:
Wanna give a second birth to your old Spring MVC web app ?
Wanna switch to HTML 5 without headache ?
Tired of JSP tag soup and bloated logic ?

 Then try ThymeLeaf, the natural HTML 5 templating engine.
 Featuring:
  - natural HTML 5 attribute-base templating
  - WYSIWIG, what you see in static browser rendering is what you'll get at runtime!
  - seemless integration with Spring MVC 3 via dialect system
  - full support of Spring EL for even more powerfull features
  - tons of helper functions for maximum productivity (don't re-invent the wheel!)
  - templates re-use with inclusion & import system
  - scripts support (Javascript & Dart) with inlining system for variable propagation
  - simple integration with Spring Security (no extra taglib)
 
 We'll explore the power and features of ThymeLeaf through a simple REST demo web app

summary:
Supporting mobile devices in addition to running a classical web site is almost a matter of course nowadays. 
In order to support mobiles devices, native apps are not the only solution.

Mobile web applications can accomplish almost the same like native apps. This session demonstrates, how you can realize mobile web applications having JavaServer Faces as base framework. It will be shown, how you can build mobile web apps based on JSF and additional JSF component libraries.

title: UI architectures with JSF
summary:
JSF is often the chosen technology when realizing the user interface of a web application. But just using JSF is not enough for getting a maintainable, stable and understandable architecture in the ui layer.

Within the ui layer, important decisions are made which influence the overall design. E.g. connecting the ui layer to the service layer, working with JPA entities or DTOs and many more.

In this session I will highlight common problems when using JSF. Of course I will also show solutions and  tips, how to improve your ui architecture.

title: Easy Dynamic Web Applications with Railo
summary:
In this session, Mark Drew will show you the power of quickly developing web applications using Railo Server and the CFML programming Language. 

Railo Server provides a great environment to develop dynamic web applications using a dynamic language (CFML) on the JVM. 

Easily integrating into a number of services, such as databases, Hibernate, XML, RSS, WebServices, HTML5 Websockets and even ReST services, you have never developed sites this quickly before. 

In this presentation we will demonstrate some of the great features of this language, starting from scratch and building a whole application in the time it takes to demonstrate it... from download to development to deploy in less than 60 minutes.

author.speakerBio:
Mark has been programming CFML since 1996, and even though he has had forays into Perl, ASP and PHP he is still loving every line of code he has crafted with CFML.

His career has concentrated on eCommerce, Content Management and Application Scalability for various well known brands in the UK market such as Jaeger, Hackett, Hobbs, Dyson, B&W, Diesel amongst others.

title: Faster Websites: Crash Course on Frontend Performance
summary:
Backend architecture matters, but chances are, most of the performance problems in your new and awesome web app are in the frontend: too many external resources, request serialization, suboptimal layout and JavaScript execution.

We'll start at the beginning: how does the browser layout the page, what are the HTML5 optimizations that can help us improve the user experience, and what are the tools that can assist us in this quest? We'll dive into Chrome Dev Tools, explore the new W3C performance specs and what they can offer, and investigate several case studies to illustrate the common pitfalls. By the end of the session, you'll be able to shave several seconds off your page load time - yes, all in the frontend! 

And for the backend geeks, we'll take a quick look at lessons learned with SPDY, talk about open source page optimization (and automation) tools like PageSpeed, and also take a quick foray into the optimizations for the mobile web.

Prior to focusing on web performance Ilya was the founder and CTO of PostRank, a social analytics company which was acquired by Google and became the core of social analytics reporting within Google Analytics. Whenever not thinking web performance, or analytics, Ilya can be found contributing to open-source projects, reading, or building fun projects like VimGolf, GitHub Archive and others.

title: Designing and consuming a Cloud 2.0 API
summary:
As the leading cloud ecosystem integration library on the JVM, jclouds has daily practical experience of dealing with cloud APIs for over three years now. Watching over 40 APIs covering PaaS, IaaS, SaaS, social networking and more as they develop, integrating them coherently and trying to provide advanced functionality, such as location metadata, not currently available from the vendor APIs has given jclouds a unique perspective on what it takes to design a "high-flying" cloud API. 
From "intrinsic" features such as formats, layout, functionality and metadata to delivery considerations such a discoverability, bandwidth, performance and version management, we'll share experiences, lessons and recommendations that will hopefully help you both *design* and *consume* cloud APIs more easily.

title: Future-safe extension of enterprise applications to the mobile device using JavaServer Faces
summary: Support for mobile devices are a must-have for enterprise applications. Coding for the mobile platform often comes with the cost of duplicate coding, new development skills to learn and the lack enterprise integration, like with SSO. Oracle ADF Mobile is a JSF based framework to extend enterprise applications to the mobile device. Based on open source PhoneGap, ADF mobile allows JSF, local HTML5 and remote web resources to be combined into a mobile application that executes in a lightweight Java VM on the mobile device. Local services, like phone book, are accessible through adapters (data controls). Join this session for an overview and demo of ADF Mobile.

title: Transparent development and the project management renaissance
summary:
Software development organisations can use a policy of transparency, varied Internet-based communication tools and the occasional programmer with social skills to remove the need to have a dedicated project manager for every development team. The obvious benefits are smaller teams, more efficient projects and reduced costs. The less obvious benefit is that project management gets more interesting as a result.

This isn’t possible for every project or team, but allows the smaller and easier projects to scale down and get done faster with a smaller team. Meanwhile, specialist project managers can focus on the hard project management problems or expand the scope of their roles.

This talk explains how this can work in practice, why it can be difficult, and how your organisation might make it fail. This a practical talk for working project managers and software developers, based on real projects, not a theoretical discussion.

title: Introducing a software generator framework
summary: Today software applications need to provide a high degree of customization as most customers are looking for individual applications matching their needs. To be able to efficiently manage the variabilities as well as being able to automate the software generation process the paradigm of generative programming gets introduced. Dive in head first and learn about software system families, domain engineering and feature modeling. Learn techniques to build a software generator application from the scratch, followed by some tips and guidelines how to continuously extend the functionality of the software generator and the resulting products. Additionally the participants will learn how to convert an existing project into a software generator.

summary: MongoDB is part of the NoSQL family of datastores. In contrast to traditional relational databases storing data in well defined data structures, MongoDB stores data as JSON-like documents with dynamic schemas. This session will give a basic introduction of MongoDB, share some insights why dynamic schemas make sense and point out some ideas where you could use MongoDB or other NoSQL solutions in your projects making your developer`s life easier.

title: Enhancing your existing application through a modeling tool (Modelio)
summary:
In addition to supporting Model Driven Architecture approaches, a new generation of modeling tool now also helps improving existing code and applications in several ways : code improvement, documentation of the existing code, design improvement, ... The benefits will be explained, through several use cases :
1 - code improvement : update the java utility methods within an existing code, such as "equals", hash", ... 
2 - documentation of the existing code : javadocs can be improved, by incorporating model (UML) diagrams. 
3 - help to understand and analyze the design of an existing application, by reverse engineering the code, automatically creating UML design diagram, automatically creating synthesis views of package dependencies, and providing a graphical means to browse through dependencies between packages or classes. 
This facility applies well to agile practices : it allows a peer programming/design approach, by facilitating a quick design level review of existing code.

title: Do you really get class loaders?
summary: Class loaders are at the core of the Java language. Java EE containers, OSGi, NetBeans modules, Tapestry 5, Grails and many others use class loaders heavily. Yet when something goes wrong, would you know how to solve it? In this session we'll take a tour of the Java class loading mechanism, both from JVM and developer point of view. We will look at typical problems that you get with class loading and how to solve them. ClassNoDefError, IncompatibleClassChangeError, LinkageError and many others are symptoms of specific things going wrong that you can usually find and fix. For each problem we'll go through a hands on demo with a corresponding solution.

title: eID Integration within your web applications
summary:
We present the different eID building blocks that the Belgian Federal Government made available over the past few years: eID Applet, eID Trust Service, eID Identity Provider, and eID Digital Signature Service. These open source building blocks can be integrated within your (Java EE) web application to provide eID based identification, authentication, or creation of qualified signatures. After an overview of the eID functionality and how it maps to the different eID services, we do a live demo of eID integration within some Java EE web application. We also present the different OWASP WebScarab authentication plugins to inspect the authentication protocol messages between the web application and the eID IdP where we sweep over different possible attack vectors. 

The attached presentation was given at EEMA last year. Will be tweaked of course.

Maybe by that time I'll also have Android support (eID over micro-USB).

Presentations available at: http://code.google.com/p/eid-applet/downloads/list

summary:
In this talk you'll learn how the JDK 7 Updates Project in OpenJDK works, and how to work within it, how to track changes, get your fixes in, and follow along as for example the Mac OS X Port gets integrated into future JDK 7 update releases.

If you are curious what kind of fixes are encouraged for JDK 7 Updates, what it takes to become a Committer or Reviewer on this Project, how the community contributes to it, and what to expect in upcoming JDK 7 Update releases, then this talk is for you. If you'd like to know how fixes from HotSpot, JAXP, JAXB, JDK 8, etc. get integrated into JDK 7 Updates, then this talk is for you.

title: Decomposing applications for scalability and deployability
summary:
Today, there are several trends that are forcing application architectures to evolve. Users expect a rich, interactive and dynamic user experience on a wide variety of clients including mobile devices. Applications must be highly scalable, highly available and run on cloud environments. Organizations often want to frequently roll out updates, even multiple times a day. Consequently, it’s no longer adequate to develop simple, monolithic web applications that serve up HTML to desktop browsers.

In this talk we describe the limitations of a monolithic architecture. You will learn how to use the scale cube to decompose your application into a set of narrowly focused, independently deployable back-end services and an HTML 5 client. We will also discuss the role of technologies such as NodeJS and AMQP brokers. You will learn how a modern PaaS such as Cloud Foundry simplifies the development and deployment of this style of application.

author.speakingReferences: Spoken at Javapolis, Devoxx, JavaOne, JFokus, Gluecon, SpringOne, Philly ETE, MongoSV/Philly/SF, Qcon, JavaZone, TheServerSide Java Symposium
author.speakerBio: Chris Richardson is a developer and architect with over 20 years of experience. He is a Java Champion and the author of POJOs in Action, which describes how to build enterprise Java applications with POJOs and frameworks such as Spring and Hibernate. Chris is the founder of the original CloudFoundry.com and now spends his time investigating better ways to develop software and evangelizing Cloud Foundry.  He has a computer science degree from the University of Cambridge in England and lives in Oakland, CA with his wife and three children.
author.name: Chris Richardson

title: Developing polyglot applications on Cloud Foundry
summary:
Developing web applications used to be simple. Your single war-file web application served up HTML to a desktop browser and used a relational database. Today however, web applications are much more complex: the front-end uses HTML5 and NodeJS, the middle tier is decomposed into multiple services, and the back-end uses a mix of SQL and NoSQL databases. Developing these kind of applications can be challenging since there are so many moving parts that need to be correctly installed and configured. Deployment is even more difficult.

In this talk, you will learn why we need to build applications with this architectural style and how Cloud Foundry, which is modern, multi-lingual, multi-service, extensible open-source PaaS, can help. We will talk about how to develop modern applications that run on Cloud Foundry and cover what’s new and different about the cloud environment. You will learn how your application can consume the various services that are provided by Cloud Foundry.
wikiPageName: Developing polyglot applications on Cloud Foundry
wikiTitle: Developing polyglot applications on Cloud Foundry
smallTitle: Developing polyglot applications on Cloud Foundry by Chris Richardson

title: Developing polyglot persistence applications
summary:
NoSQL databases such as Redis, MongoDB and Cassandra are emerging as a compelling choice for many applications. They can simplify the persistence of complex data models and offer significantly better scalability and performance. However, using a NoSQL database means giving up the benefits of the relational model such as SQL, constraints and ACID transactions. For some applications, the solution is polyglot persistence: using SQL and NoSQL databases together.

In this talk, you will learn about the benefits and drawbacks of polyglot persistence and how to design applications that use this approach. We will explore the architecture and implementation of an example application that uses MySQL as the system of record and Redis as a very high-performance database that handles queries from the front-end. You will learn about mechanisms for maintaining consistency across the various databases.
wikiPageName: Developing polyglot persistence applications
wikiTitle: Developing polyglot persistence applications
smallTitle: Developing polyglot persistence applications by Chris Richardson

title: NodeJS: the good parts? A skeptic’s view
summary: JavaScript used to be confined to the browser. But these days, it becoming increasingly popular in server-side applications in the form of NodeJS. NodeJS provides event-driven, non-blocking I/O model that supposedly makes it easy to build scalable network application. In this talk you will learn about the consequences of combining the event-driven programming model with a prototype-based, weakly typed, dynamic language.  We will share our perspective as a server-side Java developer who wasn’t entirely happy about JavaScript in the browser, let alone on the server.

summary: This session shares many of the production proven methods of running Java on vSphere. Covering scalability, load balancer integration, zero-downtime of application releases, best practices, troubleshooting techniques, GC and Java tuning, and how to improve your application architecture using vFabric components in addition to vSphere.  There will also be a special dive into how to best tune the JVM and how to best virtualize latency sensitive Big/Fast data workloads as well.  This is a technical deep dive session that will run over 2hours, attendees will be able to gain JVM tuning knowledge, Virtualization, and Fast/Big data platform tuning.

title: The challenge of millions quotes per second in a pure Java market data vendor
summary:
Traditional market data vendors receive quotes from exchanges and deliver them to the customers using C or C++ feed handlers. However, big enterprise systems that receive those quotes and deliver them to the customers' trading terminals are written in Java. Integration between native feed handlers and Java frontends is performed either via JNI or on the binary protocol level. It entailsvarious technical and organization difficulties. It is not easy to deliver them millions of quotes into the Java world, unless Java was kept in mind in the design of the system from the ground up.

I will share the success story of dxFeed -- a pure Java market data vendor that outperforms many traditional data vendors. What is so hard about handling millions of market data events? What makes it especially hard in Java? What Java-specific design and architectural decisions were made at the beginning to make it possible, and how 100% pure Java solution ultimately makes the life of all developers easier.

title: Hibernate Performance Tuning
summary:
Hibernate is an elegant, straightforward, and easy to use library. This is undeniably true for simple domain models. What about more complex ones? It turns out that in case of complex domain models we usually run into interesting performance issues.
After a brief introduction to a methodology to performance tune Hibernate applications, together with the audience we tune a Hibernate-based application. The application models a number of Hibernate performance anti-patterns that are common in real world applications. During the session, we show how to identify performance bottlenecks in Hibernate using Hibernate logging and a number of tools to track runtime characteristics. Along with the identified performance problems, more efficient alternatives are presented.

author.speakingReferences:
Numerous conferences and tutorials including major events such as ASE and OOPSLA; Java conferences including JavaOne, Devoxx, TheServerSide Java Symposium, JavaZone, Jazoon, and others; regular seminars and workshops;
The list of talks: http://yonita.com/resources/publications
author.speakerBio:
Patrycja Wegrzynowicz is a software visionary and expert specialized in automated software engineering and Java technologies. She is the founder and CTO of Yonita, Inc., a California-based start-up that focuses on automated detection and automated refactoring of software defects, including security vulnerabilities, performance and concurrency anti-patterns, and database issues.

She is also associated with Warsaw University of Technology, where she serves as Technical Manager of Passim/Synat, an intelligent search platform. Patrycja is finalizing PhD in Computer Science at University of Warsaw. She is a regular speaker at major academic as well as industrial conferences, including JavaOne, Devoxx, OOPSLA, ASE, and others.

Patrycja’s interests focus on patterns and anti-patterns in software along with automated software engineering, particularly static and dynamic analysis techniques to support program verification, comprehension, and optimization.

You can follow her on Twitter at @yonlabs.

title: Automated Refactoring of Performance Anti-Patterns in Hibernate
summary: During this talk, we tune a custom application using a tool for automated refactoring. Going step-by-step through various hibernate-related issues in our exemplary application, we explain such performance anti-patterns as inefficient collection mappings, inappropriate types for owning and inverse sides, read-only and transaction issues, and others. For each anti-pattern a better solution is presented along with an automated refactoring performed by Yonita Optimizer for Hibernate to achieve the optimal performance, yet guarantee the same semantics. In the end, the execution times of the refactored application prove the achieved performance gain. Additionally, we also present the results of optimization for an open-source projects, including the before and after execution times along with the refactored code available to download.
wikiPageName: Automated Refactoring of Performance Anti-Patterns in Hibernate
wikiTitle: Automated Refactoring of Performance Anti-Patterns in Hibernate
smallTitle: Automated Refactoring of Performance Anti-Patterns in Hibernate by Patrycja Wegrzynowic

title: Automated Refactoring of Performance and Concurrency Anti-Patterns
summary:
hat is the difference between O(n^2), O(log n), and O(1)? What happens if we design too long critical section?  What about fine-grained communication in a distributed environment? These are not only academic questions, these are real-world problems. Even though enterprise applications usually do not require fancy algorithms, they often operate on relatively large data-sets in highly concurrent and distributed environments. 
This talk presents several performance and concurrency anti-patterns along with a tool demo to automatically refactor them. We discuss performance anti-patterns related to slow data structures, inefficient data- and call-flows, and suboptimal critical sections. Then, we explain how such anti-patterns can be refactored to more appropriate structures applying the best strategy based on their usage patterns, yet guaranteeing the same semantic. During the demo we show how Yonita Optimizer improves an exemplary application.

wikiTitle: Automated Refactoring of Performance and Concurrency Anti-Patterns

title: A Performance Comparison of JPA Providers
summary:
JPA is an elegant, straightforward, and easy to use framework. This is undeniably true for simple domain models. What about real world JPA applications? Have you ever struggled with slow JPA performance? Are you in need for speed? What about scalability? 

In this talk, four frameworks: EclipseLink, Hibernate, DataNucleus, and OpenJPA compete for the title of the fastest and most scalable JPA implementation. We compare, contrast, and explain performance characteristics of these JPA implementations, mainly focusing on mappings of complex structures (specifically collections and sub-objects), JPQL efficiency, and caching. The test-cases for growing data sets reveal a speedily increasing curve of execution times. The presented code examples along with execution times show the differences among various JPA providers, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses and providing the estimates for acceptable data volumes and numbers of concurrent sessions.

title: A Security Comparison of Web Frameworks
summary: Everyone knows the importance of software security. A successful attack against an application can result in a wide spectrum of negative consequences, including the cost of a business interruption, the cost of stolen or compromised data, and a damage to the reputation. Considering a huge and still-growing technology stack used in the average enterprise application, it is extremely difficult for developers to be aware of security aspects of every web framework. In this talk, 4 frameworks: JSF, GWT, Struts2, SpringMVC compete for the title of the most secure web framework. We present best practices for developing secure applications and explain how our competitors support them. In addition, we reveal several security vulnerabilities in the selected web frameworks, including code injections and information leakage.
wikiPageName: A Security Comparison of Web Frameworks
wikiTitle: A Security Comparison of Web Frameworks

title: Security Vulnerabilities in Open-Source Java Libraries
summary: Everyone knows the importance of software security. A successful attack against an application can result in a wide spectrum of negative consequences, including the cost of a business interruption, the cost of stolen or compromised data, and a damage to the reputation. Considering a huge and still-growing technology stack used in the average enterprise application, it is extremely difficult for developers to be aware of security aspects of each and every library in their stacks. This talk presents a summary of security vulnerabilities found in popular open-source Java frameworks. We discuss such security issues like code injections, XSS, information leakage, and others. The presented open-source projects include web frameworks, JPA providers, and application servers.

title: Testing Java Persistence Layer Done Right with Arquillian
summary:
The Persistence Layer is one of the most crucial parts of enterprise applications, and we use many different frameworks and patterns to keep it clean.  We write sophisticated queries and use optimization techniques to give our end users the greatest possible experience. 

So why is Persistence very often skipped in testing efforts? Is it really that complex and painful to setup? The Arquillian Persistence Extension removes that burden and boilerplate to make you a happy and productive programmer again!  Join this session and see for yourself that writing tests for your database logic is as easy as writing normal unit tests! Don't expect too many slides, be prepared for live demo!

summary: Integration technologies are widely used and integrated in the IT infrastructure to interconnect, exchange information between systems. title: HTML5 the future of the web?
summary: There is a lot of hype around HTML5, but is HTML5 really the future of the web. Companies like Google, Adobe and even Microsoft are going the HTML5 route and stopping development on Silverlight and Flash Mobile in favor of HTML5 standards. Now HTML5 is not done yet, but there are a lot of advantages in using it, especially when developing for mobile. In this presentation I'm going to show some examples how HTML5 when used as a Mobile development platform can make for platform independence. I'll show some examples and talk about some of the frameworks that people can use to get started building the applications of tomorrow. There will be some live coding during this session to give an idea of how easy it can be to use the latest HTML5 standards to create a small application with phonegap and mGWT.

title: How to build Big Data Pipelines for Hadoop using OSS
summary:
Hadoop is not an island. To deliver a complete Big Data solution, a data pipeline needs to be developed that incorporates and orchestrates many diverse technologies.

A Hadoop focused data pipeline not only needs to coordinate the running of multiple Hadoop jobs (MapReduce, Hive, Pig or Cascading), but also encompass real-time data acquisition and the analysis of reduced data sets extracted into relational/NoSQL databases or dedicated analytical engines.

This session looks at the architecture of Big Data pipelines, the challenges ahead and how to build manageable and robust solutions using Open Source software such as Apache Hadoop, Hive, Pig, Spring Hadoop, Batch and Integration.

title: Hurdle run through testing EJB applications
summary:
Testing is inevitable - most of us agree. If you need to force your developers to write tests, you might have the wrong developers in your team. But starting testing is not always intuitive... there are frameworks and frameworks. There are environments where testing is natural, fits the tool like a glove fits the hand (say Spring, RESTeasy) and there are EJBs without much vendor support.
This session will be a practical walk through how to test EJBs, from simple unit tests, through various mocking, up to bootstrapping embedded container, vendor extensions. The session will cover some fresh and juicy JEE6 (Arquillian), but I’ll focus on EJB 3.0 with all it’s problems and hurdles (with embedding a container, using OpenEJB for testing etc). What’s the best approach and what we need to be aware. Beware - there is nothing untestable, even with an old, but still popular application server.

title: Defensible Development with Secure HTTP Headers
summary: To address security defects developers typically resort to fixing design flaws and security bugs directly in the code. Finding and fixing security defects can be a slow, painstaking, and expensive process. While development teams work to incorporate security into their development processes, issues like Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), Session Hijacking, and Clickjacking continue to plague many commonly used applications. See how these vulnerabilities actually work and see live demos showing how secure HTTP headers can be used to mitigate common attacks. Developers and architects will learn how to use the latest secure HTTP headers to proactively prevent attacks from occurring and stop hackers from exploiting their applications.

title: From Busy To Effective Developer
summary:
New technologies, web frameworks or newborn languages are very important for every developer and crucial to improve developers' skills. However, there is set of skills that very often developers miss and don't do much to improve in this area to speed up their growth.
During this session you will learn not only how to prioritize your work, what to do with "too much to do" syndrome, but also, you will learn tools and techniques to increase your productivity and save some time for even more interesting and challenging development tasks that you usually don't have time for.
We will look at:
- basic skills like touch typing
- focusing techniques (Pomodoro, GTD and others)
- PowerShell and other productivity tools
- functional tests and how they can help you be more productive as a developer
- Groovy to eliminate boring tasks
- effective usage of IM, calendar, email and phone
- gamification and fun at work
- work delegation from developer perspective
- how to protect your calendar to get your job done

title: How good are the Rendering capabilities of HTML5 and javafx?
summary:
One of the best ways to get to grips with a new technology is to try and use it in anger. For the past 2 years, Mark Stephens has been working on using HTML5 and javafx/FXML to produce a decent representation of PDF file content - in many ways the most sophisticated display format out there. Just how good are these new technologies and how do they stack up? 

So come along and find out how to use Javafx and HTML5. Find out what they offer and how you can draw on both, get lots of tips on how to push them to their limits, see how you can easily move between them and discover what their weak points are. It is time for the big show down (and guaranteed cutest kitten pictures in any Devoxx talk).

He enjoys speaking at conferences and has been a Speaker at Itext summit, Business of Software, Seybold and JavaOne conferences. He is doing a BOF at Javaone 2012 on NetBeans plugins and Javafx. summary:
Modularity is a difficult art. Osgi is a powerful technology.
After using both for 3 years in big corporate projects we as team learned many lessons on what it works and what not (at least for us).
Unfortunately it's hard to find advices on how to use Osgi to create your own architeture.
We'll show some hard learned rules of thumb for successfully embrace modularity inside your project..

Paxweb powerful tools

title: How to Write WebSocket Web Applications
summary:
The WebSocket protocol is now a standard internet protocol (RFC 6455),
and almost all browsers supports it well.
Differently from HTTP, WebSocket supports true bidirectional communication,
enabling developers to build more scalable web applications.
In this session we will look at the details of the WebSocket protocol,
of the WebSocket APIs offered by clients and servers,
of the WebSocket pros and cons, finishing with a demo showing how to
build a WebSocket web application.

title: Join the SPDY Revolution
summary:
There is a revolution quietly happening on the web and if you blink
you might miss it.
The revolution is Google’s  SPDY protocol, which may replace HTTP as
the primary protocol for the web.
In this session we will look at what is the SPDY protocol and which
improvements brings to the web,
how well is supported by browsers and servers, how it can be
25-50% faster than HTTP, and how you can make your websites
faster with Jetty and one line configuration change.

title: Comparing Functional Java Frameworks
summary: You’ve probably heard the buzz about functional programming. As a Java developer, you may have glanced at how other languages on the JVM solve many problems in a simpler, more elegant way by using the functional paradigm. Lambdas in Java 8 will address many of these issues, but what is less known is that it's actually possible to leverage some of the functional-style techniques even today. In this session, you’ll learn about real-world experiences with functional frameworks such as LambdaJ, Functional Java and Guava. What should you consider before adopting them? How do they compare against one another? If you want to be prepared for the functional future of Java 8, getting to know these techniques now will put you ahead of the curve!

title: Do you REST Assured?
summary: Today it's easy to expose services as REST/HTTP with frameworks like Jersey and Spring but validating that the server actually behaves as expected can be cumbersome in Java. REST Assured is an open source Java DSL that allows you to avoid boiler-plate code to make requests and validate even complex responses in a simple manner. Come and see how easily you can validate e.g. XML and JSON payloads by making use of Groovy data structures and closures from Java using a simple BDD-like syntax. It also comes with support for popular authentication schemes, integrates flawlessly with JUnit and TestNG and much more. Testing and validating REST services in Java cannot be much simpler!

summary:
This session will run you through the history and future of web
protocols, starting from HTTP,
then moving to WebSocket and finally to SPDY (the new protocol on the
block), analyzing pros and cons

title: Puppet for Java developers
summary:
Puppet is an infrastructure-as-code tool that allows easy and automated provisioning of servers, defining the packages, configuration, services,... in code. Enabling DevOps culture, it helps drive Agile development all the way to systems administration, and along with continuous integration tools it is a key piece to accomplish continuous delivery.

Puppet can empower developers, allowing them to code the infrastructure needed for their developments, whether it runs in hardware, virtual machines or cloud. Developers and sysadmins can define what JDK version must be installed, application server, version, configuration files, war and jar files,... and easily make changes that propagate across all nodes.

We’ll show how to install and manage Puppet nodes with JDK, application server instances with installed web applications, database, configuration files and all the supporting services. Including getting up and running with Vagrant and VirtualBox for quickstart.

title: Take Control of Your Database
summary:
Some software developers consider the database some kind of appendix to their application. It’s there even if you don’t want it. It often gets clogged and it gets inflamed. It might even become the source of some serious problems. 

But the database is in most cases an important part of the application. So if you take your job as a software developer serious you better take control of the database. Get it under version control. Test it. And do what ever it needs to keep the database a healthy  part of the application. Even if that means you have to talk with a DBA. 

This talk provides ideas about how application developers and database developers can work together in order to take control of the database and to benefit from their mutual knowledge. This includes technical advice (what and how to test database artifacts), as well as discussion of the difference in mindset and how we might overcome those.

title: Agile Whys
summary:
A session on some of the underlying concepts of Agile software development. This without touching specific methodologies or frameworks, but with focusing on the principles, values and human aspects. I will handle topics around business driven fail early lifecycles, empirical processes and knowledge work. The take away is that people have an understanding of why some practices and principles should be applied in software development in order to become more Agile. And the reason to become more Agile is to increase productivity, effectiveness, time to market and motivation. I’ve classified it under senior because it might be a bit difficult for people that have little to no experience in working on software projects.

title: Perdition or Paradise? Dealing with modular software systems to get the most out of it.
summary:
Modularity is rated as one of the key factors to decrease maintenance costs of software systems. This can be proven by a couple of scientific studies. People who failed in building modular systems often times propagate a couple of arguments like:
* The tools and processes to maintain a modular system are way too complex and therefor way too expensive.
* There are very few prominent real world examples of modular software systems. That causes some people to think that modular software systems only exist in theory and that you cannot build and maintain such a system practically.
* A lot of projects try to build a modular software system by introducing 'OSGi'. This approach is doomed if there is no modular system first.
We want to tell some stories about our experience while we moved our monolithic system into a decoupled modular system. All our experience is presented in an easy to catch guideline containing "ten commandments" you should follow on your way to a modular software systems.

title: What's new in jclouds 1.5?
summary:
jclouds 1.5 is the result of 3.5 years of development by more than 60 developers interested in portable cloud computing. You’ll get up-to-date with cloud computing technology developments such as OpenStack, CloudStack and some of the 40+ providers supported by jclouds. 
You’ll learn how to use jclouds 1.5 to control private and public infrastructures and storage clouds programmatically. You’ll also see examples of new tools powered by jclouds, including Jenkins and Whirr.
wikiPageName: What's new in jclouds 1.5
wikiTitle: What's new in jclouds 1.5
smallTitle: What's new in jclouds 1.5? by Andrew Phillips

title: OSGi Dynamics in the Cloud on OpenShift
summary:
OSGi and Cloud Computing go very well together. Previously held OSGi Cloud Workshops have clearly shown that many people are using or planning to use OSGi in the Cloud. This session focuses on a demonstration of how OSGi can really help in a Cloud environment, taking advantage of OSGi's dynamism and services model.
The demo is built on OpenShift, Red Hat's cloud which is free for developers and will show how you can use OSGi to dynamically deploy an application in the cloud and use OSGi cloud discovery to hook the various entities together, each one potentially running in a different cloud node. The demo shows concepts such as dynamic provisioning, dynamic discovery, dynamic scaling and dynamic failover all from the OSGi programming model. I will also talk about cloud-related specification work relating to what is being demonstrated that is currently an active topic in the OSGi Enterprise Expert Group.

author.speakingReferences: Past speaker at EclipseCon (2008, 2011 and 2012), Jax London, JBoss World/Red Hat summit
author.speakerBio: David Bosschaert works for JBoss at Red Hat. He has been developing software since 1983 and coding Java since 1997. He spends most of his time on Open Source OSGi projects such as the OSGi Framework in JBoss AS7 and Apache Aries. David is also one of the OSGi Enterprise Expert Group co-chairs. You can reach him at david.bosschaert@gmail.com
author.name: David Bosschaert

wikiPageName: OSGi Dynamics in the Cloud on OpenShift
wikiTitle: OSGi Dynamics in the Cloud on OpenShift
smallTitle: OSGi Dynamics in the Cloud on OpenShift by David Bosschaert

title: What can you do with the new OSGi R5 Enterprise Specs?
summary:
The OSGi R5 Enterprise specifications were recently released. A number of interesting new specs are part of this release such as:
* Repository - a requirements-based repository that allows you to find resources based on what they can do rather than what their name is.
* Resolver - the OSGi resolver can now also be used outside the framework, nice for what-if scenarios!
* Subsystems - these allow you group a number of bundles together and provides optional isolation too. Makes life easier when deploying OSGi applications.
* ServiceLoader Mediator spec - makes it possible to use java.util.ServiceLoader in OSGi.
* Common Namespaces spec - adds additional types of capabilities to the generic capabilities and requirements model introduced in OSGi R4.3.

In this talk I will show how these specs can be used in practice. My demos will use the reference implementations of these, which are done in projects in JBoss and Apache.
wikiPageName: What can you do with the new OSGi R5 Enterprise Specs
wikiTitle: What can you do with the new OSGi R5 Enterprise Specs
smallTitle: What can you do with the new OSGi R5 Enterprise Specs? by David Bosschaert

title: Eclipse 4 Application Development - The new programming model
summary:
The Eclipse Rich Client Platform is companies’ choice #1 when high-quality customer or in-house desktop applications have to be developed. In June 2012, the next generation of this wildly successful framework for building desktop applications was released to the public which finally brings lots of technical innovations to desktop application developers.

In this session we’ll dig into many of these platform innovations and show how Eclipse 4 will improve your products in terms of testability, reusability, and flexibility. In particular it will cover:

The new Eclipse 4 Application Model
How to use Dependency Injection (DI) with Eclipse 4
Using OSGi services together with DI
The IEclipseContext, context elements and context variables, ModelAddons
Extending Eclipse 4 DI mechanism with own annotations
Learn about the Eclipse 4 Application Event Bus

With more then one million visitors per month this website vogella.com is one of the central sources for Eclipse and Android programming information.

Lars is Committer in the Eclipse 4 project and received in 2010 the "Eclipse Top Contributor" and 2012 the "Eclipse Top Newcomer Evangelist" award.

title: 7 Things: How to make good teams great
summary:
Developing a product over years is a tough job. It is hard for the team to stay excited on a day to day basis. So how can you improve motivation and innovation of agile teams and still keep the focus on building a great product?

I want to share with you how we at Atlassian used an agile approach to become one of the most successful developer tool companies in the world. This talk will cover topics like FedEx days, 20-percent time, keeping distraction away from developers, lunchtime talks, dogfooding and much more.

title: Break out of your comfort zone and be more awesome
summary:
Sometimes we don't know why our software sucks. But most of the time we do know, deep down, but it's more comfortable to live with the flaw than to change it. Here are some examples: 
- Can you explain to me why there are way so many features in your software that aren't used? 
- Do you just release your software when it is ready? And this is just twice a year?
- Are you keep discussing about details without writing a single line of code?
- Why are you spending most of your time implementing features from people who scream the loudest or have the strongest opinions? 
Your comfort zone is comfortable because it's what you know. I'm sure everybody has pretty good arguments as to why the status quo is good, but if we want to become awesome we have to tackle these assumptions and norms. So let's embrace things that suck and attack them.
This session shows typical cultural anti-patterns and gives some hints how to fix the problems to become even more awesome.
wikiPageName: Break out of your comfort zone and be more awesome
wikiTitle: Break out of your comfort zone and be more awesome

title: Securing the client side: Building safe web applications with HTML5
summary: HTML5 has changed the way we build and deploy code on the web, moving much of an application's logic from the server down to a user's browser, caching data locally via storage APIs, and delivering exciting experiences without touching the network. This has excellent effects on both speed and availability, but makes it more critical than ever to practice what we preach in terms of security best practices. This talk will outline some of the ways in which you can mitigate the effects of cross-site scripting and other attacks, ranging all the way from practical use of Content Security Policy to properly sandboxing user-generated content.

author.speakingReferences: A variety of Google events (Google Developer Days and I/O, among others), Droidcon, Le Web (in a side session), and many local JavaScript user group sessions.
author.speakerBio: Mike is a developer advocate on Google's Chrome team in Munich, Germany. Since it was relatively clear early on that it would be slightly more than difficult to make a living sitting under a tree while reading Kant, he's focused his energies on the web, which happily has proven itself to be a wonderful decision. He's a committer to both Chromium and WebKit, and has worked as a web developer at companies like Yahoo! and the Süddeutsche Zeitung.

title: Continuous Delivery for the SAP ID Service: from dinosaur to spaceship in 2 years
summary:
The SAP ID Service is SAP's identity management system for its websites and cloud. The team that built it came from writing web applications in Java 1.4 for a proprietary platform where it took up to a week just to deploy a new release after it had passed mostly manual QA. 
With this new project the team rebooted itself: we adopted Scrum and started building the SAP ID Service using a lean, modern and standards-based application server built from open source components and using Continuous Delivery for build, test and deployment. We are now at the stage where each commit leads to a build with automated test coverage via Cucumber followed by a blue/green deployment to a production-like QA landscape which is provisioned from a cloud and configured automatically using Chef. A similar deployment to production is just a couple of clicks away, and the cloud-based technology used for this also enables developers to provision their own landscapes using a simple web-based tool.

author.speakingReferences:
Speaker at SAP TechEd conference, 2008-2011.
Organiser of (and speaker at) SAP Inside Track London, 2008-2010.
author.speakerBio: I work for SAP's Global IT division as an architect on the team responsible for the SAP ID Service, SAP's identity management and single sign-on platform for its websites and cloud applications.

title: Bloatware and environmental impact: Green Patterns applied to Java... and more
summary:
The manufacture of a computer emits 70 to 100 times more CO2 than a year of use. Beyond a warranty period too short, the software layer is the main factor of obsolescence of computer equipment. Indeed, the power needed to run software from a dual version to another. So that in 25 years, the average duration of computer use was divided by three. Reduce the need for material resources software is essential to reduce their power consumption and lengthen the working life of equipment.

Eco-design software is a step that is becoming increasingly necessary. The Green patterns allow developers to apply best practices to avoid an explosion of needs and reduce the environmental and technical debt. Overhead data, JVM optimization ... There are many levers to make the software more environmentally friendly!

author.speakingReferences:
Author of books "Green IT" and "Green Patterns"
Speaker on many conferences (Devoxx, Techdays...)
author.speakerBio: Olivier Philippot is an active member of Green IT community. He's the co-founder of Green Code Lab which aim is to work on eco-design of software. He works with companies and developers on projects to reduce software impact and to increase performance (Evaluation, measure...)

title: The Missing Parts in Software Evolution
summary: When adhering to agile values, the design of your software generally evolves along the way, by applying the practices of good craftsmanship. This involves much more than simply fulfilling customer requirements: It's about understanding the needs of your customers better than the customers do themselves. These practices are intuitive and sufficient for smaller systems, but as systems grow larger, more teams are involved, working in more locations, things are not so obvious. It gets more and more difficult to build a shared vision among everybody involved... without regressing to BDUF ... and you'll need to actively work on something that nature gets for free: Kill the unfit.

title: A New @Asynchronous
summary: The @Asynchronous annotation is very handy in local situations. There are some use-cases, esp. when invoking remote systems, where there is some room for improvement. The standard alternative is to use JMS, but even with the new JMS 2.0 spec, this is still a big change for the client as well as the service to use JMS instead of EJB (and it continues to add some boilerplate code for packing, unpacking, and dispatching the messages). The MessageApi project hosted on github and java.net provides an alternative.
