title: Do you like coffee with your dessert?  Java and the Raspberry Pi
summary:
The Raspberry Pi has caused a huge wave of interest amongst developers, providing an ARM powered single board computer running a full Linux distro off an SD card and all for only $35!  

This session will look at how Java can be used on a device like this.  Using Java SE for embedded devices and a port of JavaFX we will show a variety of demonstrations of what the Raspberry Pi is capable of.  The Raspberry Pi also provides GPIO line access and we’ll cover how these can be used from Java applications.  Prepare to be amazed at what this tiny board can do.

author.speakingReferences: Many: JavaOne (including keynote), Devoxx, JavaZone, JFokus and numerous other events worldwide.
author.speakerBio:
Simon Ritter is a Java Technology Evangelist at Oracle Corporation. Simon has been in the IT business since 1984 and holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Physics from Brunel University in the U.K.

Originally working in the area of UNIX development for AT&T UNIX System Labs and then Novell, Simon moved to Sun in 1996. At this time he started working with Java technology and has spent time working both in Java technology development and consultancy. Having moved to Oracle as part of the Sun acquisition he now focuses on the core Java platform and Java for client applications. He also continues to develop demonstrations that push the boundaries of Java for applications like gestural interfaces.

Follow him on Twitter, @speakjava and on his blog at blogs.oracle.com/speakjava.

title: Handwaving Redefined: Gestural Interfaces with Java and JavaFX
summary:
The way we interact with computers has changed radically over the last few years moving away from the traditional mouse and keyboard to multi-touch and even gestural interfaces.  Much of the development of these capabilities has been driven by the search for more natural ways to interact with games (the Nintendo Wii and Microsoft Kinect are great examples).

This session will look at how to build a great looking user iterface with JavaFX that can then use an array of different sensors and hardware to provide a more natural, gestural style of interface.  We’ll look at pros and cos of things like the Wiimote from Nintendo, the Kinect sensor from Micrososft and the recently announced Leap Motion high definition motion sensor.  We’ll even include the use of an EEG monitor from Neurosky so that the interface can be controlled just by thinking about it.

The session will include plenty of code samples and some great demonstrations of what’s possible.
wikiPageName: Handwaving Redefined  Gestural Interfaces with Java and JavaFX
wikiTitle: Handwaving Redefined  Gestural Interfaces with Java and JavaFX
smallTitle: Handwaving Redefined: Gestural Interfaces with Java and JavaFX by Sharat Chander

title: The Realities of Java and Low Latency Applications
summary:
Certain types of apps require low latency responses to meet all of their requirements.  The JVM makes developer’s lives easier in many ways by handling things like memory management and thread synchronisation.  To improve performance the JVM also uses numerous techniques to adaptively compile bytecodes into native instructions and library calls.  The drawback of these approaches is the non-deterministic reality of app profiles, which can be a major obstacle for those requiring very small latency of response.

This session looks at the 2 greatest issues when tuning the JVM for low latency: garbage collection and adaptive compilation.  We’ll look at how things like the introduction of the Garbage First (G1) collector and convergence of the HotSpot & JRockit virtual machines offers greater flexibility in tuning the JVM for optimal response times.  We’ll also discuss some of the coding practices that can be employed when developing Java apps making it easier to work with the JVM, rather than against it.
wikiPageName: The Realities of Java and Low Latency Applications
wikiTitle: The Realities of Java and Low Latency Applications
smallTitle: The Realities of Java and Low Latency Applications by Sharat Chander

title: Lessons learned: Usage of modern JVM Languages besides Java
summary:
Java is the main language for the JVM, but it has several shortcomings which cannot be solved in future releases such as Java 7 or 8 due to the requirement of backward compatibility. In the last years, several modern languages such as Clojure, Jython, JRuby, Groovy and Scala emerged for the JVM besides the almighty Java to improve the programming experience.

This progress report shows which modern languages we use in our projects besides Java and why we use them. The main goal is to provide information about the business value of introducing additional languages. Nevertheless, some code examples will be shown, too. 

The session shows several advantages of these languages and why a few of them should be considered at least in some parts of many projects. Of course, some non-negligible problems have to be solved when introducing new JVM languages besides Java. This sessions also describes these problems and gives hints how to solve them.

title: Seven Rules to do Business Process Management correctly
summary:
Business Process Management (BPM) is complex, expensive, and often fails! If you think so (in the year of 2012+), then you should follow the seven rules of this session to do BPM correctly. These rules are very important for success of a BPM project. If you do not consider them, your next BPM project may fail too...

At the beginning, the session describes what BPM really is. Afterwards, several myths about BPM are discussed. Many people even do not know when to use BPM, and when not to use it. Besides, the session introduces important and less important standards, and why BPM is not just tooling. However, the right tooling is a critical success factor, too. Therefore, different tools and products are presented to be able to choose the correct one for a specific BPM project.

At the end of the session, the audience will know how to do BPM correctly by following some simple, but crucial rules.
wikiPageName: Seven Rules to do Business Process Management correctly
wikiTitle: Seven Rules to do Business Process Management correctly
smallTitle: Seven Rules to do Business Process Management correctly by Kai Waehner

title: Next Generation - Systems Integration in the Cloud Era
summary:
Although it has become evident that cloud computing is the future, IT professionals need to be aware that there won’t be one single cloud solution to solve all IT problems. There will be several clouds, created by different providers and project teams. Clouds will be hosted by a range of providers, offering a range of deployment models (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, etc.) and the range of products, technologies and APIs from different vendors will continue to grow. 

Fortunately, we now have mature tools at hand to tackle integration within and across disparate cloud environments. This session compares and demonstrates options and alternatives for cloud integration, including APIs, open source integration frameworks, enterprise service bus solutions, and proprietary products. Kai will demonstrate several integration examples and deployment models based on cloud services from Amazon Web Services (IaaS), Google App Engine (PaaS), Salesforce.com (SaaS), and others.
wikiPageName: Next Generation - Systems Integration in the Cloud Era
wikiTitle: Next Generation - Systems Integration in the Cloud Era
smallTitle: Next Generation - Systems Integration in the Cloud Era by Kai Waehner

title: Systems Integration in the Cloud Era with Apache Camel
summary:
Cloud Computing is the future! Nevertheless, everybody should be aware that there won’t be one single cloud solution, but several clouds. These clouds will be hosted at different providers, use different deployment models (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) and use products, technologies and APIs from different vendors. Thus, in the future you will have to integrate these clouds as you integrate applications today. The open source integration framework Apache Camel is already prepared for this challenging task. 

Apache Camel implements the well-known Enteprise Integration Patterns and offers a standardized domain-specific language to integrate applications and clouds. All integration projects can be realized in a consistent way without redundant boilerplate code. 

This session demonstrates the elegance of Apache Camel for cloud integration. Several examples are shown for all deployment models by integrating cloud services from Amazon Web Services (IaaS), Google App Engine (PaaS), salesforce.com (SaaS), and others.
wikiPageName: Systems Integration in the Cloud Era with Apache Camel
wikiTitle: Systems Integration in the Cloud Era with Apache Camel
smallTitle: Systems Integration in the Cloud Era with Apache Camel by Kai Waehner

title: Spoilt for Choice: Which Integration Framework to use – Apache Camel, Spring Integration or Mule?
summary:
Data exchanges between companies increase a lot. The number of applications which must be integrated increases, too. The interfaces use different technologies, protocols and data formats. Nevertheless, the integration of these applications shall be modeled in a standardized way, realized efficiently and supported by automatic tests.

Three integration frameworks fulfil these requirements: Apache Camel, Spring Integration and Mule. They implement the well-known Enteprise Integration Patterns (EIP) and offer a standardized domain-specific language to integrate applications. 

These Integration Frameworks can be used in almost every integration project within the JVM environment. All integration projects can be realized in a consistent way without redundant boilerplate code.

This session shows and compares the three alternatives and discusses their pros and cons. Besides, a recommendation will be given when to use a more powerful Enterprise Service Bus (ESB) instead of one of these frameworks.
wikiPageName: Spoilt for Choice  Which Integration Framework to use – Apache Camel, Spring Integration or Mule
wikiTitle: Spoilt for Choice  Which Integration Framework to use – Apache Camel, Spring Integration or Mule
smallTitle: Spoilt for Choice: Which Integration Framework to use – Apache Camel, Spring Int... by Kai Waehner

title: Apache Camel on the JVM – Increased Integration Efficiency by choosing the right Language
summary:
Data exchanges between companies increase a lot. The number of applications which must be integrated increases, too. The interfaces use different technologies, protocols and data formats. Nevertheless, the integration of these applications shall be modeled in a standardized way, realized efficiently and supported by automatic tests.

Apache Camel is an integration framework, which fulfils these requirements. It implements the well-known Enteprise Integration Patterns (EIP) and therefore offers a standardized domain-specific language to integrate applications. All integration projects can be realized in a consistent way without redundant boilerplate code.

The efficiency is even more increased through the use of modern JVM languages. Apache Camel can be used with Java, XML, Groovy, Scala, Clojure, JRuby, Kotlin, and others. This session discusses how to gain most benefits by using the right language for the right systems integration job.

title: Business Process Management beyond Web Services
summary:
Business Process Management (BPM) is an emerging approach to optimize business processes and increase efficiency. Today, interfaces are usually specified through Web Service standards such as WS-BPEL. The limitation is unflexible and insufficient. 

This session shows a live demo about the powerful combination of two lightweight open source projects: Activiti for BPM and the integration framework Apache Camel. This combination allows to model and realize BPM. While the model and execution base on the new BPMN 2.0 standard, the integration of every thinkable technology besides Web Services, such as FTP, JMS, cloud services, and many more, is supported by Apache Camel. Even automatic testing is included. BPM was never that cheap and easy to realize in the JVM environment.

title: Java Concurrent Animated
summary:
This presentation consists of a series of animations that visualize the functionality of the components in the java.util.concurrent library.

Each animation represents a component, and features buttons that correspond to the method calls in that component. Each click of a button shows how the threads interact in real time. The animations are controlled by the actual Java concurrent component they are illustrating, so the animation is not only a visual demonstration, it's also a code sample.

Components covered include
- Executors
- Future
- Semaphore
- Reentrant Lock
- Phaser
- CompletionService
- ConcurrentHashMap
- Fork & join
And many others

If you’re still using constructs like Thread.start or wait/notify, you'll want to attend this meeting.

The presentation is packaged as a self-executable Java Archive (JAR) file and is available for download. It'll serve as a valuable reference for any Java practitioner.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne, Jazoon, JavaZone, NoFluffJustStuff, and various JUG's and SIG's. Always high ratings!

title: Tools for Java EE 7: Evolution or Revolution?
summary: In many ways, Java EE 7 is certainly an evolutionary revision of the EE platform, delivering incremental improvements of existing technologies and standards. However, some aspects of the platform are, in a subtle way, rather revolutionary. Together with the advances of client-side web technologies, such as HTML5, CSS3, Web sockets or JavaScript libraries and frameworks, Java EE 7 will accelerate the transition to a new breed of applications, in which the client side completely drives the user interface. Going forward, tools will play a crucial role in this transition. In this BOF, we will discuss how Java EE 7 will enable both incremental improvements of existing tools, as well as new tools that support the new application model.

author.speakingReferences: Spoke several times at the JavaOne conference in San Francisco, and submission was also accepted for the JavaOne 2012 conference. Recently spoke at Oracle Developer Day in Ankara (November 2011) and presented to the computer science students at the Charles University, Prague (March 2012).

title: Effective Dependency Injection
summary:
Most literature around dependency injection concentrate on teaching the basics of inversion of control with emphasis on the mechanisms. Very few resources explain how to use these mechanisms effectively (recipes) and in particular how to refactor existing code into well defined modules with properly defined external APIs, implementation bindings and documented dependencies. 

In this talk, we propose to show design patterns we encountered when refactoring existing code to use effectively the powers of Dependency Injection. 

Examples :
	- Contract/Service paradigm : define your APIs, hide your implementation, use Binding to publish.
	- The @Named code smell.
	- Use BindingAnnotations when multiple implementation exists
	- The disappearance of the Context object
	- Use Scoping everywhere. 
	- Use Explicit Binding unless you support plugins/runtime extensibility.

We expect to show around 10~15 recipes with actual code demonstrating the patterns and anti-patterns

title: java.nio.file for remote systems
summary:
The New I/O File API introduced in Java SE 7 has solved a number of shortcomings in the File API. Most importantly it was now designed for extension! For example, you can write a FileSystemProvider to perform remote file management.

The open source Overthere library implements a FileSystemProvider for SSH, CIFS, Telnet and WinRM. Furthermore, it adds an abstraction on execution of processes. We'll demonstrate how Overthere can be used to implement a number of common remote systems management scenarios such as modifying a file or deploying an application.

We'll also show you how we've implemented Overthere to perform remote system management tasks on Unix and Windows platforms. And we'll show you some of the cool bits under the hood!

author.speakerBio:
Vincent Partington is a technology entrepreneur and an Internet industry veteran with over 15 years of experience. Vincent’s passion for technology began while studying computer science at the University of Amsterdam where Vincent was involved heavily in the then budding Internet scene in Amsterdam, working at the first free Internet service (De Digitale Stad) from 1995 onwards. After graduating in 1997, he continued his work in the Internet industry. He quickly stumbled upon what was later to become J2EE and delivered his first Enterprise Java application in 1998.

After working in the Java EE space at different companies, Vincent Partington joined Xebia, in 2003. At Xebia, Vincent performed a whole range of assignments covering the spectrum of the activities of Xebia IT Architects: middleware architecture, automated build and deployment systems, performance tuning, security assessments, SOA architecture and numerous software audits. He has also taught a number of courses on Enterprise Java topics such as security and the Spring framework

Seeing a need for standard Java EE deployment automation, Vincent Partington founded the startup XebiaLabs in the summer of 2008. After delivering the first version of the product to launching customer KLM, the product, Deployit, was extended to not only support WebSphere Application Server but a host of other middleware platforms including Oracle WebLogic Server, JBoss Application Server and Tomcat. As the Chief Technical Officer of XebiaLabs Vincent is involved in development of the product and research into new features and new directions for the product.

Vincent Partington holds a masters degree in Computer Science from the University of Amsterdam in the Netherlands.

title: JavaFX: The ubiquitousness of the Java Client is back!
summary:
JavaFX has now been around for a while, and everyday it reinforces the power of java in the client platforms.  But the client market today bring a difficult paradigm to developer: what language should I use? what platform should I focus on? what tablet should I create my application for? should I go mobile or desktop?  JavaFX is the unique and sole answer to solve all these questions: write your applications once
and truly run it everywhere!

Join this session and learn everything you need to know to make your application really portable, learn how you can take your desktop application, and turn it into an amazing app that could run on any tablet.  Learn about multi-touch and gestures support in the platform.  Learn how the new JavaFX packager will help you with the packaging and distribution nightmare developers face today.

After this session you should be able to really take advantage of the ubiquitousness that JavaFX provides!

author.speakerBio: Angela Caicedo has been a Java Evangelist for 11 years, first at Sun Microsystems and now at Oracle. Angela's expertise includes: Java ME, Java SE and Java EE. She loves spending time in new and cool technologies like: Game developments, 3D, bluetooth, smartdust (Sun' SPOTs), and others. She has also presented these topics at developer conferences around the world. Angela graduated from the University EAFIT of Medellin Colombia in 1998 with a B.S. in Computer Science. During 1996-1997 Angela was a visitor student at Center for Educational Computing Initiatives at MIT. Prior to joining Sun, Angela worked for three years as a software developer and researcher at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (EPFL), in Lausanne Switzerland, and participated in several European Projects. Angela has also done research on Intelligent Agents which is one of her specialties.

title: Tools for the JavaFX platform: SceneBuilder and NetBeans.
summary:
JavaFX provides a great set of APIs for creating amazing user interfaces.  It also provides a new scriptable language called FXML,  a convenient alternative for constructing graphs in procedural code, and is ideally suited to defining the user interface of a JavaFX application.

As powerful as FXML sounds it's cumbersome to write it manually, that's when tools come really handy.  JavaFX Scene Builder a design tool for the JavaFX platform, and it allows for a simple drag-and-drop positioning of components onto a JavaFX scene, generating the correspondent FXML code.  This tool, working together with NetBeans provides  everything developers need to have to take advantage of JavaFX new features and put it together with their already existent application. A truly Java development experience.

title: Annox : Annotation and NoSQL Based JMX Configuration Framework
summary:
Annox is a framework that tries to solve issues and difficultness in the usage of the JMX and it enables application configuration to be defined very easily using annotations with bean objects. Framework also supports customizable configuration persistence (1), bean validations, OSGi and Rest.

Annox framework has developed internally in Vodafone R&D department and is being used in core network applicaton configurations. It will be open sourced for Java community usage. 

Presentation summary is detailed below:

• Framework development motivation and JMX
• Framework structure and features
• Programming API
• Persistence features
• Bean validation (JSR-303) support
• OSGi and Rest support
• Sample application
• Questions & Answers

(1) Annox uses MongoDB for persistence, a NoSQL database, by default. This can be changed by using the API.

   - Basic and advanced Java programming
   - SQL and PL/SQL basics

• Internal instructor in Vodafone Turkey. Subjects of speakings include,
   - Agile Product Management with Scrum
   - Classloading internals of Java
   - Service Delivery Framework Architecture

Ender Aydin Orak | Software Architect @ Vodafone R&D - Turkey

Working as a software architect in Vodafone for 2 years, has 10 years of software and 7 years of Java application development experience. Lead developer of Annox framework with several other open source projects including OSF (Open Service Framework) and SimpleAssist. title: Starting off Vaadin 7 on the right foot
summary: In this session, we'll create a simple Vaadin 7 CRUD application. This talk begins with a short introduction on Vaadin's architecture. Then, we'll begin developing the application step by step, each step bringing an additional concept into play. At first, we'll create the project itself. This will let us detail how this could be done in Eclipse. Then, we'll go on to add a login window with fields and button: here, we'll detail how Vaadin uses event oriented programmation. Two option are available, one using interfaces, the other introspection, each will be discussed for pros and cons. This will be the time to have a look at layouts. At this time, a word will be said about Single Page Interface applications and we'll see how to change our screen content. Finally, we'll connect our UI layer to a database with various means (pure JDBC, Hibernate and/or JPA) and display the database content to the user. This will be the chance to have a look at some powerful Vaadin abstractions like Container and Item.

title: Using GWT widgets in your Vaadin 7 applications
summary:
In this session, we'll learn about wrapping existing GWT widgets in Vaadin 7 applications. Note this session doesn't require GWT skills at all.

The development will be done around 3 main axes: the first one will be to connect the GWT widget to a newly-created Vaadin component. The second one will be to be able to configure the GWT widget from the Vaadin component. The third and final step will be to be able to send events from the client-side to the server component.

At the end of the session, all participants will be able to create their own components around GWT widgets.

summary:
There have been a lot of CDI talks at Devoxx since 2009, but with this university we want to show how the CDI framework can be put in practice with two great projects : Weld OSGi and Agorava (the social framework). By exploring a real application (a Social Network client managing multiple services) we'll show :
- Basic CDI 1.0 concepts
- A deep dive into CDI extension mechanism
- Using Decorator et Event framework in CDI
- Introduction of modularity in CDI with Weld OSGi
- A state of CDI eco-system with Apache Deltaspike

title: Discover Agorava the CDI based Social Framework
summary:
Agorava is the missing framework to deal with Social Media based on OAuth 1.0a and OAuth 2.0. It provides a way to authenticate on Social Media, use their REST APIs and map JSON exchanges with java POJOs. It’ll have multiple implementations (Java SE, JSR 330 implementation frameworks) but in this talk we'll focus on the CDI one.
This talk will deal with :
- The history of JSR 357
- The main concept of Agorava 
- How do we provide common services for different Social Media
- Feedback on JAX-RS 2.0 client framework and OAuth implementation
- Feedback on Jackson
- How Agorava uses CDI and DeltaSpike

title: Controversial Java features
summary:
Programming languages add features over time to aid developers in their day to day programming. For example, Java 7 introduced several features (reduced generics syntax, safe file handling, making large numbers readable and more) as part of 'Project Coin' to make a Java programmer's life simpler. However, are all new language features desirable or useful?
 
In this talk, we present recent empirical studies about controversial and hotly debated Java features.
 
The attendance will learn surprising facts about how core features are used in practice. For example:
- Seven years later, have generics helped reduce type casts and code duplication? 
- Covariant arrays are often seen as a language design error, but do programmers care?
- What do programmers use wildcards for?
- How do programmers use overloading? Could it be replaced with other features?
- Are checked exceptions really beneficial?
wikiPageName: Controversial Java features

title: assertImmutable : Introducing Mutability Detector
summary: Mutability Detector is a lightweight static analysis tool for Java which allows you to unit test for immutability. Using immutable objects is regarded as improving readability of your Java code, and greatly simplifying multithreaded code. However, without language support, it's all to easy to render classes mutable, and introduce the potential for subtle, hard to detect bugs. Mutability Detector gives developers a way to write immutable classes, and help keep them immutable.

title: The Beauty and the Beast: JavaScript meets JMX
summary:
Javascript and JMX are both older than the hills and started their
lives in the last century in opposite corners of the technology space.
    
Javscript lived in its niche for a very long time until it took of
like a rocket and is the brightest star in the web sky nowadays.

JMX on the other hand started its fossilisation some years ago and
although its future is more than unclear, JMX is still present in
every JVM out there and is still a very influential technology in the
monitoring world.
    
This talk presents a JavaScript-JMX crossover mix using Jolokia, the
open source HTTP-JMX bridge which connects both worlds. Several show
cases are demonstrated for how to access JMX from JavaScript.

"Aji", a new JMX console and realtime dashboard written in JavaScript,
will be demonstrated the first time live. It comes piggybacked with
Jolokia agents and does not require separate installation.

Now let's go take a look at the Beauty and the Beast ...

Roland is the lead of the Jolokia project and loves chili pepper as much as JMX.

title: What's new in PDF 2.0 regarding digital signatures
summary:
In 2008, the PDF specification was published as an ISO standard: ISO-32000-1 (based on PDF 1.7). If all goes well, ISO-32000-2 (PDF 2.0!) will be released in 2013. One of the important changes involves digital signatures. PDF 2.0 will include the PAdES standard published by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). Furthermore some of the old types of digital signatures will be deprecated.
In his talk, Bruno will guide you through the world of digital signing using a plethora of examples (including a demo on how to sign a document using the javax.smartcardio package). He'll focus on the best practices regarding signing, so that developers can make their applications future-proof.
Target audience: developers who don't want to write code creating digital signatures that will be deprecated in 2013, or who want to update their existing code, making it "PDF 2.0-ready".

summary:
Are you an Android developer? Do you want to make your app beautiful, but cannot afford a designer? Fear not, there are many easy techniques to prettify your app.

Use xml and java to touch up your Android app:
* Gradients and round corners
* Tiling background
* Custom font
* Responsive components that look different when focused and pressed

In addition to the techniques, I will show you some useful resources to integrate into your app:
* Color schemes
* Graphics
* Patterns
* Icons

By the end of the session you will be equipped to prettify your app and make it stand out in the crowded marketplace.

title: Travelling Salesman: Problem solved with Java and Artificial Intelligence
summary:
Always had an interest in the usage of Artificial Intelligence? 

In this session, some of the most prominent Artificial Intelligence techniques will be explained and implemented using Java. Using the simple-to-understand “Traveling Salesman Problem”, the Artificial Intelligence techniques Neural Networks, Evolutionary Algorithms and Multi-Agent Systems will be explained. 

After getting this basic understanding, see how these complex algorithms can be implemented fairly simple in Java. Attention will also be given to publicly available Artificial Intelligence frameworks and APIs. Live demos will be given where appropiate.

At the end of this session it is clear how Java and Artificial Intelligence can collaborate to solve complex problems such as the Travelling Salesman Problem.

summary:
A lot has happened since the Devoxx last year where feature plans for the next major JAX-RS 2.0 API release were presented. 

Now that the work on JSR 339 is over and with the steaming fresh final JAX-RS 2.0 and Jersey 2.0 release out of the door it is a great time to reiterate over the new noteworthy additions to the API such as the new client API, filters and interceptors, asynchronous resources, data validation, improved content negotiation or hyperlinking and show some of them directly in action running on Jersey 2.0.

As title suggests, the last part of the talk will be focused on discussing early future plans for either the JAX-RS API or new Jersey features.

JavaScript has become one of the most important programming languages of the 21st century. Due to its use in mobile applications it is the most prevalent scripting language today, and is associated with many successful open source projects, libraries and frameworks.

Highlights will include a look at the new JavaScript editor, enhanced with many useful features; supporting frameworks such as jQuery, ExtJs and others. title: Syntactic Salt and Sugar
summary: For the past few years and currently there is much hype around simplifying and reducing the noise in the code.  Whether it’s DSL’s, closures (Project Lambda), aspects, CDI, or annotations, fundamental changes have and are occurring that are loosely classified as syntactic sugar.  This presentation takes a step back by having an open and honest discussion from two different perspectives from an advocate for the syntactic sugar and a pragmatic engineer that sees some of it as syntactic salt.  Whether you see these elements as sugar or salt, you can take a step back and assess whether these elements really simplify the code or make the code more complex.

title: Building Amazing Applications with JavaFX
summary: Customers rank visual appearance and user experience as major considerations. Many developers believe that the #1 differentiator from the competition is how an application looks. For enterprise applications, the look and style of an application were often afterthoughts, but now they’re among the top considerations. You can think of this as the “Apple effect.” Apple has taught the world that design matters, and that is influencing customers’ purchasing decisions even when it comes to enterprise software. JavaFX is well situated to help you design applications that will impress any customer. This session shows how to build well-designed applications with JavaFX and features such as CSS, Scene Builder, and custom controls.

summary: HTML 5 is the new kid on the block, with many organizations standardizing around it. Where can Java technology be leveraged in the context of HTML 5? And what kind of tools and methodologies would be appropriate to use in the HTML 5 world? In this session, you will be introduced to complete end to end scenarios where Java web services are incorporated in HTML 5 contexts, together with a set of tools that simplifies all the tasks involved. You will leave the session with a clear understanding of HTML 5, its interconnectedness with Java, and a thorough overview of the steps to take to make the most of all the related methodologies and tools.

title: Smart, Small, Connected: Java in the Internet of Things
summary: The "Internet of Things" is rapidly happening around us. By 2016, intelligent connected systems are predicted to outnumber phones & personal computers and generate the majority of web traffic. Intelligent systems are the next frontier to build new solutions, drive efficiencies, and create business opps on a huge scale across a wide range of markets such as healthcare, industrial automation, power distribution and usage, and more. Java, with it's cross-platform, productive, and secure design, is already present in over 10B devices globally. Oracle is ensuring Java is best positioned to drive this next wave of embedded, connected, and ubiquitous computing. In this talk, learn about Oracle's vision for the "Internet of Things", and how we’re working with the industry to advance embedded Java platforms & products to meet the future. The 2nd half of the talk introduces a new embedded Java product and then spend time in a tutorial-style demo building a connected embedded solution with hardware, tools, and coding.

title: JavaFX: The ubiquitousness of the Java Client is back!
summary:
JavaFX has now been around for a while, and everyday it reinforces the power of java in the client platforms.  But the client market today bring a difficult paradigm to developer: what language should I use? what platform should I focus on? what tablet should I create my application for? should I go mobile or desktop?  JavaFX is the unique and sole answer to solve all these questions: write your applications once
and truly run it everywhere!

Join this session and learn everything you need to know to make your application really portable, learn how you can take your desktop application, and turn it into an amazing app that could run on any tablet.  Learn about multi-touch and gestures support in the platform.  Learn how the new JavaFX packager will help you with the distribution nightmare developers face today.

After this session you should be able to really take advantage of the ubiquitousness that JavaFX provides!
wikiPageName: JavaFX  The ubiquitousness of the Java Client is back!
wikiTitle: JavaFX  The ubiquitousness of the Java Client is back!
smallTitle: JavaFX: The ubiquitousness of the Java Client is back! by Sharat Chander

title: Tools for the JavaFX platform: SceneBuilder and NetBeans
summary:
JavaFX provides a great set of APIs for creating amazing UI.  It also provides a new scriptable language called FXML,  a convenient alternative for constructing graphs in procedural code, and is ideally suited to defining the UI of a JavaFX app, since the hierarchical structure of an XML document closely parallels the structure of the JavaFX scene graph. 

As powerful as FXML sounds it's cumbersome to write it manually, that's when tools come really handy.  JavaFX Scene Builder is a design tool for the JavaFX platform, and it allows for a simple drag-and-drop positioning of GUI components onto a JavaFX scene, generating the correspondent FXML code.  This tool, working together with NetBeans, provides everything developers need to have to take advantage of JavaFX new features and put it together with their already existent app.

Learn everything you need to know about the JavaFX Scene Builder and NetBeans features supporting JavaFX like runtime scene graph snapshots, debugging/profiling apps, and more.
wikiPageName: Tools for the JavaFX platform  SceneBuilder and NetBeans
wikiTitle: Tools for the JavaFX platform  SceneBuilder and NetBeans
smallTitle: Tools for the JavaFX platform: SceneBuilder and NetBeans by Sharat Chander

title: The Realities of Java and Low Latnecy Applications
summary:
Certain types of apps require low latency responses to meet all of their requirements.  The JVM makes developer’s lives a lot easier in many ways by handling things like memory management and thread synchronisation.  To improve performance the JVM also uses numerous techniques to adaptively compile bytecodes into native instructions and library calls.  The drawback of these approaches is the non-deterministic reality of app profiles, which can be a major obstacle for those requiring very small latency of response.

This session will look at the two greatest issues when tuning the JVM for low latency: garbage collection and adaptive compilation.  We’ll look at how things like the introduction of the Garbage First (G1) collector and convergence of the HotSpot and JRockit VMs offers greater flexibility in tuning the JVM for optimal response times.  We’ll also discuss some of the coding practices that can be employed when developing Java apps making it easier to work with the JVM, rather than against it.
wikiPageName: The Realities of Java and Low Latnecy Applications

smallTitle: The Realities of Java and Low Latnecy Applications by Sharat Chander

title: JSR 353 : Java API for JSON Processing
summary: JSON is a lightweight data exchange format used increasingly in RESTful Web services by highly visible Websites (Facebook, Twitter, Amazon, and the like). The format is easy for humans and machines to read and write. JSON is quickly becoming the primary choice for developers for consuming and creating Web services. JSR 353: Java API for JSON Processing intends to create a standard Java API for JSON so that the applications that use the API are smaller and portable. The goal of the API is to produce/consume JSON text in a streaming fashion and also to build a Java object model for JSON text. Attend this session for the JSR update, discussion of the API, and information on how to utilize this API in applications.

title: JavaFX for Business Application Developers
summary:
JavaFX is not only about fancy graphics and animation. What can be easily overlooked is how well JavaFX suits the needs of business application developers. 

This talk will focus on the benefits of JavaFX for business application developers. Using a JavaFX client for a JavaEE server application as an example, we will go through the steps that were required to build the application. We will discuss the roles that were involved and the tools that have been used. 

Another focus will be functionality of JavaFX that is usually most interesting for business applications, e.g. layout, data-binding, and CSS-styling.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne, Devoxx, JFokus, 33rd Degree, JavaOne India, JCertif, and others
author.speakerBio:
Michael has been part of the JavaFX development team right from its early days in 2008. During the early access phase until the release of JavaFX 1.0, he was part of the JavaFX Compiler team. After that Michael joined the JavaFX Mobile team where he was mainly responsible for performance tuning. In 2010 he became the technical lead for the core components of JavaFX:  JavaFX Beans and Properties, the Binding API, the new collections and the Animation API.

Michael is fascinated by creativity and explores all possibilities to encourage and foster it. In his spare time, he creates a new web application SketchHatch that helps distributed groups of people to become more creative and productive during meetings (http://sketchhatch.com).

summary: During this BOF, a game will be developed that uses the JavaFX 2.0 library. Starting with an empty project, step by step all parts are coded live while the underlying concepts are explained. At the end of the talk, we will have covered all fundamental components of the JavaFX library (e.g. scenegraph, animation, events, bindings) including example code that uses these components.

title: Gamestorming for Software Developers
summary:
"Hopefully this meeting is over soon, and I can get back to my desk to get some real work done!" 

Meetings are an essential part of software development. We gather with our colleagues in the hope of finding innovative solutions to our problems or generating breakthrough new ideas. But yet, most meetings are dull, monopolized by a few and more often than not they produce no satisfying results.

But in recent years a new trend emerged to fight the abyss of unproductive meetings: Gamestorming - creative games instead of endless discussions. In this talk we will explore why Gamestorming is so successful, why games are not only more fun, but can help us to generate more and better ideas, too. And we will look at some important rules and guidelines to follow while conducting games in meetings.

To round it off we will go over some of the most popular and effective games that are particularly useful in the context of software engineering.
wikiPageName: Gamestorming for Software Developers
wikiTitle: Gamestorming for Software Developers

title: Introduction to heuristics and metaheuristics for business resource optimization
summary:
Not all puzzles are easily solvable with a brute force loop to try every combination. Sometimes the search space is just too large and there is no smart, exact algorithm to solve it either. Many business planning problems, such as vehicle routing, employee rostering, task scheduling and bin packing fall into this category. Yet, humans still solve them every day. Can computers do a better job?

Yes, they can, resulting in schedules with lower expenses, a lower environmental footprint and higher service quality. In practice, these programs use algorithms such as Tabu Search and Simulated Annealing.

In this presentation, I will explain the inner working of several construction heuristics and metaheurstics using simple examples. I 'll demonstrate them on several use cases with my optimization framework Drools Planner. When you leave this session, you should be able to solve a planning problem, implement such algorithms yourself and reuse those algorithms from an existing optimization framework.

Since he started Drools Planner in 2006, he’s been passionately addicted to planning optimization.

title: 10 Months of MongoDB at Nokia Entertainment Bristol
summary:
A look at how a small group of self-motivated developers went about introducing, first themselves, and then their organisation to MongoDB. What made them do it? How did they gain acceptance for a new storage system amongst their peers, administrators and development managers? What was it like to actually write code around MongoDB? 

Join me for the answers and get the inside story of an adoption not yet a year old.

title: Business resource optimization with Drools Planner
summary:
Whether it’s employee rostering, task scheduling, vehicle routing, bin packing or another planning problem: all organizations try to optimize their limited resources under constraints. So why do most of them do such a poor job? Why do they continue to execute schedules with higher expenses, a higher environmental footprint and lower service quality? Because it’s computationally very difficult and humanly impossible to optimize these problems.

Drools Planner optimizes planning problems for normal Java programmers. It implements a series of optimization algorithms which can optimize any planning problem. The input and output are plain old java beans (POJO’s), constraints can be expressed in OO manner as Drools Expert rules or plain old Java and there's a complete reference manual and many examples.

In this presentation, I will explain the nature of planning problems, go through an entire Drools Planner example, show some demo’s and compare results.

summary: Creating a web site, web app, or native app for mobile use presents a special set of challenges. Specifically, developers and designers should be zoned into the techniques for usability - and usability can be enhanced greatly by taking performance elements into consideration up-front. In this session, we explore the many performance tips and tricks you can employ to make your website or web app or native app shine on mobile devices. This is an advanced course that discusses issues such as image batching.

title: Mobile Development Options
summary: Mobile development is hot - and there's a bevy of options for developing mobile apps. If you're looking at cross-platform solutions, there's a multitude of options to choose from. In this session we'll explore the three basic categories for developing mobile apps: native, cross-platform-to-native, and mobile web. We'll discuss the sweet spot for each of these three approaches and the benefits and drawbacks of each. Technologies discussed include Android, iOS, HTML5/CSS3, Phonegap, Titanium, and jQuery Mobile.

title: Appcelerator Titanium Workshop
summary:
Bring your laptop! Use your JavaScript skills to build *native* iOS and Android apps! Learn from an Appcelerator Titan!

This is a full day workshop specifically designed to get you up and running with Titanium and build feature-rich applications! We'll install the latest Titanium Developer and iOS SDK - then create a project in Titanium Developer and run it in the simulator to verify your setup.  Basic JavaScript experience is necessary for this session; please complete a basic JavaScript course or book before attending.

Titanium is an open-source development tool for producing cross-platform mobile applications by Appcelerator. Using Titanium, you develop your mobile application using Javascript coded against the Titanium API's. Titanium Studio, an IDE for your mobile apps, invokes their compiler and builder to take your Javascript and build a native application for iOS and Android.

title: Groundhog Day: Object Oriented Programming versus Functional Programming
summary: It seems like Groundhog Day, where the programming community is reconsidering the argument of Object Oriented Programming versus Functional Programming.  Languages like Scala, Erlang, Clojure, and the inclusion of closures in languages like Java is making Functional Programming vogue again.  Has something gone wrong with Object Oriented Programming that is fixed by Functional Programming?  Is the programming community maturing or regressing?  The session will discuss Object Oriented Programming versus Functional Programming from an advocate of Object Oriented Programming and an advocate for the new vogue Functional Programming.

title: Building Vaadin Applications With Pure Scala
summary:
Vaadin is a server-side Java framework for building rich internet applications. Since it's a Java framework, any JVM language can be used to create applications with Vaadin. Since each language has its own characteristics, adding some convenience methods can enable taking full advantage of the language with Vaadin. This presentation introduces Scaladin, a wrapper library that provides a pure Scala API for Vaadin.

Compared to other Scala web frameworks Scaladin provides a different approach for building web applications: It's possible to create rich internet applications with a component-based server-side API without HTML templates, taglibs, XML configuration or even JavaScript. The presentation introduces Scaladin and shows key concepts and ideas behind it. For demonstration purposes, a web application is written on stage. The step-by-step tutorial uses a full Scala tool chain to build the application.

author.speakingReferences: JDD 2012

He has been a part of the Vaadin team since 2007, and lately he has studied how to use Vaadin with Scala. Henri is a co-author of Scaladin, a wrapper library that provides a pure Scala API for Vaadin.

summary: Is HTML5 ready for production code? Of course it is. This is a look into all the different HTML5 technologies that can be used in your code, today. We'll review a collection of tips, tricks, and best practices for HTML5 and W3C APIs such as Web Storage, Web Sockets, Web Workers, Geolocation, and Device Orientation. We’ll examine how these APIs contrast between desktop and mobile environments, then we’ll go into a deep dive on real world implementations for each one.

summary:
With all the fragmentation across mobile devices, knowing how to support, test, and gracefully degrade new HTML5 related features can lead to many nights of heavy drinking.
Fortunately, there are a handful of W3C specifications that can be used now and are widely supported across all modern web browsers. 
We’ll code live demos showing how to use device features such as the accelerometer, Web Storage, Web Sockets, Geolocation and Web Workers.

title: lightweight and reproducible environments with Vagrant and Puppet
summary:
Many developers are in need of complex development- and test environments for different projects with customers. The ideal situation would be to have them running in a sandbox. With help of the Cloud and VMs it's possible to create those sandbox-environments but administration, configuration and maintenance cost a lot of time and money. 
With a combination of Vagrant & Puppet it's possible to create and configure those environments "on the fly". Anytime, anywhere and above all reproducible.
The Talk shows how fast you can create and configure a sandbox for a Java environment including an Application Server and a database with the help of those tools.

title: JavaFX for the Enterprise
summary: JavaFX is fast approaching the point where applications can be built and deployed on desktop and mobile platforms, which will make it good choice for targeting the new generation of enterprise projects. In this workshop we'll cover the basics of the JavaFX APIs for building custom (and good looking!) components, such as binding, styling and animation. Then we'll switch gears into proper application development, leaning on the Griffon framework for the heavy lifting. Adding database and network access requirements (via REST interfaces for example) is quite straight forward thanks to the good number of plugins supported by the framework. The workshop assumes attendees have a fair knowledge of desktop application development (whether it's Swing, SWT and/or JavaFX).

title: Low latency event processing at massive scale
summary: Efficient, low-latency and in-order event processing has always been at the focus of financial institutions and investment banks. It is also relevant today more than ever to other domains, such as ecommerce, web analytics and online booking. In a world where every millisecond counts, parallelizing the processing as much as possible is essential. This session describes common patterns for parallelism when handling events at massive scale and the trade offs associated with each approach. Slides can be found at http://www.slideshare.net/uri1803/trade-and-event-processing-a

title: PaaS and DevOps - Friends or Foes?
summary: Tools like Chef and Puppet have gained a lot of momentum in the last year or so. But the concept of DevOps and recipes can go well beyond setup, to actually accelerate the entire lifecycle of your applications, from setup, to monitoring, through maintaining high availability, and auto-scaling when required. In this session we'll see how to use Chef and new open source framework called Cloudify together to manage any application stack on any cloud environment.

title: Big data apps on the cloud - the good, the bad and the ugly
summary: The massive computing and storage resources that are needed to support big data applications make cloud environments an ideal fit. But managing your big data app is no walk in the park - configuration, orchestration, HA, auto-scaling are all quite hard to do. This session will map the existing big data tools landscape and what it means to run them on the cloud, and then discuss various alternatives to run them, such as PaaS solutions, devops tools, and pre canned cloud services.

summary: Today's application stack consists of many popular OSS frameworks such as Cassandra, MongoDB, Scala, Play, Memcached, RabitMQ alongside the more traditional JEE stack which includes app servers such as Tomcat and JBoss. In this environment the same practices that we used to have in the JEE centric world for managing and deploying our app are not relevant anymore. In this session we'll introduce a new open source framework called Cloudify, which makes use of a Groovy based DSL for packaging your application, pushing it to the cloud, automating scaling and failover and more.

title: Software Craftsmanship
summary:
This talk is about how we implement Software Craftsmanship at Kabisa - a mostly Ruby on Rails and Java development shop. We recognize clean code, we apply TDD/BDD, we throw away our code. Less is more! We participate Code Dojo's.

This talk will talk the audience through recognizing bad code and the steps you can take (that we at Kabisa took) to write clean code, while becoming happier developers and a more profitable company.

The attached slides are only a rough draft of the talk that I was going to do for Unit 4 Dev Days. More topics will be added for the final Devoxx talk.

summary: JSF provides a powerful infrastructure to build RIA applications in a rapid way. Combined with PrimeFaces, the leading component suite, JSF unleashes it's true power. This session covers various aspects of PrimeFaces including Core Features, UI Components, Ajax Extensions, HTML5 features, Theme Framework, Mobile UI kit, Ajax Push via Websockets, Cloud and more.

title: The Pi-calculus brings parallelism into mainstream languages.
summary: Ateji PX integrates parallelism at the language level into Java based on the Pi-calculus as a strong theoretical foundation. Parallel code written with this language extension is not only concise, intuitive and efficient, it also leads to interesting new programming idioms. The tool presentation will concentrate on the comparison of typical idioms induced by features such as synchronous rendez-vous and non-deterministic choice, in comparison with standard parallel programming based on the concurrency library. The Ateji PX language and compiler are available for free.

author.speakerBio: Patrick Viry is an expert in both language engineering and computation models for parallel programming. He earned a PhD from INRIA, made a carrier in the academia, with publications in prestigious journals, and later in the industry managing language development projects. He has lived and worked in France and in Japan. He founded Ateji with the goal to make innovative language technologies available to the developers community. Patrick has been the lead designer of the Ateji PX language extension for parallel programming.

title: Eclipse: An Application Lifecycle Management Success Story
summary: With Hudson driving builds from the top; Git, Gerrit, Maven, and Tycho in the middle; and Mylyn controlling the pieces from the developer's desktop, The Eclipse Foundation provides an impressive stack of technologies for building software. All this great technology combined with governance, intellectual property management, architectural guidance, and coordination via the simultaneous release, combine to deliver an Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) solution that is the envy of other open source projects and IT departments around the globe. In this session, we'll present all the pieces and show how they work together; we'll talk about evolution of the our processes and infrastructure, and muse about how they'll grow in the future.

author.speakingReferences: Wayne has delivered multiple talks at numerous user groups, including BeJUG, Boston JUG, and Victoria JUG in beautiful Victoria, British Columbia, Canada. title: Android meets Arduino
summary:
Android has several built in sensors, many connectivity solutions and a graphical user interface. This presentation will list the options to let your Android powered device communicate with Arduino in order to drive motors and pass sensor information. 

For each option to combine these forces I will list the pro's and cons. I will finish by a live demonstration on how easily a non connected robot can be connected using bluetooth and the amarino-toolkit. This requires minimal coding efforts which can be demonstrated on the live screen. For this I can modify the demo shown in the beginning of the presentation adding some initial interactivity.

After some explanation on how the amarino-toolkit works I can demonstrate an interactive demo using twitter, letting attendees can control the robot.

title: Will It Float [in Java]?
summary:
In this session we will undertake a rigorous, empirical methodology to find out the current state of Java on devices of all sizes and shapes.  Using the time-tested technique of technology immersion, the capabilities of running different devices in Java will be physically demonstrated.  We will uncover some surprising developments in Java on mobile, embedded, and consumer devices with a look into the future of Java M2M applications.  This session will be run by experts in the field of device buoyancy, so audience members are strongly cautioned against trying these experiments on their own!

Notes to committee: The plan is to take a fishtank, fill it with coffee, and throw a bunch of devices in it.  If our waterproofing is good, we may even have some bleeding-edge technology demos to go along with this!

title: The Truth Behind Big Agile - Confessions from a Former Agile Methodologist
summary: While I am best known as a JavaFX advocate, my day job prior to joining Oracle was Chief Agile Methodologist and I facilitated 3 company-wide Agile rollouts.  As a result, I have quite a bit of real-world experience with the good, the bad, and the ugly of Agile practices.  If you are skeptical of folks trying to sell you certifications, frustrated with the institution of new processes and tracking systems, or wary of process experts taking the place of technical leadership, then this is the session for you.  Come learn the insider secrets of how Agile works in a large enterprise from someone who has been in the eye of the hurricane.  However, be warned that this knowledge will give you the power to change the development culture in your organization for better or worse -- are you ready to shoulder this responsibility?

The talk will start with a brief introduction and dive into best practices and implementation patterns later one. We will conclude the session with an overview over what can actually be built on top of this generic repository abstraction and discuss integration hooks into Spring MVC and REST webservices.

title: 7 Signs that you have used OSGi wrongly
summary:
Since the first release of the OSGi Enterprise specification in March 2010 the use of OSGi in the enterprise has increased dramatically. Moving traditional Java EE applications to an OSGi stack is intentionally as easy as possible, however there are a number of common mistakes that can make it feel very hard. This session will describe some best practices for developing Enterprise OSGi applications and OSGi bundles, allowing developers to utilise the power of OSGi in a painless way.

Whilst this session is primarily aimed at enterprise developers new to OSGi, much of the content is equally applicable to OSGi development in general, and is definitely recommended to anyone looking to brush up on their OSGi principles!

Based at IBM's Hursley laboratory in the UK, she has worked in WebSphere Application Server since 2006 and a senior developer on OSGi support in WebSphere Application Server. She is an active member of OSGi Enterprise Export Group and currently works on the next OSGi Enterprise specification. Emily also participates in open source projects. She is a committer of the Apache Aries project.

title: Subsystems: developing Enterprise OSGi Applications
summary:
Enterprise OSGi 4.2 standardized the use of a number of component models for developing Enterprise OSGi applications: Servlet, JSP, Blueprint, and JPA. Implementations of these specifications have since become available in many open source projects and products such as Apache Aries, Eclipse Gemini/Virgo, GlassFish, and WebSphere Application Server. Looking at a number of these environments, it's clear that when it comes to assembly and deployment there's still something missing, namely something to represent a collection of bundles (e.g. an Application). Hence the Subsystems specification is being created for the Enterprise OSGi 5.0 specification.
Subsystems is an OSGi specification which standardizes artifacts representing collections of bundles. This presentation will describe how Subsystems can be used for development and deployment of bundle collections with different isolation semantics, to address the application, composite and feature use cases seen in the OSGi community today.

title: (The Art of) (Java) Benchmarking
summary: "If you can't measure it, you can't optimize it". Whenever you measure performance, you do a benchmark run. Whenever you reason about performance, you better have a good benchmark, which tests the "right thing". The smaller your benchmark, the larger your knowledge about benchmarked platform should be. Every single optimization in software and hardware is the potential microbenchmark failure point. Doing Java (micro)benchmarking without understanding of HW and JVM specifics is shooting yourself in the foot. What are the key things to keep in mind while doing (Java) benchmarking?

title: A new Lightweight Persistence API as an alternative to ORM complexity
summary:
Sometimes lightness is better to keep the control of a relational database in Java development.

The Lightweight Persistence API (LPA) is an alternative to classical ORM, it keeps the JPA mapping style (with annotations) but it is very light (no cache, no byte-code instrumentation, no implicit loading), simple to understand and easy to learn for everyone (no expertise required).

The mottoes are “back to basics” and “keep it simple” (no headache by trying to understand what’s going on behind the API).

This talk aims to explain the features of LPA (“Record Oriented Persistence”, queries, DataSet, …)  and to demonstrate how to use it.

A short demonstration will show how to generate the entities and the mapping annotations from an existing database with an Eclipse plugin.

title: Re-imagining the browser with AngularJS
summary:
What if you could write modern web apps with dramatically fewer lines of code and improve its readability and expressiveness at the same time? No, there’s no new language to learn. Just familiar old HTML and JavaScript. As a matter of fact, there’s some stuff for you to un-learn.

AngularJS is a client-side JavaScript web development framework where we believe we’ve done something special. We’ve approached the problem let’s say differently from the way any other JavaScript tool has before. Instead of asking what kind of functions we could provide to make writing apps smoother, we asked “what if the browser worked differently in a way that eliminates code and gives structure to apps?”

This talk will take the audience on a tour of what the web platform of the future will look like and how the AngularJS framework can provide many of the powerful capabilities to existing browsers and bridge the path to web components, model driven views and other platform features that are currently being spec-ed.

title: Minuteproject reverse-engineering tool
summary:
Minuteproject is a tool that proposes reverse-analysis functionalities whether starting from legacy database or from stratch as an iterative development methodology.
This talk will be demo-oriented and we'll see how to reverse-engineered enterprise size model (based on a well-known OS product 150+ entities) and generate, customize, integrate generated code for JPA2 backend.
Minuteproject offers also Statement Driven Development features. When you consider that SQL is the only DSL you need with its I/O, then starting from a statement you can get an app.
A demo will illustrate how to get a REST app (CXF, Spring) + Html5 client starting from SQL statement with some parameters.

title: The advantage of Using Rest API’s in Portal Platforms to extend the reach of the portal.
summary:
While JSR-311 is part of J2EE6, we decided to use it within our OS Portal platform Entando, to allow the exchange of information between external systems.
The session will start with an intro to Entando. We will also create an example that will provide an overview of how to develop a service that publishes Open Data on multiple devices (smartphones, tablets...)
The aim will be to show how using REST API’s we can extend the reach of a portal and its adoption in an organisation.
Entando is an OS Java based portal platform that allows developers to easily make vertical applications or develop & deploy enterprise portals including rich CMS capabilities. Our commitment to remain open source & our passion for opening the world of web to those with visual impairments has made us successful in government sectors & we will profile some success stories of our use of REST API’s in large government deployments in Italy including the Civil protection & the Ministry of Justice.

title: Building a network analysis tool with Neo4j and HTML5
summary: We use a combination of Hadoop, Neo4j and browser based visualization to work with graphs, search for known interesting patterns in big graphs and do ad hoc querying against graphs. The use of a graph database allows for ad hoc querying and visualization, like in this example: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6hG8xqctIWA. In this talk, I will show how we built a Java based importer (that partly runs in Hadoop) for and a JavaScript based UI on top of the Neo4j graph database. The use of a graph database avoid the mismatch that exists between network data and relational databases. The REST API exposed by Neo4j allowed us to create a completely JavaScript based app, without any backend code, doing database calls directly from the browser.

author.speakingReferences:
Berlin Buzzwords 2011

title: Coding for Hadoop in Scala using Scoobi
summary:
In this university session you will get a hands on introduction to writing MapReduce programs for Hadoop using Scala and Scoobi, a high level MapReduce abstraction. You will build a functioning recommendation engine that can handle huge amounts of data. No prior Hadoop knowledge is required, Java and a bit of Scala will help.

The amount of data we process is increasing rapidly and more and more organizations are using Hadoop in order to scale their processing beyond the limits of a single machine. When starting with Hadoop, you will quickly find out that writing Hadoop MapReduce jobs in Java is time-consuming, verbose, invasive, and involves lots of boilerplate code. Also, using low level MapReduce is not always a natural fit to problem domains. Scala to the rescue! The Scoobi library allows you to interact with Hadoop by using Scala's list manipulation constructs.

Session outline:
- Introduction to Hadoop and MapReduce
- A look at a Java product recommender
- Hacking a better one: Scala and Scoobi

author.speakingReferences: GOTO Amsterdam 2012, Xebicon 2012, The Dutch NoSQL Meetup The Dutch Hadoop Meetup, The Dutch Scala Enthusiasts, JFall 2011, JFall 2009
author.speakerBio:
Age is a open source contributor, software engineer and CTO of Software Development at Xebia. He is responsible for the technology choices involved in projects; making sure the right technologies stick and the shallow hypes don't become de facto. He is constantly on the lookout for new tech to evolve the preferred stack to optimize productivity and software quality. In his work he touches the full stack, from big data backends to web and mobile apps. He is fluent in Java, Scala, JavaScript and Objective-C.

Age is founder of the Dutch Scala Enthusiasts. He co-organizes the Dutch NoSQL NL meetup and is a speaker on several tech subjects.

title: Monoglot Rich Web Programming with Errai
summary:
Who says polyglot is the best approach to modern web development? Java is a mature, typesafe, well understood language with plenty of life left in it. In fact, we think Java is awesome. 

Errai is a radical take on the traditional web application architecture, taking a step back from conventional wisdom and thinking about the browser as more than a view layer, but as a peer within a distributed network application. Once the conventional wisdom is destroyed, a whole new world of application development opens up.

This session will revolve around a live coding session, as Mike Brock starts building an Errai application from scratch, and evolving its functionality right before the audiences eyes. 

The talk will also revolve around technologies such as CDI (Contexts and Dependency Injection), JPA, and HTML5.

title: From Runnable and synchronized() to parallel() and atomically()
summary:
For about 15 years the Java multithreaded programming model has followed the evolution of CPUs and the growing needs of applications. 
Multithreaded programming poses two challenges for the developer: parallelize the processes, and ensure consistency of the data, 
while fully leveraging the computing power of modern multicore processors. 

This lecture begins by describing precisely these challenges and their issues. It then describes the technical solutions available today, 
whether in the JDK API or in the frameworks of the Java ecosystem. From the threads of Java 1.0, to the Fork / Join of Java 7, and the anticipated 
parallel () of Java 8, from synchronized and volatile to STM and actors, everything will be explained. Some algorithm upcoming issues will also be 
shown to illustrate the talk.

author.speakingReferences: José made lots of conferences for many different audiences : students, researchers (mathematics, computer science, humanities), engineers, general public, Java user groups.
author.speakerBio:
José is an assistant professor at the Institut Galilée (Université Paris 13) and a PhD in applied mathematics from the ENS Cachan. He has discovered the Java language in 1995, and has been teaching at the university since 2000. For about 10 years, José has been working with several research teams in archeology and ancient near east history. He has been the co-director
of the MAVI project, held by the Collège de France (http://www.museum-achemenet.college-de-france.fr/), and published Open melodie (http://www.openmelodie.org /), an open source project on the Java platform, that acts as a back office for the MAVI.

José also publishes "Java le soir", a technical blog in french (http://blog.paumard.org/), with about 700 pages of courses about Java / JEE in open access. José also contributes regularly to numerous technical projects in a variety of areas.

He is also a member of the french Paris Java User Group, and one of the organizer of Devoxx France.
author.name: José Paumard

title: Fork / Join, lambda & parallel() : parallel computing made (too ?) easy
summary:
The emergence of these new language features and its API began in Java 7 with the Fork / Join framework. It
will continue in Java 8, at which point we will be able to to fully utilize the resources of our multicore processors, with a minimum of effort.

What are those new patterns ? What performance gains can we expect ? What are the new bugs that we'll surely meet ? One hour to respond specifically to these three questions, demystifying things, and most importantly, introducing new problems and solutions. An hour to understand how our habits of concurrent programming will have to evolve, and what concurrent programming will look like tomorrow.

title: NoSQLUnit. Testing your NoSQL databases.
summary:
Unit tests should follow the FIRST rules (Fast, Isolated, Repeatable, Self-Validated and Timely). When persistence layer is under test, fast and isolated rules are the most violated. For relational database management systems, embedded databases and DbUnit framework exist to help us to not break them, but there is no like DBUnit framework for heterogeneous NoSQL systems.

NoSQLUnit aids us to not break these rules by providing a JUnit extension which helps us to manage lifecycle of NoSQL systems and also it takes care of maintaining databases into known state. NoSQLUnit can be used during unit tests, but also in high level tests like integration or acceptance tests.

title: OpenJDK Hack Session (Bugathon for the Adopt OpenJDK Program)
summary:
As of Java 7, the OpenJDK is the Reference Implementation (RI) for Java. In essence, the OpenJDK is the Java we use every day! With legal and technical barriers become smaller every day, it is now more possible than ever to get involved in the language and VM that we all love.

Come and join the Diabolical Developer and friends in a hands on workshop where you get to fix bugs in Java itself!  In this bugathon we'll pick an area of the OpenJDK that could do with some Duke love (such as applying project coin features to the libraries themselves).

You'll learn how Java is build, how the OpenJDK is managed as a project and most importantly how you can directly fix bugs and even potentially add new features to Java.

Martijn Verburg (aka 'the Diabolical Developer'), CTO of jClarity, herds Cats in the Java/open source communities and is constantly humbled by the creative power to be found there!

Currently resides in London where he co-leads the London JUG (a JCP EC member), runs the Adopt a JSR and Adopt OpenJDK programmes and drinks good beer at his local pub. You can find him on-line facilitating development of FOSS projects (PCGen and Ikasan), moderating at the Javaranch or discussing (ranting about?) subjects on the Programmers Stack Exchange.

He's become a regular (diabolical) speaker at conferences on Java, FOSS and software development and has recently wrapped up his first Manning title - "The Well-Grounded Java Developer" with his co-author Ben Evans.

Martijn was recognised as an official Java Champion in 2012 for services to the Java community.

title: Java and the Machine
summary:
In Terminator 3 - Rise of the Machines, bare metal comes back to haunt humanity, ruthlessly crushing all resistance.
This talk is going to cover how the same thing is going to happen to Java!

Java's Write Once Run Anywhere (WORA) premise means that Java and the JVM struggle to utilise specialist hardware and OS features that could make a massive difference in the performance of your application. This problem has recently gotten much, much worse. Due to the rise of multi-core processors, massive increases in main memory and enhancements to other major hardware components (e.g. SSD) means that the JVM is now distant from utilising that hardware, causing some major performance and scalability issues!

Martijn Verburg and Kirk Pepperdine will take you through the complexities of where Java meets the machine and loses. They'll give up some of their hard won insights on how to work around these issues so that you can plan to avoid termination, unlike some of the poor souls that ran into the T-800...

title: Modern Software Development Anti-Patterns
summary:
The Diabolical Developer and Ben Evans (the voice of reason!) return with a full length presentation of modern software development anti-patterns. This session provides a wealth of tips and tricks to free you from the chains of so call ‘modern software development best practices’.

We’re not delivering software any more successfully than our forebears! So what’s really going on? Well things like Agile and Software craftsmanship certainly take you down some dangerous paths, and don’t even get us started on Java 7! You’ll learn about topics such as how to unleash the awesome power of:

* Mortgage Driven Development
* Turtles All The Way Down
* Conference Driven Delivery
* Unleash the awesome power of the FactoryFactoryManagerBuilder

title: The Fragment Transition
summary:
Android is evolving, but developers aren't keeping pace.

Fragments, which let you break your UI into smaller functional pieces, were released over a year ago. Fragments enable scaling of your app to tablets and the next generation of devices. There's a huge opportunity to lead the market, yet few businesses and developers are leading the charge.

Corey will show you techniques for starting a fresh project, renovating an existing Android code base, optimizing for tablets, and balancing use of new APIs, while remaining backward compatible. She has been using fragments as long as they have been around in the XfinityTV app as well as her personal projects. She’d never start a new project with out them!

She helps businesses determine their mobile needs and then builds them the appropriate solutions. She created the Philadelphia Android Alliance, a rebel army whose mission is to conquer Apple’s market share, and co-founded a start-up that builds apps for the greater good. She leads local workshops through the Android Alliance, SkillShare, and GirlDevelopIt and is passionate about spreading the love for Android and fragments. Corey is passionate about encouraging broader participation in computing sciences, local food, the outdoors, photography, and living in downtown Philly. In a past life, she helped build the XfinityTV Android & iOS applications at Comcast Interactive Media and worked on various security projects at Cisco Systems. You can find her at coreylatislaw.com.

title: Drinking from the API Firehose
summary:
You wouldn't cram all the features of your website into a mobile app, so why are doing it with your data?

Web APIs were created to solve a specific problem set and little of these design constraints overlap with mobile platform limitations. Requiring mobile clients adapt to your API instead of serving exactly what they need leads to slower performance, increased data usage, and reduced battery life. Everything you want to avoid!

We will discuss patterns and anti-patterns for adapting web APIs and weigh the benefits of reuse against the need for mobile-tailored APIs.
