title: BDD with Spring Framework in Scala with Specs2 Spring
summary:
Jan's Specs2 Spring talk will show how to take advantage of type-safe, yet elegant testing framework in their "traditional" [Spring-based] Java EE applications. The talk start by exploring unit and acceptance specifications implemented in Specs2 in Scala, and follow up with applying these specifications to Spring JEE applications (implemented in Java or Scala). This will allow those who want to try out Scala, but are afraid to use it in the main code to explore it in the testing code. The attendees will find out about elegant testing approaches and gain further appreciation of the functional languages.

This is a fast-paced talk, with no bullet points, but plenty of images and enthusiasm to get the audience fired up.

author.speakerBio:
Jan is a Java enterprise architect, consultant and developer with very strong technical skills, author of Pro Spring 2.5, Pro Spring and other books, blogs and articles. He regularly speaks at conferences and developer events in the UK and abroad and he is the editor of the Open Source Journal. Jan regularly works on open source projects; he is the author of Specs2 Spring, Scalad, Spock Spring Integration and Spring Workflow Extension.

Jan’s technical interests and expertise include lightweight JVM-based applications in Scala and Java with the help of the Spring Portfolio, Akka and Spray.

title: Aspect-oriented CSS for maintainable front-end code
summary:
The promise of web development using web standards was lower maintenance costs, better accessibility and all-round developer happiness. But as a community, we are still struggling with delivering front-end systems that are as responsive to change, easily maintained by multiple authors and as beautifully crafted as our back-end systems. How come developers spend so much time on refactoring, beautification, design patterns, modularity and testing, while HTML and CSS still seems such a hit-or-miss affair?

This talk will review some of the problems encountered by designers and developers alike on non-trivial projects, and look at some technical and methodology difficulties that cause them. We'll look at some new-ish tools, new ideas and finally a new concept of authoring web pages with HTML and CSS that could solve some of these problems, by applying some familiar concepts from the world of programming to stylesheets — without losing touch with creativity.

summary:
We release our dependency information as pom.xml files on a maven repository. But how well do we understand the effect of these pom.xml files on our users? What problems do we create in ours and their dependency resolution?

In this session, you’ll be presented with several Maven puzzlers. Each Maven puzzler is a small POM configuration with a multiple-choice question about the output. Some puzzlers are easy, others are hard. Whoever answers most puzzlers correctly, wins.

title: Leveraging Server-Side to Accelerate Java Development
summary: When changing the core of a large-scale application, or a broadly used library, it is often necessary to see the effects of the change in the context of the whole application or many library clients. It is often unfeasible to have all the dependant projects accessible on the developer's machine, and much less to have them all opened in the developer's IDE. Server-side can be leveraged to make the developer's productivity higher in such case. Queries like find usages can be easily run on the server. The usual server-side static code analysis can be greatly improved by leveraging NetBeans' declarative way to describe custom refactorings. Domain specific antipatterns can be defined using a Java-like DSL and server-side leveraged to find out which client code is violating them. In this talk, we will demonstrate both how to use such server-side support and how to setup the server side using the Hudson continuous integration server.

title: Liferay Faces
summary:
In April of 2012 Liferay announced the new Liferay Faces project which provides the following features:

- Liferay Faces Alloy (JSF component suite that utilizes Alloy UI)
- Liferay Faces Bridge (JSR 329 compliant JSF portlet bridge implementation)
- Liferay Faces Portal (JSF component suite for portal integration)
- Demo portlets for various component suites including Liferay Faces Alloy, ICEfaces, PrimeFaces, and RichFaces

This session will discuss how Liferay Faces can enable development of a wide variety of JSF 2.x portlets for Liferay Portal. Attendees will learn the benefits that the JSF framework brings to portlet development, as well as how JSR 329 provides JSF integration points with Portlet API features like Events IPC and Public Render Parameters. Demos include using Liferay Developer Studio to develop JSF portlets with Liferay Faces Alloy.

title: Vaadin & GWT - Rich Web Apps in Server-side and Client-side Java
summary:
Vaadin Framework provides a desktop-like programming model both on the server and browser for creating Rich Internet Applications (RIAs) in plain Java - without the need for HTML, XML, plug-ins or JavaScript.

Session explains the key concepts of the server-side and client-side RIA development with Java, Vaadin and GWT. To demonstrate the use of the framework, an example application is developed during the session step-by-step. The presentation is concluded with pointers on how to start developing your own applications with Apache-licensed Vaadin-framework.

You'll learn:
* How to create a desktop like web application in Java
* Difference between page oriented, client-side RIA and server-side RIA architectures
* The relationship between Vaadin and GWT

More information and materials about the presentation:
http://vaadin.com/web/joonas/wiki/-/wiki/Main/Server-side%20RIA

title: Vaadin 7
summary:
Vaadin Framework version 7 is the first new major version of the popular rich web framework in over three years of iterative evolution. It includes Google Web Toolkit (GWT) to provide best of the Java based UI development - both of the server and client-side. The presentation describes the new features and design decisions and explains the implications of including GWT.

The first goal for Vaadin 7 is to give more freedom to use underlying technologies with ease. We'll show through examples on how to utilize new API:s. The second goal is to embrace the extensibility of the framework with new APIs for adding features. Final goal of the release is to clean up the API. We show what have been changed, how the changes may break your application and give advice on how to upgrade to Vaadin 7.

title: Do you suffer from CPU Envy?
summary:
Bigger, Stronger, Faster - everyone has CPU envy.  But what about that i7 sitting in your big bad brand new macbook air?  It might just be telling you something. No, not that you spent your midlife crisis budget on a laptop instead of a harley davidson - but more about how your favorite Java application is misusing and abusing it.

Java applications live in a world far from the CPU itself, but they eventually execute on it no matter what.  In this session we’ll explore ways that you can both improve your code and make better use of the CPU you already have. If you want to execute faster - don't go bigger or stronger, go smarter.

title: The Bluffers guide to Elitist Jargon
summary:
Have you always secretly wondered what the heck 'monads' are? How about 'Tail-call recursion?' or 'monomorphic dispatch'? If this sort of terminology has ever left you with self-doubts or seething with anger because someone is confusing you with elitist terminology, then this is the talk for you!

Dr Richard Warburton, the Diabolical Developer and James Gough will take a humorous look at the wide range of incomprehensible terminology in our industry today. They'll cover the concepts behind the jargon with simple examples and some practical tips on how to blend the terminology into your day to day technical conversations without scaring everyone off!

At the end of the talk you'll be ready to battle it out on tough mailing lists (Scala!) and have a new appreciation for some of the academic principles behind our craft.

Oh and as for monads? Well they're just like burritos, except they're not...

title: Project Lombok: Return of the Boilerplate Busters
summary:
If there's too much code,
and it don't look good
Who you gonna call?
Boilerplate busters!

In this presentation, the developers of lombok, Reinier Zwitserloot and Roel Spilker, will show the audience all new lombok features. These features take boilerplate busting to the next level, including call-site extension methods, complete property support including change listeners and bound properties.

For those of you that don't know lombok, we'll cover the basics as well: instead of writing out common boilerplate such as getters, setters, toString, equals, and hashCode implementations, you can just use a lombok annotation. Lombok hooks into your compiler and IDE so that their interpretation of your source includes these methods, while you never actually see any of them in your editor. While most IDEs offer a feature to generate the boilerplate, this is little help when reading the resulting code, and such code is much harder to maintain.

title: Cross-build injection attacks: how safe is your Java build?
summary: Everyone tests the security of their application, but how safe is the build process that creates the application itself? Modern Java build tools automate the process of retrieving dependencies from public repositories like Maven Central. While convenient, this unfortunately also opens the door for malicious code-injection attacks during the build process. These so-called cross-build injection (XBI) attacks are not very well known, but their impact can be devastating. Attacks can be countered both by improving organizational processes and by using cryptographic primitives to ensure dependencies are safe. This session shows what you can do to secure your builds, by presenting XBI attack vectors along with the appropriate countermeasures.

title: OpenShift State of the Union
summary:

Join us for an action-packed hour of power where we'll show you how to deploy an application written in the language of your choice - Java, Ruby, PHP, Perl or Python, with the framework of your choice - EE6, CDI, Seam, Spring or Rails to the OpenShift PaaS in just minutes. All without having to rewrite your app to get it to work as the cloud provider thinks it should work.
We will focus on examples that highlight what OpenShift has to offer, how to get started, & provide example projects that you can access now. Bring your laptop & follow along as we help you get started with Aerogears, Drools Planner, BRMS, Switchyard & much more. Real world projects put on display for you with code you can access live during this session.
If you want to learn how the OpenShift PaaS & investing an hour of your time can change everything you thought you knew about developing apps in the cloud, this session is for you!

title: Actor model for Spring developers
summary:
I think actor based concurrency model is a paradigm shift. 

What is paradigm shift?
A change in the basic assumptions, or paradigms, within the ruling theory of science.

The paradigm shift makes simple ideas hard to grok. Even though Actor model is a simple and revolutionary idea it becomes hard for programmers to see practical benefits and usage. One possible solution to this problem is to evaluate the new paradigm in terms of old paradigm. In this presentation we will take a working Spring based web application and gradually implement it using actors. We will be skeptical and suspicious of new ideas but at the same time we will be open minded. We will learn about actor based concurrency model using the knowledge of spring.

I believe I am almost unique among programmers having strong skills with both databases and objects together. I write software for a living. But since I enjoy creating things and solving problems, I also write software on my pastime. I am currently working on scala-webmachine (restful resource framework). In past I worked on other open source projects like Panopticode, scala-inline and autotest4j. When I am not working on projects I play with functional programming and DSL.

title: Scala Koans: New way to learn language
summary:
Have you looked into Scala? Scala is a new object-functional JVM language. And it happens to be my favorite programming language. If you are interested in Scala, how you are planning to learn Scala?
You probably are going to pick up a book or two and follow through some examples. And hopefully some point down the line you will learn the language, its syntax and if you get excited enough maybe build large applications using it. But what if I tell you that there is a better path to enlightenment in order to learn Scala?
Scala Koans, a set of test cases that will teach you Scala language. The Scala koans are very much influenced by Ruby Koans (http://www.rubykoans.com/) and will help the audience learn the language, syntax and the structure of the language through test cases. It will also teach the functional programming and object oriented features of the language. Since learning is guided by failing tests it allows developers to think and play with the language while they are learning.

title: Why flight? Build applications by combining both OO and FP
summary:
We don't have to choose between functional programming or object oriented programming, we can use both. Its called multi-paradigm programming. The obvious question is why we need more than one style of programming. 
The goal of multi-paradigm computing is to provide a number of problem-solving styles so that a programmer can select the solution technique that best matches the characteristics of the problem to be solved. This provides a framework where you can work in a variety of styles and mix the constructs from different styles. Functional programming makes it easy to build interesting things from simple parts (functions), and object-oriented programming makes it easy to adopt and extend complex systems using inheritance, classes, and so on.
This presentation will use Scala programming language and demonstrate the power you get when you combine them together.

In this presentation we are going to see how to use Vagrant and Puppet to build a production-like environment and how to run automated deployment tests into continuous integration tool before running acceptance tests.

Today, Big Data is a reality everyone has to deal with. Whatever area any application involved needs to crunch large data sets in accurate and effectively. In Java world, there are various libraries dedicated for data analytics and they provide a wide range of analytics capabilities specific to the kind of what you would like to achieve.

On the other hand, R is a statistical programming language has been used for years by data scientists and analysis experts. The language itself and the packages completing the environment allow developers constructing amazing software applications on any platform via a host language, in our case it is Java!

This talk will briefly introduce the power of R language to the audience and then describe the methods developers can benefit in order to handle large data sets for their own applications via bridging Java and R aura.

title: Monitoring of High-Performance Event-Driven Systems
summary: This session presents lessons of Akka usage in context of the monitoring product of Akka. Akka is using latest jsr-166 fork-join pool and can process up to 50 million messages per second in a single JVM. Performing detailed tracing in production of Akka actor based systems involves several challenges. Collection of data must be done with minimal impact of the application. Aggregated statistics is produced from huge amount of data and presented in a meaningful user interface. The monitoring solution itself is based on Akka, and that has been a key enabler to a performant and stable system. Also, using Scala, AspectJ, MongoDB and Play 2.0 framework has been important for the Typesafe Console.

title: Up up and Out: Scaling software with Akka
summary:
We believe that one should never have to choose between productivity and scalability, which has been the case with traditional approaches to concurrency and distribution. The cause of that has been the wrong tools and the wrong layer of abstraction and Akka is here to change that. 

Akka is an, open source, unified runtime and programming model for scaling both UP (utilizing multi-core processors) and OUT (utilizing the grid/cloud). With Akka this will be taken to a whole new level with its “Distributed by Design”. Akka provides location transparency by abstracting away both these tangents of scalability by turning them into an operations and configuration task. This gives the Akka runtime freedom to do adaptive automatic load-balancing, cluster rebalancing, replication and partitioning. 

In this talk you will learn what Akka is and how it can be used to solve hard scalability problems. Akka is available at http://akka.io (under Apache 2 license).

title: Mutation Testing
summary:
Who guards the guardians? Your unit tests guard your source code, but who's testing your unit tests? Well, mutation testing can do that.

Mutation testing changes your source code, and then checks whether your unit tests can detect it. If they do, everything is fine, but if they don't, something may be wrong. Maybe there's a path through your code you haven't thought about, and you should to write an extra unit test? Maybe there's a bug, and you have to change your source code. And sometimes you have too much source code, and you can delete a few lines.

This talk first explains the basic idea of mutation testing and its relation to other software quality techniques. Then it'll discuss the techniques used by mutation testing tools and give an overview over the tools currently available, with a closer look at PIT, a mutation testing tool for Java. Finally, I'll present my personal experiences and practices using an example, with some recommendations to get started.

title: Client/Server Apps with HTML5 and Java
summary: The web application landscape is rapidly shifting back to a Client/Server architecture.  This time around the Client is JavaScript, HTML, and CSS in the browser. So, what happens to the web apps & services that were built prior to mobile apps? How easy or hard is to start building a mobile app or transform existing web apps to work in mobile platforms?

title: Functional Design Patterns with Scala
summary: Design patterns in functional programming are computation models. When you use such a pattern in modeling your abstractions, you not only get an expressive domain model, you also get the ability to verify its correctness by defining properties that hold good in the computation. In this talk, I will present a few of such abstractions - Monoid, Semi-Group, Functor, Applicative etc. and how they help build domain models in real world applications. One of the great virtues that these patterns embody is that they stay behind your application domain model and yet offer the glue that help you compose larger abstractions out of smaller ones. So they help make your model expressive by removing boilerplate glue code out of your core application.

title: Domain Models - Thinking Differently in Scala and Clojure
summary: When you model a domain you map the artifacts from the problem domain to the solution domain. The problem domain artifacts are the same irrespective of your solution domain. But the mapping process depends on your medium of modeling, the target platform, the programming language and the paradigms that it offers. Accordingly you need to orient your thought process so as to adapt to the language idioms that you have chosen for implementation. Recently I did a fun exercise in modeling the same problem domain on to 2 target languages - Scala, that offers a mix of OO and functional features and Clojure, that's much more functional and makes you think more in terms of functions and combinators. The idea is to share the thought process of this domain modeling exercise and demonstrate how even similar architectural patterns of the solution can map to entirely different paradigms in the  implementation model.

title: Disruptive Media
summary:
New APIs and standards can democratise content creation and communication: for telephony, gaming, video production, music making, news gathering and many other applications. In this session, we help you understand the new APIs and show off some stunning real-world implementations.

* WebRTC implements open standards for realtime, plugin-free video, audio and data communication
* getUserMedia() gives access to user-generated video and audio
* CSS, WebGL and the canvas element make complex visual manipulation and animation effective and efficient
* The Media Source API enables native adaptive streaming, and the new Media encryption APIs enable the video and audio elements to play encrypted media
* The HTML track element enables deep linking, deep search and has huge potential to improve media accessibility
* The Gamepad, USB, Geolocation, Orientation and other APIs provide open standards for device access
* The Web Audio API enables sophisticated audio processing in the browser

title: Pushing Infinispan Data Grid events over Tomcat Websockets
summary: Websockets are coming with HTML 5 and building rich real time event driven web applications will be the future. Tomcat has support for Websockets since the 7.0.27 release so now is an ideal time to learn this new technology. To provide the ultimate user-experience in these next generation applications data access over Websockets will need to be highly scalable, highly available and incur the lowest latency cost achievable. Infinispan's open source data-grid provides potentially linear scalability for data access and a comprehensive events framework that can be leveraged in this type of architecture. In the first part of this session we will explore this combination of open source technologies, covering the fundamental principals of Data Grids and Websockets.  Finally we finish up by combining their functionality to provide massive scale-out and low latency for a real-time web application, all for free!

Arquillian is a revolutionary testing platform for Java and the JVM that enables developers to easily create and execute integration and functional tests for Java middleware, from Java EE and beyond.

One of Arquillian's strong points is its extensibility. Arquillian was built with the ability to change its default behavior via its powerful extension model, as well as to grow outside of its original programming to take on the challenges of tomorrow.

The speakers will guide you trough the Arquillian Extensions by demonstrating how specific extensions solve common, problematic testing scenarios faced by enterprise developers. You will get a overview of what is available and possible today, as well as what is brewing in the community.

title: Continuous Delivery with Citrus
summary: The idea of continuous delivery requires automated software testing in the first place. When it comes to integration testing with several interfaces and protocols (SOAP WebServices, JMS, Http, FTP, TCP/IP) the test automation can be very difficult. Interface partners must be simulated and the test data flow must be designed carefully. In addition to that tests must be reproducible as we want prove the interface conformity on our continuous software builds. The Citrus integration test framework gives us fully automated integration tests with huge protocol support and powerful validation capabilities (e.g. XML, JSON, SOAP, REST). The presentation gives an introduction to Citrus and handles complex testing scenarios with multiple interfaces at the same time. Finally we incorporate the Citrus tests into the continuous build and delivery process so tests get executed with each code change.

title: Happy Testing!
summary:
Happiness and testing - two words that mutually exclude each other in a developer's life. Tests are boring, time consuming, exhausting and frustrating for many reasons. In my presentation I discuss the 5-10 top test mistakes and bad habits from coding and procedural perspective. At the end you will notice that most part of the test frustration comes from our own misbehavior and that things can be improved. The points discussed are:
1) Loosing brain: Avoid poor test code quality.
2) Feedback gaps: Long running software builds are bad.
3) Manual testing: Find test automation everywhere!
4) Lost in documentation: Minimize academic papers on tests in prior to coding them.
5) John Doe at the FooBar: Think of good test data not using the same values all the time.

I tried to outline my thoughts in more detail in an addendum attached.

wikiTitle: Happy Testing!

title: Pick the low-hanging concurrency fruit
summary: Concurrency is not hard. It can actually feel natural and easy. Surprisingly little effort is required to achieve a great level of concurrency in your everyday code. Come and pick the fruit that hangs low, right above your head. Stretch out your hand and learn to use parallel collections, asynchronous functions, fork/join and dataflow variables. You can write code that runs fast on modern multi-core chips without dramatic impact on your applications' architecture. It will be deterministic and reliable. Come and get ready for the multi-core future.

title: MPS - DSLs with pleasure
summary:
Let's write better code, faster. Use your customer lingo to encode your programs. Employ Domain Specific Languages and get more bang for your programming buck.
In this talk we'll look at the advantages and pitfalls of working with DSLs inside Java IDEs. We'll use JetBrains' MPS as a vehicle to get us safely across the waters of DSLs. JetBrains MPS is an open-source language workbench that integrates with Eclipse and IntelliJ IDEA. It will support you when designing your DSLs, it will assist you when using them and also help you deal with the common DSL drawbacks. Your languages can be freely combined without ambiguity, refactoring of DSLs becomes a breeze and you get full IDE support as a bonus. If the promise of headache-free programming excites you, this session is for you.

title: Creating Neo4j Graph Databases with Hadoop
summary:
When exploring very large raw datasets containing massive interconnected networks, it is sometimes helpful to extract your data, or a subset thereof, into a graph database like Neo4j. This allows you to easily explore and visualize networked data to discover meaningful patterns.

When your graph has 100M+ nodes and 1000M+ edges, using the regular Neo4j import tools will make the import very time-intensive (as in many hours to days).

In this talk, I’ll show you how we used Hadoop to scale the creation of very large Neo4j databases by distributing the load across a cluster and how we solved problems like creating sequential row ids and position-dependent records using a distributed framework like Hadoop.

author.speakingReferences: Kris has spoken at in-house knowledge sharing events and several local meetups.
author.speakerBio:
Kris is a developer with a passion for combining technologies to create new possibilities for the people around him. Coming from a Java and GIS background and being a fan of open source software, Kris started working with distributed systems and graph databases in the last couple of years.
He’s currently working on visualizing Big Data with the help of Hadoop and Neo4j

title: Mobile HTML5 Apps in minutes not days powered by Grails
summary:
Developing applications for mobile devices using web technologies is now well within reach. When the capabilities of HTML5 are combined with CSS3 and JavaScript, web application developers have an opportunity to develop compelling mobile applications using familiar tools.

Mobile web apps are now starting to provide many of the features that were once only available to native-language-based apps.

This presentation teaches developers already familiar with web application development, how to code and structure a web app for use on the mobile platform. After explaining the skeleton of a mobile web app, we will introduce JQueryMobile and some HTML5 features as Geolocation & Local Storage. To glue all these technologies together we will introduce Grails, a powerful Web Framework, and show how it is well fit for building Mobile Web Apps. 

As demo, we will build a complete Mobile Web App and we will even create Native packages for it using the Cordova Build Platform.

title: Everything you Always Wanted to Know About Versions* (*but were afraid to ask)
summary:
Seriously, a talk about versions?

Yes! Versions aren't sexy, but they're very important in modern software development: they are the primary way to evolve software and communicate the features, compatibility and stability of our artifacts.

OSGi is one of very few environments where versions are pervasively and consistently applied, and is therefore an ideal environment for growing and maintaining large systems. And yet, even many OSGi developers still don't use versions properly. Why??

Because proper versioning is hard, and existing tools force us to manually maintain them. The number of versions quickly exceeds the capacity of any human brain. But it needn't be this way: the problem is eminently manageable with tools. Developers should never have to remember to manually bump a version or think about a range.

I will describe the correct use of versions in OSGi (and elsewhere) and demo tools that automate version management, so that large software projects can be evolved in a truly modular way.

title: How we took our server-side application to the Cloud and liked what we got
summary: Taking traditional Java server-side applications to the multi-tenant Cloud introduces lots of challenges. In this session, we will share our experience of creating a SaaS offering, which is currently being used successfully by the Java community. We will start by reviewing the challenges we faced during the SaaS conversion. Next, we will share our experience with the EC2 platform. We will discuss the importance of automation and how we use tools like Chef and Puppet for SaaS provisioning. Finally, we will describe how creating a SaaS version of our product shifted our way of thinking about software release. We will recommend what’s required to successfully release both SaaS and downloadable versions of your product.

title: Plugging the users in - extend your application with pluggable Groovy DSL
summary: It is often beneficial to allow users extend your software with their own logic and with dynamic languages on the JVM it is also easy to do. In this session, we will share our experience in creating a public, Groovy-authored user plugin interface. We will explain what domain specific languages (DSLs) are, what their relevance to user plugins is, and how they can be implemented both in Groovy or Java. We will talk about another very important aspect of plugability: good public API design. Then we will cover security concerns and how they should be tackled. We will also discuss classpath isolation issues you may run into and will compare different solutions to this problem.

summary:
JavaFX is a great software platform for creating and delivering rich Internet applications that can run across a wide variety of connected devices. 
The NetBeans rich client platform provides a software platform for building higly modular yet fully integrated enterprise applications.
In typical complex enterpise situations, where isolated point solutions do not suffice, users are presented a functional but somewhat boring application.

title: ElasticSearch to the rescue of your legacy search
summary:
Most of legacy applications rely on the database for two distinct use cases: storage and data access. The problem is that these use cases are not compatible in term of constraint and performance. With data and business cases increase the response time becomes poorer.

 Then ElasticSearch, comes to the rescue. It is a distributed search engine based on Apache Lucene, a mature industry-wide searching solution. ElasticSearch gives a second birth to your search engine with:

 1) Simple data model
 2) Dynamic mapping
 3) Blazing fast search time
 4) High availability and failure resilience

title: Service Versioning in SOA and Cloud
summary:
Keeping versioning under control is essential in the success of a SOA. However, there are no industry standards for service versioning, thus leaving the responsibility of implementing a service versioning system up to the architects and developers within the IT enterprise. 

We often see design-type versioning, resulting in Big Bang governance strategies. A runtime versioning strategy may be, in fact, be preferable.

Every change must be built, and every change must be governed. A "cheap" build may lead to a large governance impact. But conversely, a small governance cost may lead to a large build impact. Both build and governance costs need to be taken into account and carefully balanced when choosing and implementing a service versioning strategy.

title: Common Mobile Architecture
summary:
As mobile development finds its way into the enterprise world, the applications become increasingly more complex. 

Quick and dirty solutions lead to unmaintainable, and even erroneous code. By applying an architecture using design patterns and proven best practices we avoid these problems.

And thus the need for a good architecture becomes ever so important. In search of a good methodology we discovered that, not surprisingly, the needs in various environments are the same, and can be tackled in the same way. Whether it's Android, HTML 5/CSS 3/JavaScript, iOS and maybe even other mobile platforms, the main building blocks of this architecture might always come back. The gains of a common architecture is that the principals behind it only need to be explained once, and can be applied on different platforms.

The main topics for this talk are:

- Architecture: an overview
- Back-end integration
- Dealing with data
- Object dependencies
- GUI architecture

summary:
Configuration Management systems like CFEngine, Puppet and Chef, are often adopted as part of devops toolchains. It promises us infrastructure as code a concept that leads to 'Agile' infrastructure: In this session I'd like to give:
 - a brief explanation of the concept and why it's useful
- an overview about the similarities this has with regular code
- concepts such as TDD, BDD how well can they be translated

title: Declarative programming with Drools
summary: When we think about software development we almost automatically think in terms of imperative programming. Despite it is not a new idea, only in recent years functional programming is gaining more traction, mostly because it makes easier the development of heavily parallel programs. Nevertheless there's a third paradigm that, especially for some specific categories of problems, represents the most natural, flexible and maintainable solution: declarative programming. After a brief introduction to declarative programming and rule engines, showing how they work and in which circumstances they should be used, the talk will illustrate how these concepts have been implemented in Drools and which tools the Drools ecosystems provides making it a complete and effective Business Logic Integration Platform.

title: “The President is....” a Google App Engine Hands-On Lab
summary:
Imagine you are tasked with putting together a web application offering information about an ongoing presidential election up to the moment the (new) president is finally announced. Obviously this application needs to scale to support many citizens for a given country.

We'll build this application together, starting from scratch and using Google AppEngine. This will offer both PaaS newbies as well more advanced developers a very large tour of the requirements and capabilities of Google's flagship cloud service. Specific features covered include JSP/Servlet, user API and authentication, DataStore writes and queries, memcache optimisation, Cron jobs, sharded counter, blobstore uploads, sending/receiving email, and of course deployment, management and monitoring of the application running in Google's cloud.

This lab was already conducted at Devoxx Paris and another conference. Several enhancements (fixes, additional features, easy I18N, ...) are currently being worked on.

title: Groovy myths and legends
summary:
The Groovy language is one of the most popular alternative languages for the JVM. However, it's also one of the oldest JVM languages and despite the recent Groovy 2 release, there are a lot of myths and legends around it.

In this session, we will discuss common assumptions about Groovy and how they compare with reality. We believe that just like Java 7 doesn't deserve to be compared with Java 1.1, Groovy 2 doesn't deserve being compared with 1.0.

We will address topics like scripting, performance, type safety, productivity, adoption and, of course, your questions.

At the end of this talk, you should be aware that legendary skills are at your fingertips!

title: Designing and Testing Actor Systems
summary:
The actor model has proven its benefits in writing highly scalable, fault-tolerant and reliable concurrent systems in Erlang/OTP. Akka (http://akka.io) is an advanced implementation of this model on the JVM, offering Java and Scala APIs. With version 2.0 we introduced mandatory parental supervision, an addition over other actor implementations which aims at fostering fault-tolerant designs from the beginning.
The first part of this talk will introduce actor hierarchies and show design patterns which can be applied when breaking down a task to model it onto an actor system. Most of these patterns are not specific to Akka but applicable to any implementation of the actor model.
The second part of this talk introduces the Akka TestKit, which supports a wide range of testing approaches from white-box to black-box, detailing strengths and weaknesses of the different levels at which tests can be conducted. It also covers the relation between the design patterns of part one and their associated testing strategies.

title: Architecting for Continuous Delivery
summary:
Your Continuous Integration system is well oiled and kicks in after every commit. Your code is compiled. Your tests are green. You feel ready to take your project to the next level and move to Continuous Delivery.

This transition can be rough and comes with new challenges. We'll look at 5 essential pillars of software architecture that will make it a success: Environment Detection, Auto-Configuration, Database Migrations, Feature Toggles and State Management. By the end of this session you'll have a solid understanding of what it takes to build applications that can be delivered reliably into production multiple times a day, with zero down-time.

title: Google Drive SDK
summary:
In addition to being a cloud storage solution for users to store their files and sync them on multiple devices, Google Drive also launched with the ability to integrate with third party web applications and let you deeply integrate with Google Drive.

There are numerous advantages in using user-managed cloud storage solution such as Google Drive in web applications. Web applications can integrate deeply with Google Drive, taking advantage of its free storage and leveraging the millions of files already hosted on user’s Drive.

First we’ll see how you can register, set up and distribute your Drive application. Then, we’ll have a deeper look into the authentication and authorization flows used in Drive which are based on OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect. We’ll conclude by looking at how Drive Files are created and read using Drive’s REST APIs and how you can use our client libraries to integrate easily.

title: Google Script (aka Apps Script)
summary:
Google Apps Script is a cloud-based scripting language for light-weight application development in the Google Apps platform. It is based on JavaScript, however instead of running on the client, it gets executed in the Google Cloud. Google Apps Script essentially provides easy ways to automate tasks across Google products and third party services.

This session will cover the basis of the language and offer numerous examples of use-cases for App Script to automate repetitive processes and workflows.
wikiPageName: Google Script (aka Apps Script)
wikiTitle: Google Script (aka Apps Script)
smallTitle: Google Script (aka Apps Script) by Nicolas Garnier

title: The Chrome Dev Tools can do THAT
summary:
Your browser is one of the most and best instrumented development platforms - you may just not realize it yet. Of course, you can inspect the source, walk the DOM, fiddle with the CSS, and even evaluate some Javascript expressions, but there is so much more! There are dozens of power tools at your disposal:

- Remote debugging capabilities (hint: debug your mobile apps on your desktop)
- Powerful JavaScript debugger and profiler
- CPU, memory, CSS layout and GPU profilers
- Built-in network monitoring tools: monitor at socket level
- SourceMaps, pretty print, revision control and autosave
- Data export and import: HAR, timeline, snapshots
- Custom extensions, customizable stylesheets, and so much more..

There is nothing more important than having great tools and visibility into where your performance bottlenecks are, as well as to help you debug those gnarly bugs. Come by and learn about all the great capabilities of Chrome Dev Tools!
wikiPageName: The Chrome Dev Tools can do THAT
wikiTitle: The Chrome Dev Tools can do THAT
smallTitle: The Chrome Dev Tools can do THAT by Ilya Grigorik

title: What's new in Groovy 2.0?
summary:
Groovy is a popular language for the JVM which brings more developer productivity and more performance after each release. After an overview of key features of Groovy 1.8, we'll dive through the new features of Groovy 2.0.

Lots of Groovy users are using the language as a Java scripting language. Not all need the dynamic capabilities, nor do they need all the library improvements provided by Groovy. For the latter, Groovy becomes more modular with smaller core modules that you can compose. For the former, Groovy 2.0 adds static type checking, allowing you to ensure the correctness of your code before it ships and quickly spot early errors at compile time. 

Also not everybody needs dynamic features at all times: With static compilation, Groovy 2.0 generates fast bytecode like Java and shields key parts of your code base from possible interferences of dynamic features. But when you need fast and performant dynamic logic, Groovy 2.0 also features the integration of the JDK 7 "invoke dynamic" support.

author.speakingReferences: Guillaume Laforge speaks at conferences and user groups around the world: JavaOne, Devoxx, SpringOne2GX, JavaZone, JFokus, and many more.
author.speakerBio: Guillaume Laforge is the project lead of Groovy, the highly popular and successful dynamic language for the JVM. He co-authored Manning's best seller "Groovy in Action" with Dierk König, and is working for SpringSource (a division of VMWare) where he's hacking full time on cool and Groovy stuff. You can meet Guillaume at conferences around the world where he evangelizes the Groovy dynamic language, Domain-Specific Languages in Groovy, the agile Grails web framework or the Gaelyk lightweight toolkit for Google App Engine.

title: Pamper your JavaScript code
summary:
Do you have confidence in the JavaScript code you deliver in production?

When you deploy your web application in production, you are reassured by your tests that ensure the quality of your Java code.

But what about your JavaScript code?

Current applications rely increasingly on JavaScript to provide rich and dynamic content. Thus, it becomes essential to take care of your JavaScript code as much as your Java code!
 
With the help of some well-chosen companions (Jasmine, JsTestDriver, Maven, Jenkins, Sonar ...), we will build the foundations of the continuous integration and improvement dedicated to the JavaScript code.

Come and see that it is possible to declare to your JavaScript code all the love you have for it!

Passionné également par les principes de l'intégration continue, il n'a de cesse d'améliorer et d'automatiser les processus au sein des équipes pour lesquelles il travaille.

title: Pebble Watch, a programmable watch
summary:
The Pebble Watch (http://getpebble.com/) is famously known for being the biggest crowd-funded tech project on KickStarter.

In a nutshell, it's a programmable digital e-paper watch that can interact with your iPhone or Android device.

You can develop new watch faces, program notifications for anything, interact with the real world to control your music or appliances, and much more.

In this session, we'll have a look at what the watch offers, how to create your own apps for it, how to let your watch talk to your smartphone, and see where our creativity leads us!

title: Migrating Real-World Million-Line Code Bases to Java 7: Lessons Learned
summary: In enterprise development, migrating to a new version of Java can be a complex endeavor. However, the swift adoption of Java 7 by the community enables a smooth transition, if you plan ahead and take one small step at a time. In this session, you’ll hear about Info Support’s experiences with successful migrations on several large enterprise projects, such as the Dutch Railways planning system, a complex, million-line code base. The presentation shows real project statistics on performance and productivity improvements because of Java 7 and addresses several topics for migration: tools, frameworks, and language changes. It also discusses approaches to incrementally upgrading in a multiteam environment and how to minimize risk and effort.

title: Automated Architectural Reviews with Semmle
summary: Keeping code at a high level of quality and in sync with the defined architecture is not a trivial matter when you are participating in a competitive market in which you would rather provide solutions today than tomorrow. Code checkers help, but most are too generic to be of real value and so end up being ignored. Customisable code checkers can provide real benefit at reasonable cost. By encoding company specific (or even project specific) rules, actual results become much more relevant. With the additional integration of UML diagrams and specifications into the code checker, it even becomes possible to manage the gap between the actual code and the architecture from day to day at reasonable cost.

title: Dynamic Server Applications with EclipseRT
summary:
EclipseRT is an Eclipse top-level project supporting a large community move to drive Equinox-based technology across a broad range of computing environments and problem domains. Today, there are many projects listed under EclipseRT umbrella. 

This tutorial will look at and use a great portion of them in order to build a nice EclipseRT stack suitable for developing cloud applications. A simple proof-of-concept example will be created as part of the hands-on exercises. At the end, an ad-hoc cloud will be created with all participants to demonstrate the cloud abilities of this stack.

Audience:
This tutorial targets developers and architects who want to develop a better understanding of what's required to build EclipseRT cloud applications. They should be familiar with OSGi bundles and services, as well as standard Java web applications.

Contents:
1. Introduction to EclipseRT (presentation)
2. Developing a sample application (exercise)
3. Creating an ad-hoc cloud (exercise)
4. Summary

In his primary role at AGETO he is thrilled to work on open source software, emerging platforms and technologies, and to help companies understand Eclipse and OSGi and execute on their business objectives in an open source context. He has been a member of the Eclipse Community since its beginning and he is a prolific contributor with many years of experience on numerous Eclipse projects; Gunnar leads the Technology PMC and is a member of the Eclipse Architecture Council. Apart from Eclipse he loves chatting about fishing, diving and his family and other things that matters over a good beer or a glass of dry, barrel aged red wine.

title: Developing Cloud Applications with Eclipse Gyrex
summary:
The Eclipse Gyrex project is a platform for building OSGi runtime applications in a cloud-like infrastructure. It separates operational aspects from development and it uses as much of existing Eclipse concepts and technologies as possible – plug-ins, features, HttpService, extension and extension points, Eclipse Preferences API, Eclipse Jobs API and a lot more.

This session will introduce attendees to the concepts and technologies available in Gyrex. It will explain the steps necessary for creating web- or data processing applications. A demo at the end will show the advantages of using a dynamic OSGi environment for Java applications running in the cloud.

title: Polyglot Persistence: EclipseLink JPA for NoSQL, Relational, and Beyond
summary: Java data access today isn’t just about reading and writing from relational databases. It’s also about being able to persist your objects in NoSQL databases and mapping your objects to XML and to JSON for on disk storage or for use in RESTful web services.  The persistence needs of applications are evolving from predominantly relational to a mixture of heterogeneous data sources.  In response to these needs EclipseLink, the Java Persistence API 2.0 and 2.1 reference implementation, is making support for NoSQL and other non-relational databases a first class citizen. In this session we’ll introduce EclipseLink JPA’s support for NoSQL and other non-relational databases and show through examples how easy it is to embrace polyglot persistence in your Java applications.

title: Build, Automate, Share - Vagrant and Puppet for lightweight, automated environments
summary:
The setup of environments is often a "work of art". But wait, with the rise of DevOps and Infrastructure as Code, quite some tools evolve which offer help to solve the tedious tasks involved in setting up development and test environments, maybe even on different operating systems. Two of these tools are Vagrant, a command line interface to setup/automate/share virtual environments and Puppet, a conifuration management software.

The session presents both of these tools, first giving a short overview and then diving head first into the topic by demonstrating how to build up a simple testing environment (application server, db, configuration of both) with them.

title: Building Modular Applications in Java
summary:
Modularity is key to keep code maintainable, and modular runtimes are getting even more relevant when moving to the cloud. OSGi is the only viable modular runtime available for Java. It has been around for over 10 years, but adoption in enterprise development has been limited because OSGi had a name of being overly complicated, hard to use, and hard to integrate with other Java technologies. This has been changing in the past few years however, and better tooling and framework support now make it easier to work with.
 
This university will be a great introduction to OSGi development. It explains how to create bundles and define package imports/exports including semantic versioning. It will discuss services; the most important concept for achieving modularity. It shows the important tools and frameworks for doing OSGi development such as ConfigurationAdmin, Felix Dependency Manager and explains design patterns such as the Whiteboard Pattern. All will be explained in a very practical way with live coding.

title: Modular Java EE in the Cloud: A Practical Guide to Modularity in the Cloud Age.
summary:
Java EE 6 is an awesome platform, but how do you design a system that can evolve for many years in production? And how do we run this stuff in the cloud? Designing a system that can evolve without creating a maintenance nightmare is not trivial. A service oriented, modular architecture will help a lot to replace parts of a system without breaking others. The only mature modularity approach for Java is OSGi - a framework that enables low-level modularity and services, but you still need APIs to create web applications, use transactions, access data sources etc. Without these APIs you will have a hard time building applications. Unfortunately OSGi and Java EE did not interoperate well in the past; But what if we want modularity in our architecture but also the ease-of-use of Java EE 6? In this university you will:

1. Understand the benefits of a modular code base
2. Learn how to mix OSGi and Java EE
3. Manage modular cloud deployments using Apache ACE

..and of course there will be lots of live coding!

Tons of lectures on Universities (student tracks) and in-company presentations and seminars.

title: Rethinking architecture using CQRS
summary:
With growing communities and on-line activity, applications need to cope with problems related to concurrency and scalability. Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) –the result of combining several proven best practices- emerged as an architectural pattern to address these problems.

In this talk, Allard will explain how CQRS based architectures address not only concurrency and scalability problems, but also how this pattern supports the developers’ everlasting battle against complexity. He will also introduce the Axon Framework, a (Java) framework that helps in the implementation of a CQRS based architecture. The outcome of the session will result in insight in both the opportunities and threats in applying CQRS, based on very practical and down-to-earth scenarios.

author.speakingReferences: Allard has previously presented at NL-JUG (3 times), GOTO conference (f.k.a. JAOO), Jazoon and several smaller local conferences.
author.speakerBio:
Allard Buijze is software architect at Orange11, an Amsterdam based company that delivers software development, consultancy and training services to both national and international organizations. As an architect, he is responsible for the technical choices in his projects and investigates technologies for their potential in the diversity of projects Orange11 does. For the last decade, he has been developing and designing enterprise applications for both large-scale and smaller projects. His focus has always been on clean application design, maintainability and testing. The training of co-developers is a very important part thereof. 
Allard has given several trainings in the areas of test driven development, application design and clean coding. He strongly believes that good craftsmanship can only be achieved through continuous and intensive exchange of experience with others.
The last years, he has been investigating and applying CQRS to a number of projects. As a result, he founded the Axon Framework, an open source Java framework that helps developers create scalable and extensible applications by providing the building blocks that CQRS based infrastructures typically require. Axon has an active and growing community and has already been used to successfully realize several projects around the world.
author.name: Allard Buijze

title: UGM - Managing the knowledge of your community
summary:
This session will present a JEE application called UGM (User Group Management), which was initially designed and developed to manage the main activities of a Java User Group (CEJUG) and now it is also managing the knowledge produced within the group. Managing knowledge means that every text posted in member's blogs and every technical message sent to the mailing list are properly indexed and organized according to knowledge that the community wants to disseminate. Members earn points as a way to reward their contributions and get motivated to contribute more. Partners/Sponsors looking for talent people don't care about CVs any more because they basically know members' experience based on what subjects they are more active (reputation).

This application is developed using EJB 3.1, JSF 2, Primefaces 3.3, MySQL 5, CouchDB 1.2, and Jersey 1.1. We will go straight to the point, presenting the main features of the application. After that, we present the architecture and lessons learned.

title: How to Make your Code OSGi-Friendly Without Depending on OSGi
summary:
OSGi is increasingly important, but has not (yet) taken over the world. Unfortunately some libraries make mistakes that render them very difficult to use in OSGi -- and also will make them difficult to use in other module systems such as Jigsaw. For example loading classes dynamically and making assumptions about where a class can be loaded from.

In this short talk I will describe how to avoid making such mistakes, and how to build a library that is friendly towards OSGi and modularity in general, without actually tying it to OSGi.

wikiTitle: How to Make your Code OSGi-Friendly Without Depending on OSGi

title: Apache ACE
summary:
A modular runtime brings a lot of benefit when deploying applications in the cloud; zero downtime deployments (without the need of a cluster), small deployments, versioning etc. We use OSGi to modularize applications, but how do we deploy them to the cloud? You end up with a large set of small OSGi bundles. If you would package all those bundles together before deployment we lose the power of modular deployments.

Apache ACE is a provisioning server that helps you deploy modular applications to the cloud, private servers, desktops or even embedded and mobile devices. You can start up new cloud nodes (e.g. on Amazon EC2) from ACE and provision bundles to them. Updates to bundles can automatically be provisioned to servers, even to hundreds of servers or devices. ACE also keeps track of all changes over time and allows you to analyze the impact of changes to components quickly and easily.

In this presentation we will show how ACE can be used to deploy modular applications to the cloud.

As a software architect he has a broad experience in different operating systems, languages and applications, ranging from enterprise applications to mobile, embedded and distributed systems. He has been involved in lots of commercial OSGi projects for over ten years and is an expert at architecting modular systems. He is currently working on Amdatu, an open source, cloud based platform. Marcel regularly speaks at conferences, including ApacheCon, EclipseCon, JavaOne, OSGi DevCon, FOSDEM, Devoxx, NLJUG and various local demo camps and user forums and has given several hands-on trainings on OSGi related subjects.

title: Neo4j, get the graph in your hands
summary:
Your applications are producing a lot of data and nowadays more and more of that data contains information about networks of interrelated things, like how people are related to other people, companies, topics, locations, etc. Graph databases are an excellent tool for exploring such data and Neo4j is one of the best graph databases available.

In this hands-on session we will show you how to store such data into Neo4j and how you can use its tools and APIs to explore and query that data.

Session structure:

- A Brief introduction to Neo4j. 
- How to install neo4j
- How to import data
- Graph Traversal
- Interacting with your graph: 
    - through the REST API
    - through the Cypher Query language
    - through the Java API

For the last few years he has been building applications for exploring and visualizing complex networked data using Neo4J and he has become an expert Neo4j developer and community member.

title: Having fun with Android mashups
summary:
Mashup is a combination of information and services from two unrelated sources, for example showing photos from Flickr on a map from OpenStreetMap. In this presentation we take the mashup one step further by combining rich Android user interfaces with different components and services available on the web, in order to create amazing programs that blur the line between application and web content.

The audience will learn how to load data from different sources, how to show web content in an Android application, and how to set up two-way communications between the Android application and JavaScript code in the web view.

author.speakerBio:
Pär is a java developer, working primarily with Android but with a long and happy history that includes J2ME, Swing and JavaFX.
He's been working with Java since it's inception and tried everything from architecture and large enterprise systems to mobile devices. 

As a developer Pär is curious and thorough and knows the importance of pixels and colors.
Curious to learn new things, growing as a human being in the process, and happy to teach and inspire others about it.
Thorough to ensure that the quality is on par with expectations and, perhaps most importantly, to really understand something makes it
so much easier and fun to work with. Pixels and Colors have never been as important as it is today, everything is measured by it's looks,
and Pär's focus on making beautiful applications is a deliberate strategy that has paid off numerous times.

Pär has been a busy speaker for the last couple of years, presenting on the international stage as well as on Swedish conferences.

title: Building Modular Enterprise Applications in Java
summary:
This lab will introduce the OSGi framework and how to create modular, service oriented, robust and durable enterprise applications. Modularity forces separation of concerns which, when combined with a service oriented architecture, enables you to replace parts of a system without breaking others.
 
You will learn all about OSGi implementations and the wealth of open source enterprise components, and how to combine those apparent opposite worlds into coherent applications. We will also show you all you need to know about setting up your development environment to get started right away.
 
Finally, we will focus on deployment into the cloud, introducing Apache ACE, a software distribution framework that allows to centrally manage and distribute software components, configuration data, and other artifacts to target systems. We will focus on building and managing OSGi deployments, showing you how to use Apache ACE to bootstrap a framework and deploy to remotely managed systems in a cloud.

title: Productive toolbox : 5 Java Tools demonstrated in 5 minutes each
summary:
A friend of mine use to say "this tool is great, it's for kids". Some tools are really intuitive, simple and easy to use, they just do the job well. 
In this live coding presentation I will demonstrate a few java tools I find very productive and that I like to use on projects.

title: Advanced Graphics, Animations and Effects in Android
summary:
Android is a new and shiny technology that promises to deliver cutting edge UIs for many years to come, yet this might not be good enough for some of us that wants to express our creativity by creating custom graphics that looks like no other. Sometimes being ordinary is great but in this presentation, it’s all about being an individual.
In this presentation we will show you how to create advanced graphics such as glow and drop shadow effects. We will go through gradients and explain how it can be used to create different light effects and how to mix them to create appealing backgrounds. We will discuss different blend modes and the things that can be achieved by combining them. Lastly we will look at animations and, together with what we’re learnt so far, create a jaw dropping UI.

It’s all about making a lasting impression.

title: Weld-OSGi, injecting easiness in OSGi
summary:
Originally created for embedded and mobile appliances, OSGi has become a widespread foundation for building modular and dynamic applications on top of the Java platform. Despite its maturity and proven track record, OSGi is more than often referred to as a source of significant complexity for no actual benefits.
In this presentation, we will show you how OSGi, CDI and Weld nicely fit together in Weld-OSGi to assemble regular and dynamic components with no added complexity on the developer side while providing all the powerness of OSGi, especially almost transparent interactions with the dynamic service registry.
This presentation will cover CDI and OSGi basics and then will deep dive into Weld-OSGi to expose each major feature. It will also cover the upcoming standardisation of Weld-OSGi in the OSGi Enterprise platform (CDI-OSGi). This presentation will be also a place for demos to see how you can highly benefit from this framework in your modular Java EE applications to make them completely dynamic.

title: Innovative testing techniques with byte-code instrumentation
summary: Byte-code instrumentation is a powerful technique, allowing you to inject arbitrary behaviour into your Java code. It can be useful in a testing/debugging, enabling code to be temporarily added during a test-run, and leaving no impact on your production ready application.  This presentation will attempt to demystify the process of byte code instrumentation. I will present an overview of what is possible and why you might want to try the technique, followed by a practical example of what how byte code instrumentation is done, and how I have used it in the testing of real applications.

title: How to handle several Terra octets of logs for a European e-commerce leader ? Now enter Flume, Hadoop and MondoDb to the rescue!
summary:
With over one thousand JVM in production, analyzing logs without impacting  software runtime can give OPS teams a tremendous headache.

Fortunately, BigData is the answer : using 100 % Open Source frameworks (syslog-ng, Flume, Hadoop, MongoDb, NodeJs), inspired by the web giants across the pond, we are proud to present the solution we built for one of the e-commerce leaders in Europe.

You will discover how troubleshooting time was reduced by 80%, but also how we implemented new usage of log analysis, ranging from technical issues to more functional ones, such as real-time web traffic analysis, fraud detection, real-time BI...

Immerse yourselves into one of the most demanding production systems in Europe, through the completion of a technically ambitious project.

title: BigData: Get on with it!. Monitor and analyse your application logs through a web portal using syslog, Flume, Hadoop, MongoDb and HTML5.
summary:
Modern software architecture produces more and more information, overwhelming disk space without being processed efficiently. 

This hands-on lab will demonstrate how to get the most out of the logs at your disposal. We’ll delve deeper into BigData frameworks, building on an end-to-end log analysis system based on what we learned from our customers. We’ll deal with the whole chain : collecting, retaining, aggregating, analysing in real-time and reporting.

This hands-on lab will be held in the following manner :
- Quick introduction of the software stack.
- Starting Application and Cloudera's Distribution for Hadoop on a VM.
- Development of :
- Flume Filter and Sink.
- Hadoop Map/Reduce jobs.
- Custom Hadoop OutputWriter for MongoDb and WebSocket.
- HTML5 GUI for real-time dashboard displays.

After this hands-on exercise, you’ll be able to build a fully operational BigData open source log analysis system from scratch.

title: What is the best way to embed your scripting language in Java?
summary: From JRuby to Clojure, Jython to Groovy, there are many different scripting languages that can now be embedded and integrated into a JVM. And there are almost as many different ways of doing it!  This presentation will compare and contrast some of the different ways of embedding scripting languages in Java, showing the advantages and disadvantages of some of the techniques, all based on real experience of embedding multiple languages in a JVM

title: From Java Code to Java Heap: Understanding the memory usage of your application
summary: When you write and run Java code the JVM makes a number allocations on your behalf, but do you have an understanding of how much that is? This session provides an insight into the memory usage of Java code, covering the memory overhead of putting in "int" into an Integer object and the cost of object delegation and the memory efficiency of the different collection types as well as providing you with an understanding of the off-Java heap (native heap) memory usage of some types of Java objects (eg. Threads, Sockets etc). Most importantly, this session will cover how to determine where there are inefficiencies in your application, and how to choose the right collections to improve your Java code.

title: Practical performance: understand the performance of your application
summary:
Speaker: Adam Pilkington apilkington@uk.ibm.com 
A discussion of how you can maximize the performance of your application deployment using both tools that are native to your server platform and cross platform Java analysis and monitoring tools. The session begins with systematic steps you can take to locate a performance problem in a complex system and moves on to analysis you can do to understand the root cause of the problem. The picture is completed by considering the tools and techniques available to monitor application performance in normal operation so that you can catch performance issues before they build up into serious problems.

title: Real-World Compatibility and the Java Promise
summary:
Speaker: Adam Pilkington apilkington@uk.ibm.com 
Ever wonder how Java achieves such success in the “write once, run anywhere” (WORA) promise? In this talk, a senior member of the IBM Java team speaks candidly about the many difficulties Java faces behind the scenes around compatibility, and the various perspectives to consider.  We describe areas such as bugs, bug fixes, algorithmic implementation assumptions, optimizations, multiple JVM implementations, and language changes. Hear how IBM is making Java better by championing compatibility and by contributing directly to OpenJDK. By the end of the session you will have clear insights on the complexity of the issue and how it’s addressed in the OpenJDK ecosystem.

title: Android DDD (Diet Driven Development)!
summary:
Is your Android code growing big and fat? 

It's time for a slim down: with AndroidAnnotations, you will lose 42% LOC in a few hours, money-back guaranteed! Oh, by the way... it's Open Source!
Try it now, it works!

Why are we writing the same Android code over and over again? Why are our apps harder and harder to maintain? Context and Activity god objects, juggling with threads, loads of anonymous listener classes, tons of unneeded casts... can we improve that?

With a few Java annotations, developers can express their intentions and let AndroidAnnotations generate the boring boilerplate code at compile time, using the Java 6 Annotation Processing API.

The presentation will start by explaining the key concepts, followed by a live coding diet on a fat application to demonstrate AndroidAnnotations' advantages.

http://androidannotations.org/

title: Java Virtualization: Optimizing Java Applications in Cloud Environments
summary:
Speaker: Adam Pilkington apilkington@uk.ibm.com 
As virtualized (cloud) environments become more common new tuning techniques are required.  This session will discuss challenges deploying Java applications in high density, or over-commited environments and present tools & approaches that can be used to craft a high performance solution.     This session will examine JVM memory footprint in depth including performance ramifications of swapping, and interaction with hypervisors (ballooning, reconfiguration).  Existing and experimental JVM features to improve application density will be presented including: - sharing artifacts between JVMs and across guests - adjusting JVM resource consumption on the fly - exposing more information from the OS and hypervisor to Java programs.

title: Hands-on NoSQL Development with Couchbase and Java
summary:
NoSQL has garnered tremendous attention in recent years as the basis of architectures for building large linearly scalable systems. As a document oriented database, Couchbase Server presents the user with a simple approach to storing and retrieving data across a cluster and handles persistence, replication, rebalancing and so on.

Couchbase Server 2.0, based on the Apache open source license, which builds upon Apache CouchDB and Memcached, has rich querying capabilities of the distributed database through views built atop an always updating incremental map-reduce.  We will see how to access the simple and yet powerful constructs using a variety of code samples and exercises based around beer data on openbeerdb.org. 

Attend this session for a very quick overview of Couchbase, NoSQL, the ecosystem and what it means to developers, architects and implementers.  Attendees will be able to implement these concepts with exercises that progress from a simple to relatively complex.

title: Why Domain-Specific Languages Are Perfect For Full Application Testing
summary:
Fact: your application has bugs -- and this is because *every* application has bugs. Our collective challenge is to find these bugs before our customers find them. We need to use and abuse our applications as our customers will. We need end-to-end, automated integration tests that behave and misbehave like our customers. 

How best to write and automate these tests? Domain-specific languages (DSLs)! Using a DSL, you can easily convert use cases into positive and negative tests, automate the tests, express the tests in easy-to-read narrative form, and write new tests almost as fast as you can conceive of them. Isn't that worth looking into?

We'll cover some common-sense approaches to both DSL inception and DSL implementation. By following a few fundamental principles, you can have your own DSL that works across applications and -- with the right approach -- works inside your applications as well. Doesn't that sound like something to improve your quality of (work) life?

title: Improving Selenium
summary: The presentation shows the Motorola approach to web GUI testing. We believe that functional tests should be black-box and reflect the way the human tester sees the web application. Unfortunately, the naive approach to use plain Selenium forces us to deal with many technical aspects of this library, has problems with test stability, and top of that - you must know the nuts and bolts of the application under test. We would like to show, how to combine Selenium with Hamcrest and aspect-oriented programming to improve the test code readability, maintainability and robustness.

title: Process Applications with BPMN 2.0 and Java EE 6 or "Activiti in real life"
summary: The Java EE platform already offers a set of solutions to recurring problems such as persistence, transaction management or security. But the aspect missing for many applications is business process management (BPM). In this talk, we demonstrate how to fill that gap with a pure Open Source stack, so no excuses not to use it! We will show how the Activiti Process Engine can be perfectly integrated in Java EE 6, how CDI can be used to offer declarative, contextual process management and how the process engine can be a first class citizen in the Java EE container with a JBoss AS 7 integration. In the talk we demonstrate and discuss a working example application using JSF, CDI, EJB and of course Activiti and demonstrate in-container-testability using the JBoss Arquillian framework. We will share our experiences from various real life projects with that stack.

title: Bad tests, good tests
summary:
Writing tests looks simple - every kid could write few lines of JUnit code. :) Writing valuable tests is much more challenging. Everyone have seen (or have written himself!) tests, which are hard to understand, hard to maintain, and do not verify anything really important (or maybe they do, but it is too hard to deduce)! Some tests are simply a burden.

During the talk I plan to present many examples of imperfect tests and show how to improve them. I will discuss typical issues related to writing tests and present techniques which can save our code like parametrized tests, custom asserts, test data builders. The talk is technical, full of useful hints & tips & tricks & dos and & dont's. It also presents few tools (that are not so commonly used). All code examples discussed during the talk are taken from real code. The talk is aimed at novice and senior developers.

author.speakingReferences: Geecon 2009, 2011, 2012 (http://geecon.org), Confitura 2012 (http://confitura.pl), some JUG meetings
author.speakerBio:
Tomek Kaczanowski works as a senior Java developer and technical team lead. He is an experienced Java developer, focused on code quality, testing and automation.

Test infected TDD enthusiast, open-source proponent, agile worshiper. Strong inclination towards sharing his knowledge. Author of the "Practical Unit Testing with TestNG and Mockito" book (http://practicalunittesting.com), blogger at http://kaczanowscy.pl/tomek. Occasional article writer and conference speaker.

title: Why Just One Cloud? Supporting multiple clouds with jclouds
summary:
When building applications and tools for the cloud, support for multiple cloud providers is key. This avoids vendor lock-in and provides flexibility for your users. With jclouds, it's easy to migrate your application from one cloud to another without code changes, support multiple clouds from within your application, and much more.

jclouds is an open source library for JVM languages providing a consistent interface to a wide array of cloud providers and APIs, including EC2, Rackspace, vCloud, OpenStack, CloudStack and many more. Its mature API greatly simplifies the work of supporting multiple clouds, giving you a stable interface to work with regardless of the underlying provider or API.

This talk will provide an introduction to using jclouds, using the Jenkins jclouds plugin and Apache Whirr to demonstrate its power and ease of use. After attending this talk, you'll be able to get hit the ground running with your own cloud-independent application using jclouds.

author.speakingReferences: OSCON 2011
author.speakerBio: Andrew Bayer is the build architect at Cloudera, a board member, committer and maintainer of a number of plugins for Jenkins, and a committer on jclouds.

This session will introduce 4 languages that deserve better recognition. We will mostly demonstrate how to code with those languages. This will go fast!

In this lab you'll experiment how to package Java-based application servers and apps and provision them properly in a Linux environment, using techniques that should appeal to your ops and make you more productive as a developer. Moreover, this will give you a better insight on the natural ways of deploying/operating apps to a Linux environment. RPMs, DEBs, Repositories, Continuous deployment will be topics of discussion and experimentation.
