title: The Building Blocks Of The Google+ Platform
summary: Creating a social layer like Google+ doesn't just mean building a mobile application or web site  - it means developing a platform for others to build on. Drawing from over a decade of engineering web APIS, this talk will cover how Google engineered our next generation APIs for discovery, how Google+ makes use of REST, how to build client libraries to make those APIs accessible, and how to make implementation as simple as drop-and-go with social plugins. The principles will be demonstrated with real code as we define and develop a new social plugin and apply the lessons we have learned.

author.speakingReferences: Spoke at Confoo 2011, Erlang Factory 2011, DPC 2008-10, keynote PHP Northwest 2011.
author.speakerBio: Ian Barber is a Senior Developer Advocate for Google+ who is based in Google's London office. Ian has been developing, and managing development teams, professionally since 2002, primarily dealing with web technologies after a brief stint in casual games. Among other open source interests, Ian is the author of the PHP Support Vector Machine extension and a maintainer of the brokerless messaging library ZeroMQ.

Applications that run within Google+ Hangouts are some of the most engaging in social media. By combining a Javascript API with multi-user video chat,  developers have already built applications that help users  collaborate at work, compete in online games, discover a world of art, and much more. All of this is available right now, and in this session we will look at what is possible when you combine the 
power of Hangout apps with the cutting edge in browser functionality, so that you too can build something amazing.

summary: Clojure is an exciting new JVM hosted language based on LISP, with a fundamental emphasis on concurrency and expressiveness. In this talk we will take a practical look at using and working with Clojure in the real world examining the development of the new Clojure client for Google APIs, the challenges we faced in providing a consistent and expressive experience, and the benefits Clojure brings for library and application developers.

title: Java has garbage collection, how can it have memory leaks?
summary:
We hear this question a lot, even from people who code in Java as their daily job. In this talk we define what is defined by the term “memory leak” in garbage collected languages and also classify the most common and/or the trickiest to handle types of memory leaks.

We start by defining the term “memory leak” as it is being used in the Java world. We also briefly compare it to the leaks in the C language. We will then discuss different types of memory leaks that can be encountered in any Java application. We will illustrate every type of the leak with some obvious examples, but also demonstrate the more unusual/obscure ones. For every type of memory leak, we also give hints on how to remedy them.

Types of memory leaks discussed in the talk:
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java Heap Space
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: nativeGetNewTLA
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: GC overhead limit exceeded

title: How big your data is. Really.
summary:
We will begin by discussing some ways of measuring the memory consumption of different objects and object graphs in Java applications. Next, these techniques will be used to measure how much memory simple objects actually take. While at it, we will explain and discuss object references, memory alignments, integer cache and flyweight objects.

After the discussion of simple objects we will then demonstrate how much memory is really needed in order to accommodate a given amount of data into different structures from Java Collection API.

In the end of the talk we briefly discuss some alternatives to Java Collections, such as Google Guava and Trove and their memory footprint in comparison to standard libraries.
wikiPageName: How big your data is. Really.
wikiTitle: How big your data is. Really.
smallTitle: How big your data is. Really. by Nikita Salnikov-tarn

title: WORA, really?
summary:
First, we briefly describe Plumbr - the Java application in question and different aspects of it that are of interest for the given talk: it uses native code, should run on different popular platforms, has a user interface and is meant to be integrated with 3rd party products and application servers. Additionally, the development team wanted it to work nicely with the continuous integration process, which included acceptance tests.

Secondly, the setup of our continuous integration process is described: Jenkins, Linux on AWS, Mac Mini + Windows in a VirtualBox. Separate builds for native code on each platform. Then acceptance tests on each platform by starting different application servers with our application integrated and then running JMeter tests on them while monitoring for expected output from Plumbr.

Lastly we will also demonstrate how we use platform-specific native code without requiring any configuration activity from the user.
wikiPageName: WORA, really
wikiTitle: WORA, really
smallTitle: WORA, really? by Nikita Salnikov-tarn

title: Plumbr case-study
summary:
In this session we share the details of the journey of JEE developers whose roles suddenly converted to low-level JVM programming in for-us-then-unknown land of product development. We review the most interesting problems that we have encountered. For each problem we will present some possible solutions and the rationale behind our choice.
Problem 1. How to track objects’ creation and disposal events? Bytecode instrumentation and the classes that cannot be instrumented. Using JVMTI object tags to elegantly encode a lot of useful information. A problem of locking and overhead.
Problem 2. How to conduct graph analysis in a memory scarce environment. The problems of already existing libraries and APIs and why we ended up implementing the basic graph algorithm one more time ourselves.
Problem 3. User iteration and desktop integration from a Java agent. Who is RMI Reaper and how to decide when you need to commit suicide.
wikiPageName: Plumbr case-study
wikiTitle: Plumbr case-study
smallTitle: Plumbr case-study by Nikita Salnikov-tarn

title: The Rise of NoSQL and Polyglot Persistence
summary: The rise of NoSQL is characterized with confusion and ambiguity; very much like any fast-emerging organic movement in the absence of well-defined standards and adequate software solutions. Whether you are a developer or an architect, many questions come to mind when faced with the decision of where your data should be stored and how it should be managed. The following are some of these questions: What does the rise of all these NoSQL technologies mean to my enterprise? What is NoSQL to begin with? Does it mean "No SQL"? Could this be just another fad? Is it a good idea to bet the future of my enterprise on these new exotic technologies and simply abandon proven mature RDBMS? How scalable is scalable? Assuming that I am sold, how do I choose the one that fit my needs best? Is there a middle ground somewhere? What is this Polyglot Persistence I hear about? The answers to these questions and more is the subject of this talk along with a survey of the most popular of NoSQL technologies. Be there or be square.

title: CRaSH an extensible command line for the JVM
summary:
CRaSH is an open source shell for extending and monitoring a Java Virtual Machine. The shell can be accessed by various means, either remotely using network protocols such as SSH or locally by attaching a shell to a running virtual machine.

Commands are written in the Groovy language and can be developed live making the extensibility of the shell easy with quick development cycles. CRaSH comes with a bunch of commands such as thread management, log management, database access and JMX.

The session will begin with a short introduction to the shell, showing basic CRaSH features like auto completion and basic commands. The main part of the quickie will focus on showing how to develop CRaSH commands with several examples, showing how easy and powerful the development of a command can be.

The target audience is pretty much anyone using a JVM. Attendees will learn how to install CRaSH, connect to an instance and develop a CRaSH command to interact with virtual machine resources or services.

Avant cela, Julien était ingénieur chez JBoss où il a crée le projet open source JBoss Portal en 2004. En quatres années, Julien a crée un serveur de portail avec son équipe.

Julien a commencé dans l'open source au début des années 2000, principalement sur le serveur d'application JBoss 3, et a rejoint l'entreprise JBoss Group en 2002.

title: How RESTful is Your REST?
summary: The rise of Mobile and the diversity its technologies make exposing a RESTfull API the most crucial capability of any application and the key to its success. In the absence of widely adopted best practices and well-defined conventions, designing such an API is nothing but trivial. This presentation introduces the fundamentals of REST architecture, and discusses the principles of RESTfull design. Among the topics covered: resource modeling (URI design, and HTTP verbs/status code canonical usage), multiple representation support, cache control, security (Http and OAuth), and API versioning. HATEOAS and REST maturity model are also discussed, and implementation of a sample API in JAX-RS will be provided. No prior knowledge REST is required.
wikiPageName: How RESTful is Your REST
wikiTitle: How RESTful is Your REST
smallTitle: How RESTful is Your REST? by Abdelmonaim Remani

title: The Art of Metaprogramming in Java
summary:
Metaprograming is the dirty little secret behind the success of many Java frameworks such as Spring and Struts2, and constitutes the backbone of many of the most fundamental APIs across the JEE technology stack. This session aims introduce the topic and highlight, with code examples, the different mechanisms and techniques to take advantage of this underused feature of the Java Programming Language.

This session will adopt a learn-by-example approach that combines the philosophy and theory behind metaprogramming with concrete code examples. The audience will be walked real-life scenarios to highlight the benefits of this technique such as minimizing the number of lines of code, reduced development time, and greater flexibility, etc… Design patterns, and best practices will be picked up along the way.

No previous knowledge or exposure to the topic is required, but an intermediate understanding of Java SE is expected.
wikiPageName: The Art of Metaprogramming in Java
wikiTitle: The Art of Metaprogramming in Java
smallTitle: The Art of Metaprogramming in Java by Abdelmonaim Remani

title: Software Craftsmanship - more code, less tree hugging!
summary:
The agile movement brought the software development community forward, but the focus of most methodologies is the team organization itself. The software craftsmanship community tries to complement the agile values with a focus to the coding skills to enable the developers to deliver working software at a high quality. 
There are numerous local software craftsmanship usergroups that organize meetups, open space conferences and events like code retreats and coding dojos. The talk will explain why the software craftsmanship movement was born, it's goals and how it's trying to achieve them.

He is one of the founding members of the Softwerkskammer Duesseldorf (the local software craftsmanship usergroup for Duesseldorf and the surrounding area) and is an active speaker on that topic for example at the FrOSCon this year.

summary:
This session is your chance to contribute to the open source projects you've been learning about. Instead of a presentation, we will come together with several open source experts and write a plugin, a small feature, or a bug fix for a project that interests you. This is your chance to get involved with opens source and learn how to make a difference for the projects you're passionate about. Bring your laptop and your ideas; everyone is welcome. 

These are just some of the experts that have participated in the past: Hans Dockter (Gradle Lead), Andres Almiray (Java Champion, Griffon Lead, and Groovy Committer), Stephen Chin (Java Champion, JavaFX and Android Expert), Hamlet D'Arcy (CodeNarc and Groovy Committer), Peter Gromov (IntelliJ IDEA guru).

title: Cloud Without Fear
summary:
What does it mean to develop an enterprise Java application for the cloud? How "cloud aware" must an application become to be considered a good tenant in a shared container? If the cloud is largely about virtualization then which is the most effective layer in the stack to virtualize? And how many WebSphere Application Servers can dance on the head of a pin? Or a Raspberry Pi.

This session will look at how relevant Java EE is to the cloud, how enterprise platform architectures are evolving to meet the challenges of mobile and social-enabled workloads, and how to take the fear out of developing and deploying ever more complex solutions at huge scale.

summary: It's a well known fact that the Java language is verbose, probably more verbose than what it should be. In the past, developers have relied on external tools such as IDEs to cope with the verbosity level. But what if we were able to workaround the problem with the language itself? Come learn about AST transformations and how they can be applied to the Java language.

title: Building Interactive, SEO, and safe web applications with JWt
summary: Despite the official stamp that Java web interface solutions like JSF carry, there is still a growing interest in alternative approaches which increase developer productivity and reduce security risks. This is what drives the increasing popularity of alternative Java solutions such as JWt or Wicket. In this hands-on lab, we will create a small multi-page web application with JWt, which includes real-time social interactivity (chat and drawing board) using the latest techniques such as HTML5 history management, WebSockets and async I/O. In the process, we will also gain insight in what JWt does under the hood to make applications secure-by-default.

He is a co-founder of Emweb, which drives the development of these toolkits, and which provides services to companies world-wide, helping them to make safer, and better maintainable web applications faster.

title: 7 Languages in 7 Weeks with Xtext
summary:
Developing domain specific languages (DSLs) for Java has become surprisingly easy! Xtext lets you reuse Java compatible language concepts such as expressions, type references and annotations anywhere in your DSL. You only need to describe the grammar and a mapping to Java. From that you get a statically typed language with its own compiler and top notch Eclipse integration.

To inspire your imagination we’ve developed 7 useful yet different DSLs. These languages include a Gradle-like language to describe builds, an Http routing DSL similar to the one from play! and a fun and interactive reimplementation of Logo (do you remember?). All of them support debugging and tight integration with Eclipse's Java IDE out of the box. And the best is that it actually didn’t take 7 weeks to do that.

In this session you will learn the basic steps needed to implement a DSL for the JVM. After that, you will get a brief overlook of what else is possible. Language development with Xtext is interesting, fun, and creative!

author.speakingReferences: I regularly speak at conferences. I've been talking at EclipseCon, JAX, W-JAX, SeaCon, OOP Munich, Jazoon, Jfokus, various Java User Groups and other events. I have been voted to one of the top speakers at EclipseCon 2012 (http://goo.gl/cJEzD)

He leads an open-source development lab in Kiel which focuses on language design, compiler development and Eclipse technologies. He is project lead of several open-source projects at Eclipse.org. Among them is Xtend (http://xtend-lang.org), a statically-typed programming language that compiles into Java source code, and Xtext (http://xtext.org), an award-winning framework for language development.

title: Polyglot Persistence Spring Applications on OpenShift
summary:
Red Hat OpenShift is a multi-language, multi-framework, multi-cartridge Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) solution from Red Hat. This rich platform gives the developer several choices in terms of languages (e.g., Java, PHP, Python, Ruby, etc.), frameworks (e.g., Spring, JavaEE, etc.), and datastores (e.g., MySQL, PostgreSQL, and MongoDB). Support for multiple datastores enables you to choose the right tool for right problem and embraces Polyglot persistence. In this session, I will cover:

    What is OpenShift
    How you can interact with the OpenShift rhc command line tool to:
        Create an application
        Enable Jenkins support
        Add MongoDB and MySQL cartridges
    Walk through a Spring MongoDB MySQL web application
    Push the code to cloud

Bring your laptops and follow the steps as we create and push applications to the cloud.

title: Database-driven mobile applications: the power of ORM
summary:
As of ColdFusion 9 you have the ability to create database driven applications by writing virtually no SQL statements using ORM. You can use this server-side feature on the client-side in an AIR application.

This session will talk you through the basics of using ColdFusion ORM in AIR and how to "automagically" synchronise your local data with a remote ColdFusion 9 server. That's not all: we'll go one step further and take that ability to create database driven applications onto the mobile platform as well. Just like that.

author.speakerBio:
Steven Peeters built up a solid background as a (Visual) C++ developer on both Windows and AIX environments during the first 6 years of his career. After this period he made the switch to developing Rich Internet Applications. Starting out in 2004 with Flex 1.5, he now has gained over 7 years of experience in developing technologically complex and demanding Flex and AIR applications (desktop and mobile), in combination with LiveCycle Data Services, BlazeDS, amfphp and ColdFusion.

Steven joined multimediacollege in February 2008, where he also became the first Adobe Certified Instructor for Flex and AIR in the BeLux region (Belgium and Luxembourg). So now, most of the time he teaches Flex, AIR, Flash Catalyst, LiveCycle and ColdFusion courses to all kinds of developers (beginner and advanced). But of course he does some interesting projects between the courses as well to keep his skills up-to-date and to improve them constantly.

He does some presentations and workshops on Flex, AIR and LiveCycle Data Services for the Belgian Adobe offices on a regular basis. As Adobe Community Professional and User Group Manager for the Belgian Adobe ColdFusion User Group Steven is also dedicated to sharing his knowledge with the community, hence this website.

In May 2012, Steven Started his own company. Silver Lining is a company that offers consultancy for desktop, web and mobile projects, as well as training and workshop offers for Adobe related products such as Flex, AIR, ColdFusion, Captivate, Flash, Dreamweaver, Photoshop etc. You can visit the website at http://www.silver-lining.be to find out more about what exactly this company has to offer and for more contact information.

title: Xtend - An Introduction For Java Developers
summary:
Xtend is a new language that compiles into idiomatic Java source code. It is designed to work great with existing Java APIs and idioms, yet introduces new features to modernize Java applications. It is faster than Groovy, simpler than Scala and incorporates all benefits of Java such as great tool support and interoperability with many thousands existing tools and frameworks. It’s the CoffeeScript for Java.

The session starts with an overview of the main design goals. After that we go through real-world and fun code examples, showing the expressiveness and flexibility of the language. Finally you'll see examples for Android, JavaFX and GWT demonstrating how nicely Xtend interacts with existing Java APIs. 

If you know Java, you should be ready to have fun with Xtend after this session.
wikiPageName: Xtend - An Introduction For Java Developers
wikiTitle: Xtend - An Introduction For Java Developers
smallTitle: Xtend - An Introduction For Java Developers by Sven Efftinge

title: Blast your webapp with Gatling
summary:
Your application is going live tomorrow, the new marketing campaign is about to start, you enjoy a margarita, life is good. Yet something keeps bugging you, are you sure your webapp won't crash down? "Damn, forgot about the stress tests!"

Traffic grows, data grows, our applications have to withstand increasing loads, so stress tests are more and more of a critical issue.

Gatling is a new generation stress tool developed in Scala. Its fully async engine based on Akka actors and Netty NIO makes it very efficient, and the rich yet simple DSL makes it very user-friendly. Your project managers will love it too, thanks to its relevant and portable reports.

This talk will cover the main principles of Gatling's architecture and demonstrate how quick and easy building stress tests with Gatling is.

More information about Gatling here:
http://gatling-tool.org
https://github.com/excilys/gatling

author.speakingReferences:
Stéphane frequently speaks about Gatling in various conferences: JUGs, SUGs, DevoxxFR, Devoxx, etc.
https://github.com/excilys/gatling/wiki/Events
author.speakerBio:
Stéphane is the eBusiness Information CTO, a french JEE consulting company, part of the Excilys Group.
He's been having fun playing with the Java ecosystem for 12 years, but Scala and Akka bring fun to a higher level.
He's the founder and the technical leader of the Gatling stress tool project.

title: Fiddling with Phidgets
summary:
Everyone has seen lots of Rich Internet Applications on the web and on the desktop using Flash, Flex and AIR. Awesome games with mind blowing (3D) graphics and astonishing real-time business applications are actually just the tip of the iceberg. 

In this session you’ll learn about coupling these cross-platform and cross-device technologies to hardware such as motors, sensors and RFIDs, which allows you to create all kinds of robots and some real world fun and games. To take it even one step further you’ll discover how you can take advantage of mobile devices to take control of that hardware. It's not all talk, because there will be some demonstrations as well. 

Whether it’s domotics, robots or games, the only limit is your imagination…

title: Scala, JavaFX, Java EE 7 and Enterprise Integration
summary: This session shows you how to use Scala, which is one of the hottest technologies, to build a JavaFX application that to talks to a Java EE 7 application server. Scala is a object-functional language that improves on Java in several areas. Java EE 7 is the enterprise edition "taking it to the clouds" with virtualisation. I will show how to build a Scala application with ScalaFX framework, a domain specific language, and tie it to application that stores data to the cloud. I will discuss the limitations of the technologies I chose to write the application. I will also discuss the hot issue of the moment, should I stick with Spring Framework or dump it to go with the Java EE specification.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne 2012, Devoxx 2011, JavaOne 2011
author.speakerBio:
Peter Pilgrim is an independent contractor, a professional software developer, designer and architect. Since 1998 he has worked in the financial services industry, investment banking mainly, developing Information Technology for clients. He is a well-known specialist in Java Enterprise Edition (Java EE) technology, focused on the server-side and the implementation of electronic commerce. Peter has built professional Java EE applications for Bluechip companies and top-tier investment banks including Lloyds Banking Group, UBS, Credit Suisse, and Royal Bank of Scotland. Peter is the 91st Oracle Java Champion (February 2007). He is a fan of Agile and TDD.

As well as extensive Java development experience, Peter is an early adopter of technologies and leading light for progression on the Java platform, especially by influencing the wider community. Peter gained valuable experience in alternative JVM languages such as JavaFX, Scala and Groovy. He has developed a number of JavaFX experimental custom controls.

title: Raise Your Java EE 6 Productivity Bar With JBoss Forge
summary:
Getting started with Java EE development can, despite the important improvements over time, still be quite daunting for newbies. Putting a JSF application to work, setting up persistence or enabling restful web services are not trivial tasks.  
JBoss Forge is a versatile and lean development environment entirely written in Java and making smart use of CDI. Its purpose is to offer you the possibility of incrementally working in new functionality into existing Java projects. It is a command-line oriented tool, so creating entities or scaffolding a user interface is just a matter of issuing a few commands. 
But what if your task cannot be done by Forge? No worries, as Forge operates by means of plug-ins, the answer is simply to look for an appropriate plugin or create it yourself if one is not available. 
Finally, Forge can also be integrated in graphical IDE's opening up all its power to users of common platforms such as Eclipse.
Come to this session if you want to see this powerful tool live in action!

Earlier he was responsible for the Eclipse support and the different workflow editors of the jBPM project. Koen graduated as a Civil Engineer from the Belgian Royal Military Academy and obtained an additional Master's Degree in Information Technology at the Brussels Free University. Before joining JBoss and Red Hat, he worked respectively in the IT department of the Belgian Army and as a software consultant. Koen is a regular speaker at public events and conferences.

title: Code injection in  Android
summary:
Tool allows to optimize, trace and modify Android project on the fly using code injection into existing project.
Code is intected on the fly, no need to modify old functionality to add logging/profiling or disable portion of the flow. 

Main functionality of the tool:
- trace: entering/exiting to/from method, collecting parameters and exiting value)
- profile: measuring the frequency and duration of method calls
- disable: disabling/skipping part of the program flow by overriding returning value from methods defined by the user.

Tool is written in Java and AspectJ, works with Eclipse.

title: Hibernate Performance Tuning
summary:
Hibernate is an elegant, straightforward, and easy to use library. This is undeniably true for simple domain models. What about more complex ones? It turns out that in case of complex domain models we usually run into interesting performance issues.
After a brief introduction to a methodology to performance tune Hibernate applications, together with the audience we tune a Hibernate-based application. The application models a number of Hibernate performance anti-patterns that are common in real world applications. During the session, we show how to identify performance bottlenecks in Hibernate using Hibernate logging and a number of tools to track runtime characteristics. Along with the identified performance problems, more efficient alternatives are presented.
wikiPageName: Hibernate Performance Tuning
wikiTitle: Hibernate Performance Tuning
smallTitle: Hibernate Performance Tuning by Patrycja Wegrzynowic

title: Webservice versioning - a practical example, from documentation to publication and from code to deployment
summary:
The problem with webservices is that is it usually not possible to upgrade the server and all clients at the same time. Therefore some kind of webservice versioning is necessary. Unfortunately there is no official standard for this. In this (methodology) conference talk I would like to present a practical example of how we create and version webservices at Reggefiber. 
First, I will show our choices
* the version number is added to the namespace, WSDL and XSD filename, package name, WAR name and endpoint
* every change results in a new version number (making it not backwards compatible)
* the (dis)advantages of the above choices will be discussed in the last part of the presentation
Next, I will guide the audience through an example and show how the above choices are handled in
* documenting our webservices
* publishing our webservice definitions
* generating OXM classes and publishing them in our Maven repository (Nexus)
* implementing webservices
* building WARs
* deploying our applications
wikiPageName: Webservice versioning - a practical example, from documentation to publication and from code to deployment

title: ‘Back to the Future’ – Taking Arduino back to its Java roots to move forward
summary:
Arduino began life as the java based Processing IDE, which forked as Wiring, and again as Arduino and again as MPIDE. Needless to say with all this forking things are starting to break!

The Muvium V18’O Plugin includes an Ahead-Of-Time compiler, USB HID programmer and Emulator taking Arduino ‘Back to the Future’ by plugging into Processing and supporting Java in place of Arduino “NQJ” (Not-Quite-Java) 

Benefits include
* Tighter integration with the Processing ecosystem
* Java better suited for teaching and professional development
* Dynamic Objects, Garbage Collection, Exceptions, Inheritance, Interfaces and other java language features missing from Arduino make code easier to develop and share
* Emulation is ideal for testing and sharing code but missing from Arduino
* In-Circuit debugging is also missing from Arduino. Muvium supports JDWP ready for use with Eclipse/Netbeans for those who outgrow Processing

Demonstration includes Installation, Use of the Emulator and Programming a Real V18’O

James is the creator of an integrated suite of technologies that work together to blur the edge of virtual and real. Including VirtualBreadboard (www.virtualbreadboard.com) – the abstract hardware design and simulation tool that makes the real world virtual, and Muvium (www.muvium.com)- the Ahead-Of-Time Java compiler for microcontrollers that makes the virtual world real.

title: Hibernate Strikes Back: Performance Anti-Patterns Episode 2
summary:
Hibernate is an elegant, straightforward, and easy to use library. This is undeniably true for simple domain models. What about more complex ones? It turns out that in case of complex domain models we usually run into interesting performance issues.

After discussing basic mappings of collections and sub-object last year, this time we focus on advanced parameters for collections, inheritance hierarchies, and HQL. In this puzzle-driven talk, we explain common mistakes or omissions related to usage of advanced attributes in mappings of complex structures like collections or inheritance trees. Additionally, we show performance impact of various constructs in HQL-based or Criteria-based queries. The presented real code examples illustrate how the anti-patterns can decrease performance and how to implement the mappings to speed up execution times.

title: Fighting Layout Bugs
summary: Nearly everybody has automated tests today. But those tests typically only check functionality – what about layout bugs? How do you ensure, that every page of your web application looks like the designers wanted it to look like? I will present some proven and some novel techniques to help you automatically check the work of HTML and CSS programmers. I will show examples of typical layout bugs and explain techniques how you can write automated tests for detecting/preventing those bugs.

title: Rethinking application design for the Cloud
summary:
Cloud is everywhere: It is no longer used exclusively by famous startups or elite teams such as DropBox or NetFlix. Brick and mortars businesses such as newspapers and even banks now use Cloud Computing!
 
However, these success stories did not happen by chance. Having infinite resources, servers, memory or storage is not a silver bullet.
 
Let’s discover the new application design guidelines to succeed on the Cloud. We will not only cover the glamorous new concepts for scalability, high availability and new keys to productivity but also the new security constraints, legal challenges, costs models or reversibility rules.
 
We will cover with a live demo
* Availability and scalability with Amazon AWS
* Cloud services: the new building blocks for applications
* Security, legal issues, pricing and reversibility on the Cloud

title: Automated Detection of Security Vulnerabilities
summary:
This talk discusses and contrasts two approaches to automated detection of security vulnerabilities in web applications: black-box testing and white-box static analysis. 

In our demo of automated detection of security vulnerabilities, we run two tools: Yonita for Security (source-code static analysis) and Yonita Security Scanner (URL scanning) against a custom application with numerous security vulnerabilities (including code injections, XSS, CRFS, authentication and authorization problems, integer overflow, and direct object references). While comparing the results, we discuss the capabilities of both tools and explain the mechanisms behind the tools together with their strengths and weaknesses.

Additionally, we also present a short summary of security issues found automatically in popular libraries, including Spring, Struts, and others.
wikiPageName: Automated Detection of Security Vulnerabilities
wikiTitle: Automated Detection of Security Vulnerabilities
smallTitle: Automated Detection of Security Vulnerabilities by Patrycja Wegrzynowic

title: Big boys play Java with Lego, leJOS and Android
summary:
I would like to show a combination of Java and the well known Lego bricks. Including some small motors and a few sensors, the Lego Mindstorms kit makes it possible to build various robots from Technic bricks, control them using the motors and make them interact with the outside world through the light, sound and distance sensors.

The robots can then be programmed using the open-source leJOS library, which consists of a mobile virtual machine (to replace Mindstorms' original firmware) and a nice hardware abstraction.

Additionaly, the talk covers some basic topics related to use of Bluetooth and motion sensors on Android. The above combined let us build a simple robot remotely controlled with an Android phone.

The talk is going to have a theoretical part, during which I would like to introduce the basics of leJOS and Android development, and give a brief overview of the remote control application and the robot software. This is then going to be followed with a live demo showing the robot in action.

title: H-UBU – Dependency Injection for JavaScript
summary:
The popularity of JavaScript continues to increase, despite misgivings from some quarters. Developers now shun it at their peril, but what happens as ever-more complex applications are implemented in JavaScript? They quickly become unmaintainable.
We implemented one application that peaked at 60,000 lines of JavaScript. During development, we began investing in reusing Java/server-side patterns in JavaScript. The result is H-UBU, an injection framework for JavaScript. H-UBU allows JavaScript applications to be developed with self-defined, autonomous and testable components. Components interact with one another using injected references or events. Thanks to H-UBU, we have been able to develop and maintain large JavaScript applications. We have code that scales better, and developers who can reuse the concepts promoted by CDI and other Java component models.
This talk introduces H-UBU, and explains how you can use this simple injection framework to successfully build sophisticated JavaScript applications.

title: Down the rabbit hole with scalaz
summary: Monads, Monoids, Functors, Applicatives. These are the magical terms that define the higher order functional landscape of Scala. In this talk we will start in the lower level lands of Scala, and explain how these magical terms work on a practical level. We show examples that demonstrate the simplicity and power of this approach (using Validation as our main tool). In the second part we will level up! Into the abyss, descending into the theoretical parts of functional programming and category theory to explain the concepts of functors, applicative functors and monoids which form the basis of the Scalaz library. All of this will be explained using live coding.  Some knowledge of Scala and functional programming is assumed.

author.speakingReferences:

DynCon 2011, Concurrency in Clojure

Sander van den Berg has been active in IT since 1999.

He has worked as a software developer for several defense related companies, where he mainly worked on MDA/MDD solutions. Sander van den Berg joined Xebia in 2010 as a Senior Consultant for the unit IT Architects, where he is responsible for the Xebia Lean Architecture approach.

Besides architecture, Sander is very interested in language design. He is active in several functional programming communities. He likes elegant solutions to hard problems, preferring Haskell as a means to express them. Being an advocate for DSL’s, he also has a keen interest in Clojure.

summary: This talk presents how Apache Maven can be used to rationalize JavaScript and CoffeScript development. We explain how you can continue to keep your client-side development on the cutting edge, while making it more robust and easier to integrate. A set of plugins can help you to manage all aspects of development from compilation and syntax checking to aggregation, minification and tests. We cover everything you need to know in order to successfully use Maven with JavaScript and CoffeeScript. This talk also covers the LESS CSS framework.

title: How to solve memory leaks within minutes with Plumbr
summary:
Plumbr is a memory leak detection tool that makes solving memory leaks easy. It launched beta in the end of 2011 and quickly became popular and received thousands of downloads. The product launched an official 1.0 version in June 2012 and has been used by many companies since.

In the session we will:
* get a quick re-cap of what constitute a memory leak in garbage-collected JVM
* create a simple classloader leak and a heap leak on the fly
* see the effects that the leaks have to the permgen and heap usage
* see how Plumbr detects the leaks and study the leak reports
* solve the leaks and verify that the application is leak-free

The presentation is targeted towards Java developers and Java system administrators. You will learn how to recognize a memory leak and how to solve the most common cases of it. No previous knowledge of JVM internals required.
wikiPageName: How to solve memory leaks within minutes with Plumbr
wikiTitle: How to solve memory leaks within minutes with Plumbr
smallTitle: How to solve memory leaks within minutes with Plumbr by Nikita Salnikov-tarn

title: Everyone wants an "app for that" - IBM's answer for rapid mobile app development and delivery
summary: Regardless of how you choose to implement a mobile app, the pressure to deliver it rapidly is intense. Many projects have release targets only a few weeks from the start of work. The line-of-business stakeholders have very high expectations for the attractiveness and usability of the mobile app. And they wanted it to be available in the app store last month, not next month. Implementation choices can help or hurt you with meeting aggressive release targets. We'll talk about those issues and we'll also look at the role that your tools play and how your development process can be tuned for tight deadlines. We'll discuss your development team organization and many other ways in which "speed bumps" can be eliminated from your mobile development project.

author.speakingReferences:
GSMA Mobile Asia Congress - The IBM Mobile Enterprise strategy - Overview and mobile application development details
IBM delivers a comprehensive end-to-end mobile solution.

His current role is as a member of the IBM Rational Software Chief Technology Officer team, influencing the strategic direction for products in the Rational brand and leading the solution definition for mobile application development. Leigh holds a BS degree in Computer Science from Nova University and a Masters degree in Computer Engineering from University of Texas at Austin.

title: Illustrated DevOps: App configuration in a nutshell.
summary:
Application configuration parameters is one key element in the Dev and Ops battle. This quickie will focus on how to answer the following questions :

- What are the basic principles of an application parameters gouvernance ?
- How to avoid manual management that could be error prone ?
- How to ensure an up-to-date documentation of each version delivered ?
- How to trace and debug the configuration values at each application startup in production ?

We illustrate typical application configuration issues and explain some best practice and patterns to make the way more easy.

Our code base contains many parameters : options, urls, emails ... some params with a default value that never change, some params to change during the application staging. Managing the configuration by hand is error prone and could introduce some high friction between dev and ops.

Becoming aware of the configuration gouvernance is a basic for starting some DevOps practice: we show some pragmatic demo to begin quickly.

Actuellement, il est architecte pour le site LesFurets.com (comparateur d'assurances), et aime aussi prendre l'air de temps en temps à San Francisco ou à Anvers. Il a présenté différentes sessions à JavaOne, Devoxx et plusieurs Java User Group en France.

title: Funamble: a web oriented mobile framework enabling to create rich, interactive, flexible & cross-platform applications
summary:
Since 2011, the mobile applications market has seen the rise of web-based applications. 
However, web standards are not universally supported or rendered the same way from one platform to another. So, a company adopting a web-oriented strategy to develop cross-platform applications must make numerous crucial choices in terms of JS libraries & CSS properties. In addition, a cross-platform design is almost impossible to achieve. For these reasons, we have created a framework, named Funamble. It is an object-oriented JS library based on Mootools and jQuery enabling us to build rich and flexible cross-platform mobile applications, like games or animations. It dynamically creates, adapts and drives the application UI without requiring a hard-coded, CSS-based “responsive” design. To achieve this, Funamble manages an ultra-thin subset of HTML / CSS and requires only one version of the UI design. This talk presents Funamble and details FishDish implementation, an action game deployed on Android & iOS marketplaces.

title: Up and running with Kotlin
summary: After spending over a decade designing tools and IDE’s for languages, and having programmed these mostly in Java and C#, we have been through many a language and we still continue to develop our tools in Java and C#. Reason being is that we still haven’t found a better replacement, and that’s why Kotlin is born. A strongly typed static language, developed in the open under the Apache OSS license, Kotlin tries to solve the shortcomings of Java and at the same time provide interesting features from other languages such as Scala. In this session we'll see a brief introduction to Kotlin, what it's about, and what you need to get up and running.

author.speakingReferences: http://hadihariri.com/conferences
author.speakerBio: Hadi Hariri is a developer, speaker, podcaster and Technical Evangelist at JetBrains. His passions include software architecture and web development. Book author and frequent contributor to developer publications, Hadi has been speaking at industry events for over a decade. He is based in Spain where he lives with his wife and three sons, and runs the .NET Malaga User Group. He is also an ASP.NET MVP and ASP.NET Insider.
author.name: Hadi Hariri

wikiPageName: Up and running with Kotlin
wikiTitle: Up and running with Kotlin
smallTitle: Up and running with Kotlin by Hadi Hariri

title: Putting Kotlin to the test
summary: Kotlin is a new OSS programming language from JetBrains, leaders of IDE’s and Developer tools. Its purpose is to provide a general industry focused language that can be used for all types of development, and at the same time, fixing some of the common pitfalls of other languages that can end up being very expensive. That’s the idea behind it at least, but does it hold? In this session we’re going to find out. We’ll put it to the test by creating a real-world application and see if and where it can help and whether it has enough the potential to be a prime runner!
wikiPageName: Putting Kotlin to the test
wikiTitle: Putting Kotlin to the test
smallTitle: Putting Kotlin to the test by Hadi Hariri

title: Kotlin: Making the Java Platform a Better Place
summary:
Kotlin is a modern statically typed general-purpose language designed to be safe, concise, expressive and 100% Java-compatible. It is compiled to Java byte code as well as JavaScript, so it can run on both client- and server-side.

This session gives an overview of the key features of Kotlin and demonstrates how the new language integrates into the existing infrastructure. On top of that we show how one can make Java APIs better using Kotlin, without having to alter them in any way.
wikiPageName: Kotlin  Making the Java Platform a Better Place
wikiTitle: Kotlin  Making the Java Platform a Better Place
smallTitle: Kotlin: Making the Java Platform a Better Place by Hadi Hariri

title: What's with all the node?
summary:
Node.js has been around for a few years, then boom! A sudden increase in popularity, Microsoft catching wind and supporting it on their cloud platform Azure and suddenly everyone is talking node.js. As a Java or .NET developer, is this something you should care about? IIs it merely about scalability or is there something else behind it? Is it hype or is it hip?
In this session we’ll find out what makes node.js so attractive, how it simplifies drastically the programming model using asynchronous callbacks, how an amazing ecosystem provides pretty much anything we might need, from simple helpers to full-blown MVC frameworks.
wikiPageName: What's with all the node
wikiTitle: What's with all the node
smallTitle: What's with all the node? by Hadi Hariri

title: Just cause it's JavaScript doesn't give you a license to write crap!
summary:
JavaScript, the language that we all laughed at and our usage of it was limited to copy/paste of scripts to have some dynamic content in a web page has all grown up. From jQuery on the client-side to node.js on the server, everywhere you look there’s JavaScript. Unfortunately there’s also a ton of horrible, twisted and somewhat convoluted code that would make any developer that remotely cares about clean code suicidal. 
A dynamic language that has somewhat given us a license to do anything we want has been abused to the point that much of the blame has been placed on the language itself as opposed to the developers. In this talk we’ll discuss some of the patterns and anti-patterns of JavaScript, things you should and shouldn’t do. If you care about writing clean and maintainable code, you should care about it in any language!
wikiPageName: Just cause it's JavaScript doesn't give you a license to write crap!

title: Thinking through Enterprise Performance
summary:
Performance of Enterprise Applications is a requirement and usually a challenge. Improving performance by tuning the application after it has been built seldomly renders huge improvements. By taking a step back - or even two - and regarding the application and performance from a distance, it becomes possible to really design and architect for performance. Order of magnitude improvements are attainable through logical reasoning and careful application of multi-tier architecture principles and JEE platform facilities.

In its essence, performance can be improved by a number of approaches that are discussed. This sessions guides the audience through a few logical steps, using every day examples that are translated to JEE architecture facilities and design decisions. Attendees will look at their application architectures in a fresh way.

author.speakerBio: Lucas Jellema is an experienced Java and Oracle developer and architect, working for AMIS in The Netherlands. Lucas has close to 20 years of experience in a wide variety of projects, organizations and technologies. He has been nominated Oracle ACE Director for Fusion Middleware. He is a frequent presenter at JavaOne, Oracle Open World, NLJUG and other user group conferences around the world. He also teaches Master Classes on on various topics such as SOA & BPM, Database Development and Java application architecture. He frequently writes at http://technology.amis.nl and has also authored the Mc GrawHill publication Oracle SOA Suite 11g Handbook.

title: Don't call us - we'll push - cross tier push architecture
summary:
Pushing information is a decoupled and performance effective way to ensure interested parties have the most recent information ASAP.

This session looks at reasons and technology for pushing information at various points in an enterprise architecture. Databases can push to the middle tier - as a result of data manipulation - the middle tier pushes to the browser - triggered by email, chat, JMS message or CEP (Complex Event Processing) event and one client can push to another. The link with Event Driven Architecture is explored as well as mobile applications.

HTTP Channels and Web Sockets are introduced, push in JEE 7 is discussed as well as AJAX based background push, push from the database. We'll look at what to send in an event and how to present the push signal to the end user. This session will explain how push is good for performance and (decoupled) architecture in general, it talks about upstream push and real time challenges. Of course this session includes many interesting demos.
wikiPageName: Don't call us - we'll push - cross tier push architecture
wikiTitle: Don't call us - we'll push - cross tier push architecture

summary:
Your bugtracker does not implement the processes you want ? It's to complicated for your needs and you are planning to develop your own solution ?

title: Who killed Jetty on server#53?  Developing and working efficiently with collections of servers
summary:
Software systems nowadays are composed of lots of servers and processes (webservers, workers processes, distributed caches, …). 
You might have seen situations like these : 
- Do I need to restart this process after deploying the new version?
- We bought more machines to scale, can we deploy everything to put them into production by tomorrow?
- it takes a day to implement and test this feature, so we can have it in production for tomorrow, right?
- Where is the up-to-date list of production machines and what processes run on them?

This talk is based on feedback from real-life experiences in small teams developing software systems on grids of servers.
I will explain how we grew a solution for managing grids of dev, pre-prod and prod servers. 
The solution allows one-command redeploy of a given version (GIT) of the system and various maintenance processes. 
It is build incrementally, allowing the team to optimize the work process based on day-to-day feedback.

title: Developing JEE Web Applications with built-in business agility and customizability
summary:
Software development and release cycles take much longer than business would like: weeks to months instead of days. The agility and short time to market so desired can be brought about by introducing configuration-at-runtime facilities into applications - that allow changing behavior and look & feel without the need for software re-development and rollout. Additionally, SaaS applications can be tuned to specific user groups using customization features per internal user group or external customer. This session demonstrates how such agility can be built into JavaServer Faces applications. Demos include: fine grained permissions, add/change/hide fields, page reorganization, boiler plate text editing and more.

The key objectives of this session: explain how customization of (SaaS) applications are similar & desired, discuss how functionality & look/feel can be made configurable at run time and show how run time manipulation of the JSF UIComponent tree opens many options for customization

title: JEE development - the Oracle way: introducing Oracle ADF to Java professionals
summary: Oracle was among the first companies to embrace Java, back in the '90s. They have a long history with Java - to create their middleware and tools and also to build small, specialized as well humongous enterprise applications. The Oracle Application  Development Framework (ADF) is their implementation and application of the JEE platform, the strategic foundation under all application development by Oracle and many of its customters. This session introduces ADF to Java professionals: what is it (to you)? How can you work it it, learn from it, further your career with it or argue against it? The session will have key demos, point out strengths, weaknesses and future developments. It will also explain how JEE developers can get started with ADF

title: Java developers: make the database work for you
summary: The database can be much more to your Java application than just a dumb data store. Most database can handle complex aggregations and data analysis, calculations and bulk manipulation, and some offer advanced features like flashback, change notification, zero-down time upgrades and fine grained security and auditing. At the same time, NoSQL style grid based cache facilities may (partially) replace or complement traditional relational databases. This session reviews what Java applications can and should make databases do - and what not. It also demonstrates how the database can best be accessed - and how the database can push information the other way to the application.The objectives for this session: make the audience better appreciate what modern database can do, illustrate how a multi-tier application can be designed - taking the database into account as tier and demonstrate some useful Java/Database interaction patterns-leveraging each for its specific strength.
wikiPageName: Java developers  make the database work for you

title: Going live with the OpenStack Open Source Cloud Solution
summary:
This conference will present OpenStack, the Open source software for building private and public clouds, based on hands-on experience gained from R&D activities and test-beds set-up for industrial partners. The talk will cover two releases and the evolution between both: Diablo & Essex.
First, the usage of Devstack for testing and development environments and the configuration will be detailed, up to advanced features, such as DRP, nova-volume backup and replication, as well as the test of bleeding edge features.
As regards practical usage of OpenStack,  the experience from integration in production environment will be detailed as well as the scripted installation. A feedback from the usage of various hypervisors will be given (KVM, xen via libvirt, xenserver and XCP via XenAPI).
As an open source software, the support and activity of the OpenStack community will be covered as well as the evolution in the field of open source cloud managers.

title: Oh Behave!!!! Behavior-driven development with JavaEE
summary:
Behaviour-Driven Development (BDD) is an evolution of Test-Driven Development (TDD). It shifts the vocabulary from being test-based to behaviour-based, and positions itself as a design philosophy.

JBehave is a Java framework for Behaviour-Driven Development and this session will explore how to write integration tests for your Java EE apps using JBehave. We will also demonstrate how to leverage the Context and Dependency Injection (CDI) APIs to implement your tests.

This session is a must see for all Java EE developers who want a better way to write integration tests that are aligned with the intended behaviour.

The session covers:
• Brief introduction to Behaviour-Driven Development
• JBehave introduction  
• Using JBehave with CDI
• Techniques building integration tests

title: From Zero to Cloud – and Beyond – in 10 Minutes
summary:
You have just developed a cool new Java EE app. Finding a Cloud to run it is one challenge on its own. Once you get there - it’s great to see it live in a couple of minutes but still there are those tiny details here and there to make it really perfect. 
Typically people lose tremendous time in redeploying their apps over and over again with every little change they make. Don’t you think there are better ways to spend your time? Wouldn’t it be perfect to see the changes as soon as you save them in your IDE? 
Join us to see this developers’ dream coming true and start planning what to do with all the time you’ll save that way.

title: Plugging Into JBoss Forge
summary:
JBoss Forge is an incremental enhancement tool that lets you take an existing Java project and safely add in new functionality. Forge operates by means of plug-ins, each of them contributing one or more commands to do a particular task. 
This session is a deep dive into JBoss Forge plug-in development. While we will show how to create such a plug-in, the purpose of the session is also to gather ideas for new and cool plug-ins. Come share your opinion and make sure Forge can be extended with the capabilities you would like. Maybe we can even develop it on the spot!

title: Behavior Driven Development with Cucumber-JVM
summary:
How do you ensure that you're developing the right software? A difficult task that projects face ever since. How do you understand what the customer wants - and how does he get his idea across? How do you communicate the requirements to all colleagues participating in development and testing? By the way, documentation is needed as well! And automated acceptance testing would be great! We want to introduce Behaviour Driven Development with Cucumber to you as a possible answer to all these questions.
With the help of to little stories from real world projects we want to show you how the methodology of Specification By Example helps yout to specify the right system. Finally we demonstrate how to transform this specifiaction into operational software with Cucumber. It is a tool that took the Ruby community by storm and is also availabe for Java as well. We transform scenarios described in natural language into automated acceptance tests and share our practical experiences an pitfalls we identified.

title: Let DevOps Drive Architecture
summary:
Let me tell you a story of a social game running at Facebook: First it was small and everything was nice. Then it grew to epic proportions with millions of daily users and things were not so nice anymore.

When you have to handle 100,000 database writes / second the only thing that matters is if you can scale the system far enough and if you can still operate it afterwards.

Things we did included the automation of everything in a cloud setup, a migration from a relational database to a NoSQL database without downtimes and now even removing most of the central databases to migrate from a stateless application server architecture to using stateful servers - again without downtimes. And by the way, all this was done by just two developers and no extra administrators.

Want to know more? Come to the talk!

author.speakingReferences:
I spoke at some major conferences during the last year or so:
- RailsConf 2011, Baltimore
- EuRuKo 2011, Berlin
- SPLASH 2011, Portland
- QCon 2012, London
- Jax 2012, Mainz
- Webinale 2012, Berlin

Videos of two of my talks are available at InfoQ at http://bit.ly/infoq-jesper . I also regularly speak at smaller events like Amazon's or local user groups.

I have been to Devoxx (or Javapolis) multiple times in the past and I liked it very much. Thus I would like to give something back and deliver this talk.

Please note that the game I would like to talk about started out in Ruby and is now running in JRuby, so this is not a pure Java story. But I did a similar talk at Jax in April (http://slidesha.re/M90LNX) and it was very well received by the pure Java audience.
author.speakerBio: Jesper Richter-Reichhelm is working as Head of Engineering at Wooga where he is responsible for the development of backends. Currently Wooga has 40 million monthly users making it the world's 3rd biggest developer of social games at Facebook.

title: Is JEE development still painful ?
summary:
Whether you like it or loath it, Java the language and Java the platform have set the standard for enterprise computing for over a decade and don't look like giving up that top spot for a while yet. However, we continue to hear complaints about the complexity of developing applications with JEE. Various frameworks sprang up over the years to try to simplify the lives of JEE developers (Seam,Spring,...) and with the advent of Java Enterprise Edition 6, we are starting to see a renaissance. So the question deserved to be asked : is JEE still as painful as it was rumored to be ?

Therefore, we'll look at what has happened in the last few years that have already increased the productivity of enterprise Java development, such as CDI. We'll illustrate some of this with the new release of the JBoss  AS7, which is a full EE6 compliant application server and yet is fast, modular and lightweight. And also mention some Open Source advancement that may make their way into the standards.

title: Connect ALM tools thanks to the Open Services for Lifecycle Collaboration specification
summary:
The overall acceptance of ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) platforms is growing slowly. A likely barrier to take-up is their limited tool interoperability. Currently, each ALM platform vendor predetermines a list of tools with which its ALM platform connects. Unfortunately, connecting new tools often requires integration effort. The Open Services for Lifecycle Collaboration specification (OSLC) is changing the game. If a tool provides an API compliant with the OSLC specification, it will then seamlessly integrate with OSLC-compliant ALM platforms. Few commercial ALM platforms currently implement the OSLC specifications, but a growing number of tools are now proposing OSLC compliant API.
After a presentation of the current ALM platforms situation, a review of ALM tools is presented. Subsequently, a several queries where data from different tools are aggregated are used to demonstrate the power of OSLC. Finally, the talk concludes on the perspective and challenges of ALM platforms of the future.

title: Putting some SQL in NoSQL: The Cassandra Query Language
summary:
Apache Cassandra is a distributed datastore designed for handling huge amount
of data on commodity hardware and is one of the leader NoSQL solution. Recent
versions have introduced a new API: the Cassandra Query Language (CQL). That
CQL sounds a lot like SQL is no accident, CQL is an SQL-alike query language.
This talk will cover the motivation behind CQL and in particular behind its
last incarnation dubbed CQL3. Through examples, we will present the language
and explain a number of data modeling principle in Cassandra.

database working at Datastax. Previously, he worked at Yakaz, a real-time
classified ads web service, where he developed the storage infrastructure built
on Cassandra. He holds a Ph.D in Computer Science from the University of Paris 7.

title: Simple Build Tool in practice
summary:
sbt is the de-facto standard build tool for Scala projects, and is also the engine behind Play builds.   sbt offers the full power of scala as well as a rich set of libraries to use for defining your own builds.  

This talk covers the basics of interacting with sbt/play builds and moves swiftly into adapting build workflows for your projects.   sbt encourages a very interactive build process, and this can be leveraged to great effect in standard builds.

The talk finishes discussing deployment strategies for projects.   sbt excels at taking a set of loosely affiliate projects and bundling a deployable artifact.  With the migration away from standard J2EE container based deployment, these kinds of deployments are becoming more common.

Outline:
* Introduction
* A simple play project
* Adding a backend project
* Debugging build issues
* integration testing
* Deployment

title: A web development runtime platform based on the wiki paradigm
summary:
When developing a web application, the traditional way is to develop the application from scratch using a general purpose language such as PHP, Grails, Play, Java/JSP, etc. 

This presentation will show that a next generation wiki (examples based on XWiki: http://xwiki.org) can be used as a web development platform to develop applications on top of it, providing a strong  infrastructure scaffolding to building web applications.

The advantages are similar to those of using an application sever. However whereas an application server offers technical services only, a wiki platform offers higher level services such as content management, rendering, storage, WYSIWYGeditor, user management, and a lot more.

Not only are these services offered, you can develop using them in your traditional IDE or in the runtime, directly in wiki pages. This allows developing web applications extremely quickly, collaboratively and with a fast turnaround time, which is perfect for adhoc web application development.

Vincent also co-authored 3 books: JUnit in Action , Maven: A Developer's Notebook and Better Builds with Maven. He's a regular speaker at IT and Java conferences and also a member of LesCastCodeurs podcast, a French podcast focusing on news in the Java world at large.

title: Addressing the long tail of applications
summary:
Every day we imagine some new apps we'd love to have: having an application to allow people to submit talks, to register new holiday requests, expense reports, simply get data from one site and combine it with data from another site and display that, etc. This is the long tail of application (see http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Main/SecondGenerationWiki).

However in most cases we just drop the idea and continue with our life because we know it would take days or weeks to be able to develop that quickly before you could reap the benefits.

What if there was a way to have these apps developed and working in just a few minutes!

We'll demonstrate how a next generation wiki platform allows to do just that by using the XWiki open source project as an example (http://xwiki.org).

title: Functional patterns in asynchronous programming
summary:

After acheiving the concurrent nirvana, one is faced with the issue of testing. With a few simple functional abstractions, the same code can be used in both a synchronous and asynchronous manner. In particular, this talk covers:

* Monadic workflows
* Applicative Functors and joined computation
* Essence of Iteration

As seen in the Akka futures library.

title: Ceylon behind the scenes: the making-of of a new programming language
summary:
"We didn't know it was impossible, so we went ahead and did it"

Everybody thinks it's impossible to create a new language, and that used to be true not long ago. Nowadays? It's just damn hard. But also interesting, challenging, fraught with questions, innovation, backtracking and pride when it works out. You can do it for ego, or to make the world a better place.

Ceylon is a new programming language, written to help programmers find inner peace and generally propel mankind into the future with happiness.

Here's story that rarely gets told: how a new programming language goes from wet dream to running programs and saving the world. Well, at least we'll cover the first two points.

Come see why and how Ceylon was created, the technologies used (how on earth do you even write a new language, right?), how all the pieces fit. What the new challenges are.

From scratch to a spec, compilers, IDEs, module repositories. Open-source all the way, we give people a unique glimpse of how we've done it.

title: Depth sounder - Quality management with Sonar
summary:
Quality management in professional software development is a key factor for success. In order to measure and control the quality dynamic and static code analysis is usually applied to support architecture, design, and code reviews.
There is a broad variety of tools existing in the Java domain to help to collect such data. A major problem in using these tools is that there is no consolidated view on the measured value. Additionally the tools sometimes measure the same thing differently, like cyclomatic complexity.
Sonar is an open-source "aggregator tool" which works like an umbrella over a good selection of such analysis tools. It provides consistent configuration of these tools and defines views to give different consolidated views of the measured values.
In the first part of this session an overview of the tool is given. In the second part the ease of setup, configuration, and usage is demonstrated by measuring a project in several iterations.

title: FastOQL - Fast Object Queries for Hibernate
summary: To search for a set of objects or data that satisfy some complex criteria, spanning over many classes and relationships, Hibernate developers use HQL queries. However, it is a well-known problem that complex HQL queries, with many joins across class hierarchies, may perform very poorly, especially if executed on large databases. In such cases, Hibernate developers often escape to native SQL, giving up the object perspective and compactness of queries. Complex SQL queries are, however, cumbersome and difficult to maintain. FastOQL solves this problem by producing optimal SQL queries with a minimal number of joins from object queries. FastOQL is a Java library that compiles OQL (Object Query Language) queries into efficient SQL queries. It is designed to work with Hibernate, as an alternative to its HQL, to address its performance and scalability problems. If the domain model has inheritance hierarchies and/or collections mapped to association tables, FastOQL can bring substantial performance benefits.

title: Event driven for Java and .NET
summary:
Event driven architectures (EDA) provide an high degree of decoupling using an intermediate broker which is responsible to receive messages from producers and to forward these to the appropriate consumers. The Enterprise Integration patterns describe an pattern language to design EDA based systems.
Apache Camel implements this pattern language and Apache ActiveMQ offers the possibility to integrate .Net message producers and consumers directly using NMS.
This session shows how to design such an architecture in an heterogenous environment using Apache Camel and ActiveMQ NMS. Addtionally, we will look at alternative frameworks and tools to implement connectivity in such heterogeneous setups.

title: Measuring performance and capacity planning in Java-based data grids
summary: Measuring your data grid's performance it's not a trivial task. In this presentation, Mircea Markus will introduce project Radargun: a benchmarking framework that helps measuring the performance and throughput of in-memory data grids. Radargun offers an simple and effective way to compare how various data grid products would behave based on a specific use case helping you to chose the one that fits your need. It also makes it a great tool setting up a prototyping your data-grid based application in a matter of minutes.

title: JNAerator & BridJ: use native libraries from Java without loosing your temper!
summary:
The NativeLibs4Java project aims at realizing a dream: using a native library from Java ought to be as simple as putting it in the classpath.
That slightly utopic goal led to the development of JNAerator, which converts C / C++ / Objective-C headers to Java, and BridJ, a recent alternative to JNA that deals with the runtime aspect of native interoperability and even allows to derive C++ classes from Java, without compiling any extra native glue!

The first part of this talk will cover the concept and architecture of BridJ and JNAerator, detailing some of the challenges of dynamic native interoperability. During the second part, we'll go through a step-by-step demo on how to convert a popular native library into a self-contained cross-platform JAR, and how to use it efficiently.

title: Web Application Security; keeping them hackers out.
summary:
Security is everywhere… or is it?

Just recently we had to change our LinkedIn passwords. But we have seen SQL injection attacks on the MySQL developers forum and the embarrassing loss of customer data of Sony’s Playstation network due to very low to non-existing security levels. Sometimes attacks are very sophisticated but most of the time somebody just left the door open. 

But there are many things developers can do to prevent at least some of these attacks. This presentation will give a live demo to show how hackers can abuse common attacks like Cross Site Scripting, Cross Site Request Forgery and Session Hijacking to break their way in. 

After that I will show how you can use OWASP ZAP proxy to test you own websites to find security vulnerabilities. This Open Source tool is available free of charge and can easily be configured to automatically report security holes in your website. 

Last but not least this presentation shows how you must protect your passwords once they have been lost.

title: Building Mobile Applications with NoSQL
summary:
We are in the post-PC era – more mobile computing devices (smartphones, tablets) ship per quarter than PC’s, and have since the fourth quarter of 2010*. Mobile devices are where we gather and consume information with increasing frequency, but the cloud is where that information will be aggregated, analyzed and enriched. NoSQL databases are ideal for the cloud-side data management needs of mobile applications, powering some of the most successful and widely used mobile apps, including the recent hit Draw Something by OMGPOP which reached 50 million downloads in 50 days.

In this talk, attendees will learn about:

    The rapidly evolving mobile landscape
    Why a NoSQL database may be the best fit for your application
    Mobile use cases from real-world deployments

title: Natural Order of Refactoring
summary: Refactoring techniques have been widely explored.But when we notice that these techniques are actually transformations a chunk of the source code from one stage into another one.We come up against some problems. 1:some refactorings take a time;2:it is impossible to a developer to spend all his weekly time on refactoring.3:we usually have more than one refactorings started at the same time. Our source code changes. It is always in the PROCESS.This process we call Natural Order of Refactoring – a mental model, which help to answer most critical questions: What stage my source code is really on? Which refactoring technique causes most valuable change? How to refactor step by step in small chunks? Major benefits are:1:programming and refactoring are no more seen as two separate skills or techniques; these are two sides of the same coin – sides of the NOR process;2:code development is controlled by well-defined process;3:a developer has clear criteria how to move his solution from one process stage to the next one

title: Gradle Fireworks
summary: After several years of development, Gradle 1.0 has been released. During the presentation, we will celebrate this mighty, general-purpose build tool by showing you a firework of innovative and long sought-after features. We will demonstrate lightning-fast incremental builds, fully self-contained builds that can be easily shared within a team, how to easily deal with large multi-project builds, how to avoid external dependencies hell when working with multiple repositories and how you can enable standards across your enterprise. We will also demonstrate goodies like the very expressive Gradle DSL, the hard-working Gradle Daemon, and the deep Ant and Maven integration. The presentation includes many live-coding examples taken from real-world scenarios. Finally, you will learn about how Gradle will continue to innovate and we will show you some of the latest Gradle post-1.0 features. Come and see for yourself, why Gradle is already the build tool of choice for many enterprises and open source projects.

title: Gradle
summary:
After several years of development, Gradle 1.0 has been released. During the University presentation, we will introduce the audience to the concepts and application of Gradle through many real-world examples. First, we get familiar with the Gradle basics like tasks, dependencies, plugins, and declarative build configuration. We then move on to more advanced topics like custom tasks, incremental builds, multi-project builds, partial builds, Ant and Maven integration, and custom extensions to the Gradle build language. We also cover some of the innovative goodies that come with Gradle out-of-the-box, like the Gradle Daemon and the Gradle Wrapper.

By the end of the University presentation, the participants understand the powerful concepts of Gradle and how they help to elegantly solve the challenges that we face in our daily enterprise builds.

title: The Making of a Platformer Game with HTML5 Canvas
summary:
Hardware accelerated HTML5 Canvas has arrived! Recent releases of Chrome, iOS5, and Apple's Safari on Lion all have hardware accelerated Canvas, and it makes a huge difference in performance.

Hardware accelerated Canvas makes it possible to implement full-featured video games that run smoothly, not only in desktop browsers, but on tablets as well.

This session shows you how to implement a platformer video game (ala Mario Bros.), complete with scrolling background, parallax, sprites, collision detection, explosions, and special effects, that runs at a rock solid 60 frames/second. On an iPad. You will see how to:

Use Canvas to draw shapes and images
Implement smooth animations with requestAnimationFrame()
Scroll backgrounds with parallax for a 3D effect
Implement and manipulate sprites
Detect and react to collisions
Use tweening effects, such as ease-in, to simulate natural movement
Find freely available spritesheets, backgrounds, and sounds for your games
