author.speakerBio:
David Geary is the author of Core HTML5 Canvas to be published by Prentice-Hall in April, 2012.

David is a prolific, passionate, and entertaining public speaker. He has spoken at hundreds of conferences worldwide, including JavaOne, StrangeLoop, The Server-side Symposium, Devoxx, and JAOO. David was a regular speaker for six years on the No Fluff Just Stuff tour, averaging five 90-minute sessions at more than 120 conferences. David is a three-time JavaOne Rock Star.

David has written eight Java books, four of which are best-sellers in their respective categories, including one of the best-selling technical book series of all time: Graphic Java. David has also written numerous articles for several online publications such as JavaWorld and IBM Developerworks. David's three-article series on Developerworks covering JSF alone has had nearly 500,000 views -- and 275 five-star reviews.

After leaving Sun Microsystems in 1997 to start his own company, David helped define server-side Java technology by serving on the JavaServer Pages Standard Tag Library, JavaServer Faces (JSF) 2.0 Expert Groups at Sun. David is the co-author of the best-selling Core JavaServer Faces, and was one of a handful of experts selected by Sun to write questions for Sun's Web Developer Certification Exam.

David has also contributed to the open source community. He was the second Struts committer, and he invented the Struts Template library which was the precursor to Tiles, a popular framework for composing web pages from JSP fragments. David was also a committer on the Apache Shale project.

title: The Evolution of Java Persistence
summary: The data access requirements of today’s Java applications keep expanding and have grown to include features such as tenant data isolation for cloud deployment, extensible models to support per tenant customization, JSON binding for RESTful web services, the ability to store Java objects in NoSQL databases and more. EclipseLink is well known as an object-relational mapping framework and as the JPA 2.0 reference implementation in Java EE 6, but it continues to evolve and now provides a comprehensive set of data services for Java developers building enterprise and cloud applications in Java EE and SE.  In this session we’ll dive into these new services and build an application that goes from mobile device to back end storage leveraging EclipseLink both in the back end for data persistence and on the front end for JSON over REST to support HTML5 clients.

author.speakingReferences: JavaPolis/Devoxx, JavaOne, SpringOne, JAX/JAX London/JAX Asia/JAX Conference, EclipseCon, Eclipse Summit Europe, and many others
author.speakerBio: Shaun Smith is an active member of the Eclipse community and a Product Manager for Oracle TopLink. He's Ecosystem Development Lead for the EclipseLink project and a committer on the Eclipse Gemini Enterprise Modules, and the Dali Java Persistence Tools projects. Prior to joining Oracle Shaun was a consultant specializing in enterprise application architecture and agile software development. He's been involved with object persistence since 1996 starting with TopLink for Smalltalk and it's successor TopLink for Java. He's currently working on JPA for NoSQL databases, leveraging EclipseLink JPA and MOXy (JAXB and JSON binding) to accelerate the development of data services for HTML5 applications, and Oracle TopLink Grid which supports the scaling out of EclipseLink JPA applications using Oracle Coherence.

title: Creating Cross-Platform Games with PlayN
summary: One of the main promises of Java was write once, run anywhere. PlayN is a 2D game library that delivers on this promise. PlayN uses a pluggable architecture to allowing you to write core code and have the library let the library intelligently resolve the commands on the target platform. With the same codebase, you can create games for desktop Java, HTML5, Android, iOS, and Flash. In this session, we will learn how to setup and create a PlayN project and deploy it to various platforms.

summary:
Static is the new dynamic. With the ever increasing capabilities of HTML5-based browsers, we can give the server a rest and put security problems behind us by publishing static HTML5 documents and shifting the dynamic behavior to the client. Not only does that let you blog out of static hosting sites like GitHub pages, it also means you can put more processing power into the author tools.

In this session, you'll be introduced to Awestruct, a Ruby-based tool for building and publishing static websites. You'll discover how you can leverage a wide range of lightweight markup languages such as HAML, Textile, Markdown, SASS and CoffeeScript to keep your source terse and DRY. We'll use Awestruct's extension pipeline to setup a blog, add comments to your site or add analytic tracking scripts to your pages, then build and publish the site to github pages in a single command. Just because the pages are static doesn't mean they can't be dynamic too.

Dan is an open source advocate, community catalyst, author and speaker. He proudly pursues these passions as a Red Hat employee and community member. In his role as Principal Software Engineer, he serves as the Arquillian community manager and draws on that experience to help make a variety of open source projects wildly successful, including Arquillian, Awestruct, Asciidoctor, JBoss Forge and CDI.

Dan is the author of Seam in Action (Manning, 2008), has written articles for IBM developerWorks, NFJS magazine, Java Tech Journal and JAXenter and is an internationally recognized speaker. He has presented at major software conferences including JavaOne, Devoxx, NFJS, UberConf, RWX, JAX and Jazoon and has been recognized as a JavaOne Rock Star, JBossWorld Top Presenter and JAX Hall of Fame speaker.

title: Drop the angled brackets. Write (Ascii)Docs with pleasure!
summary:
Writing documentation is already hard enough. Why do we make it more difficult by burying the content in an XML syntax like DocBook or wrestling with finicky WSYWIG editors?

What if you could just write? Forget about the layout and styling and just let the thoughts flow? That's the idea behind the lightweight markup languages such as AsciiDoc. With AsciiDoc, the bulk of document is the content, embellished with subtle and intuitive semantic notations. AsciiDoc is designed for humans, yet machine parsable. It can even meet the most advanced publishing requirements.

Come learn how to write documentation with pleasure using AsciiDoc and still be able to produce beautiful HTML, DocBook and PDF documents--and even presentation slides! Like this one.

title: How to use MQTT to connect the physical world to the digital world ?
summary:
SUBMITTED ON BEHALF OFF DAVE LOCKE:
MQTT is a light weight open event oriented (pub sub) protocol designed to connect "things at the edge of the network" to other things. It has been used in many weird and wacky projects from a household mouse trap monitor all the way up to a large scale smart grid project and more recently has been used in a number of smart phone projects. This presentation will provide an overview of MQTT and its history, show how to use MQTT using the open source in the Eclipse Paho project as well as talking about some real world examples of its use

Although JavaFX 2 includes many UI controls, there is often a need to write your own. This session walks you through the options that are available to you and demonstrates how to go about building a custom UI control for your needs.

title: Building Modular Applications with Enterprise OSGi
summary:
Every Java EE developer is familiar with WAR files and Servlets, and most are familiar with Spring and dependency injection. Those who have used these two technologies together are also painfully aware of how hard it can be to manage the class path and class loaders of their application as they add more library JARs.

OSGi offers the perfect modularity solution for this “class path hell”, but few developers are aware that you can use WARs and dependency injection within an OSGi framework.

Moving Java EE applications to an OSGi stack is as easy as possible. In this session we will discuss the basics of the OSGi modularity model, and demo the build tools, middleware, and architectural principles which can be used to turn a chunky WAR into a lean, mean, extensible OSGi web application ! 

Whilst his session is primarily aimed at enterprise developers new to OSGi, much of the content is equally applicable to OSGi development, and is recommended to anyone looking to brush up on their OSGi principles

She is a co-author of Enterprise OSGi in Action and has spoken at Devoxx, JavaZone, The ServerSide Java Symposium, JAX London, GeeCon, and the Great Indian Developer Summit, as well as a number of user groups.

title: JSR 352: Batch applications for the Java Platform.
summary: Batch processing is a pervasive workload pattern across virtually every industry,  applied to such tasks as statement generation, bank postings, risk evaluation, credit score calculation, inventory management, portfolio optimization, and on and on. However, there is no industry standard for a Java batch architecture, at least until now. JSR 352 defines a standard programming model on Java SE and EE to build batch applications and submit/manage Java batch jobs.

author.speakerBio: Sajan Sankaran is a Batch Architect at IBM working on IBM WebSphere Application Server. Sajan has been leading the enterprise Java batch work in IBM for over 7 years. Prior to that he was leading the caching function in IBM WebSphere Application Server for 4 years.

title: Concurrent Programming Using The Disruptor
summary:
The Disruptor is an open source concurrent programming framework developed by LMAX, a financial exchange based in London.

The most interesting thing about it is how the Disruptor has promoted discussions about approaches to writing high performance code, and shown that Java is a serious contender in this space.

Contrary to the current trend of hiding multi-threaded concerns behind languages or frameworks, the Disruptor provides a way to do quite the opposite - to enable developers to think about how to parallelise their architecture in a straightforward and easy to code fashion.  In this workshop, Trisha Gee from LMAX will show examples of how to use the Disruptor to share data between threads, and walk you through how to create your own application using the Disruptor.

author.speakerBio: Trisha is a developer at 10gen (the MongoDB company).  She has expertise in Java high performance systems, is passionate about enabling developer productivity, and has a wide breadth of industry experience from the 12 years she's been a professional developer.  Trisha is a leader in the London Java Community, and involved in the Graduate Development Community, she believes we shouldn't all have to make the same mistakes again and again.
author.name: Trisha Gee

title: Why Open Source Your Secrets
summary:
As a business, it’s easy to see the benefits of using open source code - mostly because it’s free.  However, it’s often much more difficult to make a case for open sourcing code from your own money-making product or service.

This session gives three good business reasons for exposing your secrets to the outside world by open sourcing parts of your code base, and makes the case for giving back to the community as well as just utilising it.
wikiPageName: Why Open Source Your Secrets
wikiTitle: Why Open Source Your Secrets
smallTitle: Why Open Source Your Secrets by Trisha Gee

title: Making sure you don’t work with idiots: A guide to hiring great developers
summary:
This is a session aimed at Developers - don’t leave recruitment to HR!  If you want to work with real talent that you can learn from, or even just enjoy coding with colleagues, you need to get involved in the hiring process.  You’re the only person who can say if the candidate is bright enough, experienced enough, and good enough for you to work with.

Recruiting developers is tricky.  The best developers are often headhunted before they even write their CV; it’s very hard to figure out a person’s real technical ability before they start on the team; and many organisations drastically underestimate the importance of cultural fit.

In this session we’ll share our experiences in doubling the size of the development team, going from 12 developers to 24 in less than a year.  We’ll cover:
 - Places to look for good developers
 - How to attract them to your organisation
 - The interview process

We’ll give solid examples of things we’ve done to make our lives easier, and lessons we learnt the hard way.
wikiPageName: Making sure you don’t work with idiots  A guide to hiring great developers
wikiTitle: Making sure you don’t work with idiots  A guide to hiring great developers
smallTitle: Making sure you don’t work with idiots: A guide to hiring great developers by Trisha Gee

title: Agile ++: When Agile Goes Well
summary:
LMAX might be famous for having created one of the fastest intra-thread messaging frameworks around.  You might even know that we literally wrote the book on Continuous Delivery.  But none of that answers the question of how we actually do what we do.

Agile from the beginning, the technology team took a lot of ideas from places like ThoughtWorks and grew, adapted and changed them until they became a hybrid monster of agile.  And guess what?  It actually works.

We’ll talk you through the agile processes and tools we use; we’ll cover how we got to where we are today; we’ll give examples of what does and does not work for us, and we’ll show how agile has spread well beyond the technology team and into the whole business.

This session is for anyone interested in agile methodologies.  It shows:
 - What a dedicated investment in agile can give your organisation
 - How you can evolve your current agile processes
 - What challenges still face those who are “doing agile” effectively.
wikiPageName: Agile ++  When Agile Goes Well
wikiTitle: Agile ++  When Agile Goes Well

This session will show the latest features of the HTML5 platform with simple code examples which are applicable to real world problems. 
There will be demos of features like file system access, media streaming, multimedia, bleeding edge css and the new websockets.

These frameworks have become the standard for building mobile apps with GWT.

title: Unleash Vaadin with Google & Co
summary:
Vaadin is by now one of the most popular frameworks to build rich internet applications. Based on Google Webtoolkit it provides an easy way to build stunning web applications with java. 
Its simple component based Java API makes it easy to get in touch with, especially by neglecting the usual struggle with html-templates, cascading-stylesheets, hacking java script etc, which most java developers aren’t quite familiar with. Just pure java code which reminds a bit of programming swing, but this time the outcoming application is on the web with just a few clicks.

But this approach also has it pitfalls. Although it seems to be quite easy in the beginning, writing sustainable code relying on reusable components can get quite challenging as the code base grows over time. During this session we want to present you a way to get this done by applying dependency injection with Google Guice and an Google Guava Libraries in order to create an application based loosely coupled components.

title: mgwt - GWT goes mobile
summary:
Building mobile apps and webpages with mgwt & gwt-phonegap is a great way to build cross platform mobile apps in Java. Especially porting your existing GWT apps becomes incredibly easy.
With Phonegap you can build cross platform apps based on web standards. This can be done with Javascript. GWT on the other hand is an excellent tool for building fast Javascript apps in Java, but it is missing some key parts for building great mobile apps with it. The two open source projects mgwt and gwt-phonegap close this gap: mgwt provides mobile widgets, that look like native widgets for different platforms - gwt-phonegap enables GWT apps to use Phonegap. 
Putting these frameworks to work creates performant mobile apps that feel like native apps while being platform independent.

title: GWT - no speed limits for web development
summary:
GWT is one of the great web frameworks and has had a tremendous effect since it started in 2006. Writing efficient Javascript apps with GWT has never been easier since the GWT 2.5 release offers so many new great things like Elementals, Super Dev Mode, massive compiler improvements and UiBinder Templates.
This session will take you through a journey of GWT past, present and future and will also shed some light on the future development process of GWT and the latest releases.
Using a compiler to write Javascript apps seems unusual at first, but it offers an amazing source of performance gain. This talk will show many of the GWT Compiler tricks that make GWT apps so fast.

title: Restful Objects: a hypermedia API for domain object models
summary:
REST architectures are becoming increasingly more common, both on the internet and within the enterprise. Behind most of these REST APIs is a domain model; the wiring up of that REST API to the model typically involves lots of boilerplate and lots of testing.  Sometimes there is a separate resource model in front of the domain model.

Restful Objects is a specification that describes how to expose any domain model - with or without a separate resource model - over REST. It documents a set of HTTP URL resources and the corresponding JSON representations that they support; and it fully supports the stuff that REST-heads care about: HATEOAS, media types, link rels, conneg, HTTP headers, response codes etc.

Restful Objects isn't just a specification though: there are also two separate open source implementations, one for JVM, the other on .NET.

In this talk, Dan will explain some of the ideas behind the spec, and will show how you can use it to REST-enable an app in a matter of minutes.

author.speakerBio:
Dan is a freelance consultant, developer, writer and trainer, specializing in domain-driven design, agile development, enterprise architecture and also REST on the Java and .NET platforms. He's a well-known advocate of Naked Objects, and was instrumental in the success of the first large-scale Naked Objects system which administers state benefits for citizens in Ireland. He continues in his role there as an advisor to the government.

Dan is a leading committer on the Apache Isis project, being an amalgam of the original Naked Objects Java framework and a number of sister open source projects that he wrote for his book, Domain-Driven Design using Naked Objects (pragprog, 2009).  Dan spends much of his remaining time building enterprise apps that use Apache Isis as their platform.

His most recent open source work is the Restful Objects specification, which defines a hypermedia API for exposing domain object models. Apache Isis provides one implementation of this spec, and Dan is also a committer on Restful Objects.NET, an implementation for .NET on ASP.NET MVC.

Dan is a regular presenter at various conferences, and has written a good number of online and print articles. As well as the DDD book, he's written a couple of previous books too, including “Better Software Faster” on the effective use of TogetherJ.

title: Extreme Performance and Scalability with Infinispan Near Caches
summary: The aim of near caching is to provide a bridge between fast, in-memory, local caching and remote, massively scalable, Data Grids in such way that most recently or most frequently accessed data is quickly available while at the same time, clients still being able to transparently and seamlessly access the remote Data Grid when needed. Due to zero latency access provided for local data and the scalability offered by the possibility of going to a remote Data Grid, it's no wonder that this is one of the most demanded Infinispan patterns. In this talk, Galder will offer a detailed view of the pattern with a look at best practices for deploying it in your own environment. The talk will finish with a demo showing near caching in action!

title: The JBoss Polyglot Revolution - Be part of it!
summary: In this talk, Galder will look at the evolution of JBoss, from a producer of java based middleware, to the current expansion towards multi-language platforms. How did Torquebox come about? Why are we creating Ceylon? What is Escalante? What is Immutant? This and many other questions will be answered in this informal chat that will not only look into the motivations behind building middleware in other languages, but will also discuss the technological advances that have this expansion possible. During this presentation the audience will get invaluable feedback on the lessons learnt while developing with other languages, pitfalls of the different languages used, tips of learning new languages...etc, giving them first-hand advice that they will be able to apply in their work environments. Finally, the talk will finish with information on how join and contribute to the JBoss Polyglot Revolution!

summary: Escalante is an application server for Scala built on top of JBoss Application Server 7. In this talk, Escalante founder and project lead Galder Zamarreño explains the motivations behind building Escalante as well as stressing that Escalante's aim is to encompass all Scala technologies. Whether you are Lift or Play developer, Escalante offers a speedy, lean environment for developing and deploying Scala applications, and crucially it integrates with JBoss Developer Studio to increase developer productivity, and OpenShift for scalable, cloud, deployment. The talk will include a demo showing Escalante in action via JBoss Developer Studio deploying to OpenShift.

title: mobile apps are a dead-end
summary:
mobile apps have had a tremendous success and everyone still believes in their future. But if you take a look back at the fight desktop vs. web apps you can spot the similarities. 
Mobile apps are an intermediate step while we are waiting for the mobile web to happen. The web already has won on the desktop and it will establish itself as the primary source of software for mobile devices eventually.
This talk will take a look at the past and will try to give a clear view of what is ahead for mobile software development and will introduce you to a future-proven way of building your mobile apps with phonegap.

title: Miko, or how to write a JVM in JavaScript
summary:
What does it take to load and run Java class files in the browser?
Miko has come a long way so far, supporting a large part of the JRE, including reflection, multi-threading, and regular expressions. Since it runs class files it can handle Scala or Clojure programs just the same.
Learn the ins and outs of Java bytecode interpreting, and how to do all that in JavaScript, stretching the limits of what's possible in the browser. Oh, and don't forget to bring your iPad.

title: Finding the Higgs boson… and a suitable web development framework at CERN
summary:
Finding the Higgs is far from trivial… but in some sense, so is finding a suitable Web application framework!
Faced with the challenge of the many different technologies and development practices used to build applications for the world’s largest particle physics laboratory, we explain how our team at CERN implemented a framework based on Groovy/Grails + GWT/GXT technologies. We will describe our ecosystem of newly developed plugins, components and HTML5 widgets, and show how this helped to create a seamlessly integrated framework. We will go on to show how this harmonized our development processes and infrastructure.
 
To illustrate the framework, two major tools developed with the framework will be shown, the first allows CERN management to align competencies with the future challenges of the Organization and the second tool coordinates the work of over 4.000 specialists as they prepare the LHC for the next generation of physics at CERN.
 
Some analogies with the Higgs boson quest will be made...

author.speakingReferences: Several talks about Groovy/Grails/Java ecosystem at knowledge exchange meetings within CERN.
author.speakerBio:
Enthusiastic Java developer working for the “Advanced Information Systems” group at the European Organization for Nuclear Research.
Quick to grasp new ideas and concepts and to develop innovative and creative solutions to
problems.

title: What makes your web app screamingly fast
summary:
Users expect web apps to be fast and responsive. We as developers need to be able to build a user experience that does not fall short. Performance is not just a marginal side effect, it is a major feature.
This talk will show statistics on how bad performance affects the traffic to your site. It will also teach you how to build sites that are incredibly fast by using many different techniques based on small code examples. It will deal with asynchronous loading of scripts, page reflows, CSS layouting and many more exciting possibilities in the browser.
Sometimes finding the performance drain is one of the most important jobs of a developer. By introducing different tools this talk will help you to find yours.
wikiPageName: What makes your web app screamingly fast
wikiTitle: What makes your web app screamingly fast
smallTitle: What makes your web app screamingly fast by Daniel Kurka

title: HTML5 WebSocket and Java
summary: The family of HTML5 technologies has pushed the pendulum away from rich client technologies and toward ever-more-capable Web clients running on today’s browsers. In particular, WebSocket brings new opportunities for efficient peer-to-peer communication, providing the basis for a new generation of interactive and “live” Web applications. This session examines the efforts under way to support WebSocket in the Java programming model, from its base-level integration in the Java Servlet and Java EE containers to a new, easy-to-use API and toolset that are destined to become part of the standard Java platform.
wikiPageName: HTML5 WebSocket and Java
wikiTitle: HTML5 WebSocket and Java
smallTitle: HTML5 WebSocket and Java by Arun Gupta

title: Developing JAX-RS Web Applications Utilizing Server-Sent Events and WebSockets
summary:
This hands-on lab guides attendees through building a Web application with the new JAX-RS 2.0 API. It shows how to use some value-added features of Jersey (the open source JAX-RS reference implementation) and Tyrus (the early draft implementation of Java API for WebSocket [JSR 356]) for leveraging HTML5 technologies such as server-sent events and WebSocket.

As part of the lab attendees will work on a single web application and a programmatic client. It will be split into 3 exercises: 1) Building a web application using JAX-RS - attendees will learn some of the new concepts in JAX-RS 2.0 and use them for building the web application (using pre-loaded code snippets) 2) Adding SSE and WebSocket support to the web application - attendees will learn how to extend the existing web application with bi-directional communication between the server and the client  3) Building a simple client - the attendees will learn the new JAX-RS 2.0 client api as well as the client-part of web socket and SSE support in Jersey.
wikiPageName: Developing JAX-RS Web Applications Utilizing Server-Sent Events and WebSockets
wikiTitle: Developing JAX-RS Web Applications Utilizing Server-Sent Events and WebSockets
smallTitle: Developing JAX-RS Web Applications Utilizing Server-Sent Events and WebSockets by Marek Potociar

title: What’s New in Java Message Service 2.0
summary: JMS is the Java standard for accessing enterprise messaging systems. This session introduces JMS 2.0 (JSR 343), the first update in more than a decade and easily the longest-awaited component of the forthcoming Java EE 7 standard. The biggest new feature of JMS 2.0 is a new API that makes JMS much easier to use, especially in a Java EE application. JMS 2.0 also provides API features to support greater scalability as well as additional messaging features, changes to support PaaS and Saas deployment, and a long list of minor enhancements and clarifications. With JMS 2.0 entering its public draft review stage, now is an ideal time to find out more about it and give your views.

We will demonstrate how the open source GraniteDS project can help bridging the gap between the different concepts and technologies of these two frameworks, for example how you can use JavaFX data binding with JPA entities or Bean Validation in a JavaFX client. We will also show how easily you can implement advanced features such as real-time messaging using websockets.

title: Deep dive into invokedynamic
summary:
￼￼A step-by-step introduction to the least visible yet most profound improvement brought by Java 7: the introduction of the invokedynamic instruction in the JVM: origins, rationale, approach, potential.

Starting from a reminder about method invocation and method dispatch, we'll briefly survey traditional approaches to implementing dynamic languages on the JVM and we'll discuss their limitations before analysing examples relying on MethodHandle, CallSite, AnonymousClassloader,... and eventually scripting the JVM and performing some calls to invokedynamic.

This talk is for you, even if you haven't (yet) tried Groovy, JRuby or Python on the JVM, even if you are not that much into JavaScript, even if you haven't heard about lambda in Java8. Whatever your level of experience with Java, reflection, code generation or java bytecode, you are guaranteed to learn something!

This talk will be illustrated with examples in Java and in BiteScript.

title: A closer look at closures
summary:
In a recent poll more than 50% of java developers voted that 'closures' will change how they write java code. Programming languages such as Scala, Scheme and Ruby provide direct support for closures.  Closures (or lambda expressions) has now become one of the most sought after features of java 8. Through closures and related features Java 8 aims to support programming in a multicore environment.

Given that today multi-core hardware is default, it is critical to write code that parallelizes gracefully. While fork-and-join introduced in Java 7 is a step closer to extract the benefits of multi-core, it still faces hurdles related to boilerplate code. Closure is designed to eliminate the need for boilerplate code while working with parallel arrays.

Come join us in hands on exploration of this sought after feature, its impact on multi-core programming and associated gains in performance!!

summary:
Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Android*

This talk is collection of various topics that tends to be a popular subject any time Android development is discussed. While some of the methods presented won't be exactly what creators of Android had in mind, the focus is to behave correctly, be reusable and extensible and how to make best of the techniques Java gives us to cope with whatever shortcomings Android might have.

title: Bean Validation 1.1: it's not Beansland anymore
summary:
Bean Validation standardizes constraint declarations and validation for the Java platform.Bean Validation 1.0 has been widely adopted and seamlessly integrated with some other JSRs (like JSF, JPA) and the rich Java framework environment at large.

We will explore what version 1.1 brings to the table and what new features you can expect for your future Java SE or EE applications. We will discuss in an example driven fashion method-level validation, Context and Dependency Injection (CDI) integration and many more new features and improvements.

Come join us to see that Bean Validation is not Beansland anymore.

title: Bridging Objects and Tables with a Database Designed for your ORM
summary:
Use an ORM like Hibernate with a complex schema? You’ve probably had issues scaling your application in production.    Mapping Objects to relational database tables means constantly assembling and disassembling object graphs.  As your schema scales in complexity, this constant activity becomes a significant drag on performance.  

This presentation introduces a new open source database - Akiban Server - built from the ground up as a pure-Java database to work efficiently with ORMs.    The core concept, Table Groups, stores related data together giving your applications a 1:1 mapping between objects and the way data is stored in your database.  This translates to dramatic improvements in performance.  Akiban bridges the RDBMS with more document-oriented databases while preserving the ability to run SQL.  

Specific examples of 10-100x performance improvements will be demonstrated and attendees will learn how they can start using Akiban in existing applications without a costly rewrite.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne 2011, Open Source Bridge 2011 (in Portland, OR), various JUGs.

In addition to writing, Tim has served as a writer and consultant to Sonatype, Inc. writing Maven: The Complete Reference and Maven by Example.   He has been a consultant to Forbes, Inc., Consumer Reports, Scholastic, Inc., and Gleanster in addition to contributing to open source software.

title: Android Desktop Invasion
summary:
There is no doubt that Android and other mobile platforms changed the IT industry forever, with millions of new mobile users every day and more and more developers working on next great mobile application right now. 

The mobile empire is striking again, and this time the motto is "All your desktop are belong to us". Traditional desktop applications of yesterday are going to change forever, being augmented with connected mobile applications that go hand in hand with them.

"Android Desktop Invasion" talk will cover a few examples of such hybrid mobile-desktop applications, highlighting the advantages over existing solutions and explaining how they work behind the scenes.
The talk will have a look at Android as a powerful desktop invasion weapon, including Android as a server, examining HTTP, WiFi, BT and NFC and how they can talk to your desktop, as well as sensors that your mobile device already have and how you can enrich applications running on your PC and simplify the interactions from the desktop.

title: Java Source Code Generation Tools Teaser
summary:
Source code generation has been an interesting topic for quite a long period and many Java source code generation tools have been developed and used through the years. However, only limited information regarding the quality, strengths and drawbacks of such tools exist, and picking the right tool for the right job is not easy.

In this talk, several powerful Java source code generation tools will be presented shortly in action, each of them used with some small, but representative code generation example, showing a typical usage scenario, giving the first impression and teasing the audience. As a summary, the strengths, drawbacks and common applications of the tools will be presented.

The tools selection covers various approaches of modeling and generating Java source code from: UML, MDA, Java annotations, XML, DSLs, console, etc.

author.speakerBio:
Nikolche Mihajlovski is a software engineer who always seeks improvements of the commonly established processes, practices and technologies. He has over 15 years of programming experience in various programming languages, paradigms and technologies, diverging from experimental research and pet projects to massive enterprise applications. His main fields of interest include Programming Languages, Code Generation and Cloud Computing.
Nikolche is the author of JAnnocessor, an innovative technology for annotation-based code generation, as well as RDXPL, an experimental multi-paradigm dynamic programming language. He is an active member of the local Java User Group and becomes a regular speaker at the Java conferences.

title: Continuous Inspection with Sonar - Fight the 7 Deadly Sins of the developer
summary:
The Job of a developer has evolved strongly in the last 10 years, pushed by new requirements and new tools. Software Development Industry has now reached a sufficient level of maturity to engage into a new practice to manage source code quality while running projects : Continuous Inspection.

This practice is supported by Sonar as Continuous Integration is supported by Jenkins. Continuous Inspection enables developer to fight back the temptation of the seven deadly sins of the developer, increasing maintainability of software and thus productivity of the developer.

wikiTitle: Continuous Inspection with Sonar - Fight the 7 Deadly Sins of the developer

title: The Wonderland of Java Source Code Generation
summary:
Source code generation is a powerful concept and many Java source code generation techniques, tools and paradigms have been developed and used through the years. Which modeling approach, code generation technique and tool is the best fit for your current or future project? Let's take a tour through the plenty of them to find the answer...

In this talk we will dive together into the wonderful land of various Java source code generation techniques, tools and practices, discussing various approaches of modeling and generating Java source code from: UML, MDA, Java annotations, XML, DSLs, console, etc. Each approach will be presented with appropriate code generation example, by using a representative tool in real-time, thus showing a typical usage scenario with detailed discussion of the strengths, drawbacks and common applications of the approach.
wikiPageName: The Wonderland of Java Source Code Generation
wikiTitle: The Wonderland of Java Source Code Generation
smallTitle: The Wonderland of Java Source Code Generation by Nikolche Mihajlovski

title: Hands-on Java Social with Agorava and DaliCore
summary:
Following an overview of Social Media support on the Java Platform, this workshop will demonstrate real life use cases for Enterprise Social Media using Java EE and two popular Social Media Frameworks for Java, Agorava Project and DaliCore. 
DaliCore, integrated with the GlassFish ecosystem primarily helps creating Social Content and Private Social Networks for all who wish to go beyond what Facebook, Twitter or Google+ have to offer. You don't have to be a celebrity like Lady Gaga or Justin Timberlake to run your own social portal, with DaliCore anybody can do this in a Java EE container like Glassfish, as we are going to show. 
Agorava Project aims mainly at Social Content integration and connecting different services or APIs from within Java, using the type safe convenient and state of the art techniques like CDI. 
The session will demonstrate also how Agorava and DaliCore can work together, and how both will benefit from upcoming Java Standards like JSR-353 (JSON) or JSR-351, Java Identity API.

Werner Keil is Build Manager at Maersk after working as Agile Coach, Principal Consultant and Distinct Architect for a Financial Services company and emergn, an Agile consultancy specialized in Value, Flow and Quality. Among his earlier clients are Sony where he designed and implemented micro-format based tags its online music portals.

He has worked for more than 22 years as a project manager, software architect, analyst and consultant on leading-edge technologies for Banking, Insurance, Telco/Mobile, Media and Public sector. Werner develops enterprise systems using Java, JEE, Oracle, IBM or Microsoft, does Web design and development using Adobe,Ajax/JavaScript, dynamic or functional languages.

title: Device Recognition with OpenDDR and Apache DeviceMap
summary: There is nothing worse than content not tailored or optimized. Just think how frustrating is surfing a complex website on the small screen of your cellular phone. You waste your time zooming and scrolling the pages, and it becomes clear: if you want a comfortable user experience you need dinamically adaptable contents according to hardware and browser specifications of your device. That’s the reason why W3C Device Description Repositories (DDR) exist. Unlike most commercial or closed source products, OpenDDR is currently the most comprehensive open and free repository of device description available. One of the reasons, it also became the first choice for initial contribution to the upcoming Apache DeviceMap project, the next generation of free, Open Source Device Repository by the Apache Community.
wikiPageName: Device Recognition with OpenDDR and Apache DeviceMap
wikiTitle: Device Recognition with OpenDDR and Apache DeviceMap

title: Tooling Support for Enterprise Development
summary: In this presentation we will cover the tooling support of Java EE applications. One of the challenges of Java EE development is managing your project within an IDE. Most Java EE books talk about the different Java EE packaging schemes but often leave the actual setup to the reader. Setting up a project in an IDE can be a daunting job - you have to configure dependencies as well as create deployment descriptors and get everything packaged correctly. In addition you have to tackle unit tests and integration tests execution. Complicating matters, you must minimize cycle times for the developer so that they don’t spend most of their day waiting on builds. In this presentation we will cover Java EE project support provided by the major IDEs.

Prior to joining DS he worked for a startup distributed-computing company, TurboWorx, and Eastman Kodak's Molecular Imaging Systems group, now part of Carestream Health. title: From the Cloud to the Wall
summary: In this presentation we will dig into the possibilities of running Java EE applications on small ARM based devices. As the iPad has demonstrated, it is now possibly to have extremely compact and powerful systems that sip power with a unique form factor. While all the rage might be putting your application up in the cloud, you can also deploy it to a device the size of a light-timer and plug it in behind your desk. We will examine performance numbers and demonstrate how easy it is to deploy and manage applications on these devices. Perhaps it is time that we moved from the cloud to the wall!
wikiPageName: From the Cloud to the Wall
wikiTitle: From the Cloud to the Wall
smallTitle: From the Cloud to the Wall by Ryan Cuprak

title: The Future of Mobile and Embedded Java towards a Semantic IoT World
summary:
Wouldn't it be cool, if Java was more like Fantom?;-) Less technical aspects like language constructs like closures, traits or semicolons you may leave aside. Fantom among few other languages has first class Units of Measurement support beside a better approach to date and time similar to Joda or JSR-310. While the latter may also help the IoT and Semantic Web, what really matters in M2M communication between Arduino, NAOs or your Coffee machine in the office while you're still at home is a unified precise exchange of measurement values, quantities and their units.
This session is going to demonstrate, how Future Mobile and Embedded Java versions may fit in with the Semantic Web, the Internet of Things and all these great innovative devices, avoiding to turn your Arduino Quadcopter into a Gimli Glider or having your NAO lost in Space like the Mars Rover;-D
Based around the same innovations that fuelled Fantom's Unit support or projects like Unit-API we'll see, how this may work in future versions of Java.
wikiPageName: The Future of Mobile and Embedded Java towards a Semantic IoT World
wikiTitle: The Future of Mobile and Embedded Java towards a Semantic IoT World

title: XACML3. What is it,  and why do I care?
summary:
XACML, eXtensile Access Control Markup Language, is an emerging standard for the expression and evaluation of access control rules.  However, XACML has been largely aimed at large enterprise, and government IT problems, and it is not even clear how relevant XACML is to smaller developers. I will show how as the cloud becomes more and more ubiquitous,  the need to interact with XACML becomes more interesting. 

I will give a short overview of XACML, its history and its form.  Then we will cover the options you have as far as a XACML evaluation engine, of which there are several, both commercial as well as open source.  We will also talk about why it is even important to you, especially if you are not in large enterprise.

I will then cover the work of a group working to build a free, open source, platform independent client api allowing even the smallest developer to be able to leverage XACML.

author.speakingReferences: OSCON 2011, DEVOX 2010, OSCON 2010, OpenSourceDays (Copenhagen 2010) Community ONE 2009, 2008, Confoo 2011

Allan is based in Portland, Oregon in the USA. Allan brings 25 years of experience in the development, internet, and Identity management spaces to ForgeRock. Allan's career has reached from Apple Computer inc, to Netscape, AOL, Guru Associates, and Sun Microsystems before joining the team at ForgeRock.

title: Mobile cross platform development based on PhoneGap an jQuery mobile
summary:
Mobile development has become a big topic in more and more software development projects. But developing for mobile devices means dealing with a number of different operating systems and programming languages.

This talk presents, based on different live examples (Android and iOS), how mobile cross platform development can be done using the HTML5 based application platform PhoneGap and jQuery mobile. In addition the audience will learn how a project setup for a single source, multi platform project can look like.  During the presentation pros and cons of this approach are as well discussed as it's limits.

The audience will get an impression on how HTML 5 based mobile development can look like, how it can ease the approach of different platforms and when it is the right approach (or not).

summary: Using OpenAM, a fully open source Access Management product from Forgerock, we will demonstrate how you can easily integrate your application with major cloud providers.  We will demonstrate how your application can leverage OpenAM to authenticate via Facebook using OAuth2,  Integrate with GoogleApps using SAML2,  and then access resources using OAuth2 authorization tokens.

title: soap-ws - pimp up your architecture with codeless web-services
summary:
Web-Services are everywhere. There is a plethora of WS stacks but most of them follow the paradigm of stubs generation. Handy as it may seem at the beginning, it can be redundant and cumbersome, e.g. one WSDL change triggers full recompilation and redeployment of the app. Problems also appear when many versions of the same service have to be maintained and the trickery that is then applied (postfixing class names, adding version numbers to packages, etc.) does not scale well, causes a rapid code-base growth and is clearly against "best practices". 

soap-ws, authored by me, presents a different approach. It is a lightweight Java Web-Services stack that handles SOAP "codelessly" on a purely XML level. Using soap-ws enables generation, transmission and handling of SOAP messages without the usage of stubs. This session will cover some of the key drawbacks of using code-based SOAP stacks preventing people from following bad practices and offering handy tools to overcome above mentioned problems.

title: Reimagining the Desktop with JavaFX
summary: The conventional thinking in software development and IT over at least the past ten years has been that the web is the future of application development and deployment. iOS and Android have both upended this belief and proved that users want highly interactive and easy to use applications. Desktop Java, with the advent of JavaFX is poised to ride this resurgence in heavyweight clients. In the presentation we will examine JavaFX animation support and the special effects capabilities of JavaFX. You’ll learn how to make a wizard UI exciting, use animation for business data and processes, and provide visual feedback. JavaFX’s animation and scene graph architecture open up new possibilities to make desktop applications exciting. We will look at how and where animation and special effects can be used to improve a desktop application.

title: Introducing PersistIt: Open-source Java, Key-Value Storage that Beats Native Alternatives
summary:
Persistit is a new open source library that provides fast, embeddable, and compact B-Tree library built purely in Java which provides simple key-value storage for any Java application.   Similar in concept to BerkeleyDB, InnoDB, and Kyoto Cabinet DBM, the core use-case is applications that require an extremely fast, in-process storage engine for arbitrary data.   If you need to store, sort, and retrieve data PersistIt provides a pure-Java B-Tree with performance that rivals alternative native implementations.

This presentation focuses on using PersistIt for developing embedded applications, collecting log files, and an example of tracking application data using an in-process B-Tree on a mobile device.  Persistit works like a collection of Java Maps that are persistent, unlimited in size and capable of being shared among many threads. As a persistence product, Persistit offers all the benefits of fast Key-Value storage with the additional advantages of transactional durability and strong crash-recovery.
wikiPageName: Introducing PersistIt  Open-source Java, Key-Value Storage that Beats Native Alternatives
wikiTitle: Introducing PersistIt  Open-source Java, Key-Value Storage that Beats Native Alternatives

title: LDAP and REST working harmoniously together!
summary:
In this demonstration I will use OpenDJ, a fully open source LDAP directory server from Forgerock, to show how LDAP can fit into the REST/ajax world.  Being able to access an LDAP directory using web based REST calls, and having responses returned as JSON objects, you are able to access LDAP directly from a client application, without any special libraries,  protocols or handling.

We will demonstrate a simple web application interacting with the LDAP store via REST, allowing for rich client apps to directly manipulate the LDAP store.
wikiPageName: LDAP and REST working harmoniously together!
wikiTitle: LDAP and REST working harmoniously together!
smallTitle: LDAP and REST working harmoniously together! by Allan Foster

title: Trends in Global Artifact Consumption and the Imperative of Using a Repository Manager
summary:
The Central repository fuels global development providing easy access to an array of artifacts.   In this presentation attendees will see an analysis of traffic showing some of the global trends in consumption.  In this presentation you will see a long-term analysis of the winners and losers over the past two years along with a full exploration of what it takes to run the most important resource in the world for Java developers.   The following categories will be analysed: Web Frameworks, Dependency Injection, Logging, Utilities, Alternative Languages, Build Tools, and other popular categories.

Along with an analysis of general traffic trends from Central - a plea for attendees to start using a repository manager to proxy Central.   This presentation will focus on the imperatives of adopting  a repository manager both to conserve bandwidth on the Central repository and as an attempt to redefine core infrastructure essential to software development.  Repository managers are as essential as source control.
wikiPageName: Trends in Global Artifact Consumption and the Imperative of Using a Repository Manager
wikiTitle: Trends in Global Artifact Consumption and the Imperative of Using a Repository Manager
smallTitle: Trends in Global Artifact Consumption and the Imperative of Using a Repository M... by Tim O'brien

title: Truly automated dependency management for the Eclipse Ecosystem. Finally!
summary:
Are you familiar with the automated dependency management like in Maven or any other fancy tool? You just define a bunch of artifacts and everything happens automagically. It does not, however, work like this for everybody. Dependency management in Eclipse RCP is a bit different. It is caused by two facts: on the one hand RCP is an OSGi environment which extends the Java dependency model, on the other hand there are some awkward RCP conventions. 

In this session I will present how to fully automate dependency management in your Eclipse RCP app. I will show how to bridge the gap between Maven-like and RCP-like dependency management styles so that all Maven features can be seamlessly used without shivering. I am going to introduce p2-maven-plugin, authored by me, which does most of the hard work and serves as the missing piece in the integration between Maven, Tycho and RCP. The session will be concluded with the presentation of a fully-featured Eclipse RCP Ecosystem with Maven, Jenkins and Artifactory.
wikiPageName: Truly automated dependency management for the Eclipse Ecosystem. Finally!
wikiTitle: Truly automated dependency management for the Eclipse Ecosystem. Finally!
smallTitle: Truly automated dependency management for the Eclipse Ecosystem. Finally! by Tom Bujok

title: Developing Enterprise Java in the Cloud
summary:
The often-abused "Cloud" buzzword has become pervasive in enterprise development these days, and given the wealth of technologies now available to us in the Java EE space, it's hard to argue its validity.

We're now at a point where we may fully-automate the deployment and provisioning of publicly-available web applications, and in most cases it's as simple as pushing a commit.

Come to this BOF session to discuss the present state and future of development in a cloud-enabled environment, and learn about the tools available right now.  Representatives from all vendors are welcome on the panel, and the format will be a loosely-structured discussion encouraging participation from attendees.

title: Continuous Enterprise Development: Case Studies in Java EE Integration Testing
summary:
This highly technical session examines solutions for easing the testing of some of the more complex use cases within Java EE. Each example is backed by a runnable test (publicly available to participants), and the presentation covers automated continuous development of:

• The Web user interface (via Selenium)
• Persistent data and JPA
• Transactional boundaries
• Cloud-based deployments
• RESTful endpoints
• More

It showcases various techniques outlined in the book Continuous Enterprise Development in Java, forthcoming from O’Reilly Media, and is delivered by the authors. Expect a lot of proof through open source demos. You'll see the presenters exercise the features of any compliant Java EE 6 runtime, using the Arquillian platform.
wikiPageName: Continuous Enterprise Development  Case Studies in Java EE Integration Testing
wikiTitle: Continuous Enterprise Development  Case Studies in Java EE Integration Testing

title: Protecting Web Services with OAuth
summary:
In this presentation I will cover Web Services and the various methods being used today.  I will then discuss, using real world examples, the issues faced with Web Service Security.

I will discuss the two separate yet similar issues of protecting access to the web services, and protecting access to the resources being accessed.

Using OAuth2 to protect access to Web Services is a lightweight and extensible way to secure web services.  I will demonstrate the various actors in this security, as well as how it might integrate into a more traditional access control environment.

Providing security to the underlying resources is a more traditional access control problem, and can leverage XACML3 to provide the fine grained access control to these objects that is often required.
wikiPageName: Protecting Web Services with OAuth
wikiTitle: Protecting Web Services with OAuth
smallTitle: Protecting Web Services with OAuth by Allan Foster

title: Today’s Rapid Java EE Development: Live Coding from Scratch to Deployment
summary:
The myth of Java EE as a cumbersome platform is easily dispelled in this session, which aims to create a working application, from a blank repository to a live cloud deployment, in real time. It:

• Covers tools that bootstrap project creation, freeing you from mucking around with Maven POM boilerplate
* Generates a domain model and reverse-engineers JPA entities from it
* Automatically creates the scaffolding for tests that run in a real Java EE container, launched from the IDE
* Pushes it all to production on a public site

Using a variety of projects from the JBoss Community adhering to and building upon open standards, this presentation can create real enterprise apps in the time it takes other sessions to click through some slides. Let’s get building!
wikiPageName: Today’s Rapid Java EE Development  Live Coding from Scratch to Deployment
wikiTitle: Today’s Rapid Java EE Development  Live Coding from Scratch to Deployment

title: Introducing The JBoss Developer Framework
summary:
The JBoss Developer Framework provides you with the toolkit to follow the JBoss Way - an approach to building your Java EE applications quickly, productively, and easily. 

Based on the Apache Deltaspike project, the industry standard for portable Java EE 6 extensions, the JBoss Developer Framework provides an excellent platform for building modern, mobile ready, cloud friendly applications. You can use JBoss Forge to create projects in a matter of minutes, and JBoss Developer Studio to craft your changes. 

Will session will show you how to get started with Java EE using the JBoss Developer Framework, and then provide a deep dive into selected components.
wikiPageName: Introducing The JBoss Developer Framework
wikiTitle: Introducing The JBoss Developer Framework
smallTitle: Introducing The JBoss Developer Framework by Andrew Rubinger

title: A Decade of Shipwrecks: The Past, Present, and Future of Builds
summary:
In this presentation, Tim O'Brien gives an overview of build tools from gmake in the late 1990s to Gradle and Maven in 2012.  Instead of focusing on builds, this presentation tries to reset the discussion to focus on requirements rather than features.  What is it that we're looking for from our builds, and why have current approaches failed?

This BOF explores the following questions: What are trends in build tools?   What are the persistent problems?   How many of us are still dissatisfied with the build tools we use and how can we as participants in open source affect positive change? This presentation outlines the remaining problems with builds that are yet to solved and develops a framework to discuss how builds need to evolve going forward.
wikiPageName: A Decade of Shipwrecks  The Past, Present, and Future of Builds
wikiTitle: A Decade of Shipwrecks  The Past, Present, and Future of Builds
smallTitle: A Decade of Shipwrecks: The Past, Present, and Future of Builds by Tim O'brien

title: Acceptance Test Driven Development with Arquillian
summary:
It’s great to have a solid base of unit and integration tests; this gives us confidence about overall system integrity. But at the end of the day it all amounts to whether our end users are happy using our application. So how can keep the fail whale at bay and communicate with the stakeholders that the requirements are being met?

During this talk we will see that the Arquillian ecosystem is way more than just integration testing. We will dive into the concept of ATDD and demonstrate how to build higher-level, end-to-end functional tests; we’ll be emulating user interactions using the Arquillian Drone extension together with the open source browser automation tool WebDriver. Reusable web testing components called Page Objects will make our tests cleaner and easier to maintain. Eventually we will sugar coat them with a Groovy DSL for Behaviour Driven Development to achieve testing nirvana.

If you care about quality of your software you definitely shouldn't miss this talk! Expect to see lots of live demos!
wikiPageName: Acceptance Test Driven Development with Arquillian
wikiTitle: Acceptance Test Driven Development with Arquillian
smallTitle: Acceptance Test Driven Development with Arquillian by Bartosz Majsak

title: What is your ORM doing? (and why it drives your DBAs insane)
summary:
There's some tension between Java developers and DBAs.  With Java developers busily mapping object models to database tables and using ORMs often without considering the impact ORMs have on database performance.   In this presentation Ori Herrnstadt fully explains this conflict and address specific ways in which Java developer and DBAs can work well together.  In this presentation, Ori present several key approaches that will make it easier to scale an application that uses and ORM if employed at the beginning of your application's architecture.

Don't be fooled by the simiplicity of JPA, Hibernate, or MyBatis.  It's easy to work yourself into a corner, and Herrnstadt delivers solid advice to avoid future problems.

author.speakingReferences: Percona Live 2012, MySQLConf 2011
author.speakerBio: Ori Herrnstadt is co-founder and CTO of Akiban. He has been developing large-scale operational database technology for years. After experiencing the common problems of operational systems in the military, SaaS, healthcare, enterprise ERP, CRM systems and modern web applications, he started developing the Orthogonal Architecture. In 2009, he co-founded Akiban Technologies to accelerate the development of the technology into the Akiban Server.
author.name: Ori Herrnstadt

wikiPageName: What is your ORM doing  (and why it drives your DBAs insane)
wikiTitle: What is your ORM doing  (and why it drives your DBAs insane)
smallTitle: What is your ORM doing? (and why it drives your DBAs insane) by Ori Herrnstadt

title: Advanced layouts with CSS
summary:
Rich web applications based on JavaScript, Ajax and CSS forces developers to use web technologies in ways they were not designed to handle. While standards designed with dynamic applications in mind are slowly being adopted, developers must weight learning curve, utility and browser support against each other.

This presentation investigates the current situation with regards to layouting generic UI widgets in web applications. Various CSS3 features are evaluated and compared to older alternatives. Based on constraints from desktop and mobile browsers, three progressive approaches are presented for fully utilizing CSS and then counting pixels and applying inline styles when static CSS is not enough.

Presentation objectives:
1) Show best practices for layouting web applications and reusable components
2) Provide insights into CSS usage in dynamic applications
3) Learn from our experiences from designing the Vaadin RIA framework and numerous applications

author.speakingReferences: None
author.speakerBio: Leif Åstrand, M.Sc., has been building web pages and web applications professionally since 2005. He is currently designing and implementing the next generation of Vaadin, an open source Java-based framework for building business-oriented Rich Internet Applications.
author.name: Leif Åstrand

wikiPageName: Advanced layouts with CSS
wikiTitle: Advanced layouts with CSS
smallTitle: Advanced layouts with CSS by Leif Åstrand

title: How to Scale an Application with Table Groups
summary:
This session introduces participants to the Akiban Server, an open-source pure-Java database that was designed to support ORMs from the ground up.   Starting from a sample application that uses an existing schema, participants will learn how to define Table Groups in an Akiban Server and improve the performance of problematic queries.   Participants will then learn how to query data from the Akiban Server as both documents using a JSON interface and as traditional rows in a relational database.  

The final hour of this Lab focuses on novel forms of query optimization and execution possible by Table Groups including fast reporting systems built atop operational databases that would be otherwise impossible without the benefit of Table Groups. Technologies used in this demonstration will include: Gradle, Eclipse, PersistIt, Hibernate, Spring, and Akiban Server.   Attendees should be a familiarity with SQL and Java web applications.
wikiPageName: How to Scale an Application with Table Groups
wikiTitle: How to Scale an Application with Table Groups
smallTitle: How to Scale an Application with Table Groups by Ori Herrnstadt

title: How to Set Up and Administer Nexus for your Development Team
summary:
If you are not using a repository manager you should to attend this hands-on lab to learn how to change that, quickly.   We'll focus on the advantages of running a repository manager and some of the motivation behind the project.  Then we'll dive right into practical considerations that surround your deployment of a repository manager.

What questions should be answered before you deploy a repository manager?  What is your security model for accessing artifacts from the repository?  And, how is Nexus best suited to support software releases?   You won't only learn how to setup and install Nexus, you'll learn how to make sure that your instance is optimized for your needs.
wikiPageName: How to Set Up and Administer Nexus for your Development Team
wikiTitle: How to Set Up and Administer Nexus for your Development Team
smallTitle: How to Set Up and Administer Nexus for your Development Team by Tim O'brien

title: Performance Optimization Methodology
summary: Performance optimization has always thought to be a fine art as it could not be easily formalized, or constrained into one solid workflow. However, there are common patterns all performance engineers could follow in their investigations. This session describes some approaches and tools to analyise modern application performance problems in J2SE and hardware.
wikiPageName: Performance Optimization Methodology
wikiTitle: Performance Optimization Methodology
smallTitle: Performance Optimization Methodology by Aleksey Shipilev

title: Practical guide to Infinispan Queries
summary:
Infinispan is a powerful and extremely efficient transactional NoSQL: a distributed in-memory Data Grid exposing primarily a Map-like API, but also integrating Apache Lucene to allow full-text queries. This integration however can be setup in a number of ways, resulting in different architectures.

How to pick the right clustering mode? Which indexing backend to choose? Should you use a shared CacheLoader?

Let’s explore these options via some practical examples.

author.speakingReferences:
Spoke at Devoxx 2011 in a University track on Infinispan, Devoxx 2012 on queries.
Spoke as well at JUDCon, Java Day, OpenBlend, Agile Day, various JBug and JUG events in Italy, France, Portugal and UK.
author.speakerBio: Sanne Grinovero is a member of the Hibernate and Infinispan teams at JBoss by Red Hat, and a member of the London Java Community. He works on NoSQL OSS integrations, like Hibernate Search and Infinispan's integrations with Apache Lucene and Hibernate OGM. He lived in Holland, Italy, Republica Dominicana, Chile, Portugal and currently resides in London.
author.name: Sanne Grinovero

wikiPageName: Practical guide to Infinispan Queries
wikiTitle: Practical guide to Infinispan Queries
smallTitle: Practical guide to Infinispan Queries by Sanne Grinovero

title: Type safe, efficient, and low level programming for the Java Virtual Machine
summary: AL1 is a new assembler language for the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), but doesn't require any knowledge of its stack based, sometimes non intuitive instruction set. Instead it defines high level, type safe, Java-like methods which allow a low level access to the JVM. With intrinsic functions (without the calling overhead) AL1 allows to "enhance" the JVM instruction set by offering unsigned integer arithmetic, safe arithmetic with overflow detection, alternate switch behavior, and so on. Although limited to the possibilities of the JVM AL1 promises a significant performance boost in specific areas without the need to switch to native implementations in C, which is especially useful when creating time critical frameworks and libraries.

author.speakingReferences:
Talks at Conferences since 1998 (NET Object Days, Java Forum Stuttgart, OOP, GUI & Design, prio.conference, JAX, W-JAX, dotnet-Konferenz, EAI-Forum, Systems, online, Unicode Conference, Herbstcampus. .NET Developer Conference)

Michael is founder of the JUG Metropolian Area Nuremberg, "collects" programming languages, and likes to study their design and implementation.

title: Parsing DSLs or your favorite programming language with SSLR in a couple of hours
summary:
SSLR (SonarSource Language Recognition) is a powerful open source library to parse languages. Java-based, it is currently used in Sonar to parse programming languages such as Java, Javascript, Flex but also PL/SQL, Cobol or C++. SSLR offers an easy way to create a parser but also provides a testing framework to unit test the parsing rules and avoid regression when making changes. It also comes with a powerful toolset for lexing and pre-processing.

In this university, we will go through the concepts of language analysis (lexing, pre-processing, parsing) and then show how to use SSLR and its toolset to quickly write a parser and the corresponding tests. We will also use the written parser to extract information.
wikiPageName: Parsing DSLs or your favorite programming language with SSLR in a couple of hours
wikiTitle: Parsing DSLs or your favorite programming language with SSLR in a couple of hours
smallTitle: Parsing DSLs or your favorite programming language with SSLR in a couple of hour... by Olivier Gaudin

title: Apache Wicket: the web framework for the 99%
summary:
For each Facebook, Twitter or Amazon, there are millions of applications that don’t require internet scalability, but rather a competitive edge delivering a maintainable, performant and secure solution to clients in short time. Every time someone says you shouldn't store state in your server, the 99% kill a kitten. Stop catering to the 1% and spit out your applications on time, on budget and with time to spare for your family.

I'll unveil lessons learned over 7 years of deploying Wicket applications, reminiscing the old days of prototype.js, dojo.js and how things have improved and matured over the years.

Learn how to integrate any JQuery plugin with ease in your Wicket application today. Build your own RAD component library so you can deliver and maintain several 1000+ page application in months instead of years.

Improve the quality of your Wicket applications with embedded quality checks such as markup validation against W3C standards, memory utilization and application monitoring tools.

author.speakingReferences: JavaPolis, Devoxx, ApacheCon, 33rd degree, FOSDEM, JavaOne, JavaZone, TSSJS, Øredev, NLJUG, guest lectures at Saxion College, guest lecture at Windesheim College.
author.speakerBio: Martijn Dashorst is a senior software engineer for Topicus B.V.. He is a committer on the Wicket project and works on many Wicket related projects. When he doesn't work with or on Wicket, he likes to spend time with his family and two cats.
author.name: Martijn Dashorst

wikiPageName: Apache Wicket  the web framework for the 99%
wikiTitle: Apache Wicket  the web framework for the 99%
smallTitle: Apache Wicket: the web framework for the 99% by Martijn Dashorst

title: Push applications with Apache Wicket 6
summary:
With Apache Wicket 6 the push era has finally arrived. Learn how you can utilize web sockets and push in your Wicket applications. 

In this session I'll explain the concepts of push, the benefits for you and your users and how Wicket can leverage this technology to create very interactive applications.
wikiPageName: Push applications with Apache Wicket 6
wikiTitle: Push applications with Apache Wicket 6
smallTitle: Push applications with Apache Wicket 6 by Martijn Dashorst

title: G1 Garbage Collector - Big Heaps and Low Pauses
summary:
The Garbage-First (G1) is the latest garbage collector in the JVM, aiming to be the long-term replacement for CMS. Targeted for machines with large memories and multiple processors. Promising low and more predictable pause times while achieving high throughput. 

The session will introduce the architecture and design of G1. Then the main focus of the talk  will be the performance characteristics observed under different loads; tuning capabilities and common pitfalls. With the aim of answering the question can you run big heaps and achieve low pauses.

author.speakingReferences:
- Software Summer Camp 2011. "Introduction to the Spring Framework Lab" was a top rated session according to the participant survey. Contact: www.swsc.cz, Organizer: IBA CZ, stanislav.filipcik@ibacz.eu

- Liferay Conference Prague 2012. "Building an Unbreakable Portal". Speech focused on non-functional aspect of Liferay Portal. Contact: www.ibacz.eu, Organizer: IBA CZ, lukas.matejka@ibacz.eu

- Delivering speeches on Spring Framework at Masaryk University in Brno, Czech Republic. Contact: 	petr.adamek@bilysklep.cz

Jaromir Hamala is a Senior Consultant at C2B2 Consulting Ltd., focusing on non-functional requirements of systems. He wrote his first line of code when he was 7 years old. Since than he was always interested in "How this system works under the hood?"

Jaromir is an expert on JVM, Spring Framework and Liferay Portal.

title: Evolving JavaEE in the NoSQL Era
summary:
Applications needing NoSQL often suffer from a high degree of coupling to the peculiarities of the datastore. Is that acceptable nowadays? Maybe, and we might have no choice, but that sells the soul of your application to the chosen technology.

To make optimal use of NoSQL we can't ignore its diversity. The Hibernate Object Grid/Mapper offers a balanced abstraction to expose a standard compatible Java Persistence API, while taking advantage of the most exotic features of the new NoSQL models.

In this talk Sanne illustrates the design of Hibernate OGM and focuses on the capabilities of the new hybrid Query Engine introduced to make optimal use of several well known NoSQL implementations.
wikiPageName: Evolving JavaEE in the NoSQL Era
wikiTitle: Evolving JavaEE in the NoSQL Era
smallTitle: Evolving JavaEE in the NoSQL Era by Sanne Grinovero

title: Apache Wicket: a primer
summary:
Apache Wicket is a Java component oriented web framework that has been around since 2004, is used daily by thousands of developers, but still remains unnoticed by many. 

In this session I will introduce Apache Wicket's concepts, the basic components (labels, links, forms, lists and panels) and how to create internationalized applications. I'll touch upon JEE conversations with CDI, integration with Spring. and how you can use Ajax and Push in your Wicket applications. I'll quickly show how to automate your web testing with Wicket's embedded testing framework.

The talk will end with showing the new features in Wicket 6, such as push with web sockets and the improved resource management (JavaScript and CSS files).
wikiPageName: Apache Wicket  a primer
wikiTitle: Apache Wicket  a primer
smallTitle: Apache Wicket: a primer by Martijn Dashorst

title: The ALx Language Family for the JVM
summary:
Like Groovy, Ceylon, or Kotlin the ALx language family tries to circumvent some of Java's limitations. ALx does this by providing simple consistent syntax elements and several levels which address different problem areas and paradigms. This allows for example to add domain specific features or to program native parts without the need to switch to C/C++.
This talk gives an introduction to the structure and levels of the ALx, shows some of the more interesting and unique features in these levels, and demonstrates how to extend the language.
wikiPageName: The ALx Language Family for the JVM
wikiTitle: The ALx Language Family for the JVM
smallTitle: The ALx Language Family for the JVM by Michael Wiedeking

title: Annotation Features in JDK 8
summary: While large language changes are afoot in JDK 8, annotations are getting some enhancements too! Come hear about design and implementation issues in repeating annotations, annotations on types (JSR 308), and annotation processing. While small, these features touch all of the language, the VM, and the core API. For annotation processing while the original annotation processing tool, apt, has been removed, the successor API javax.lang.model could be available at compile time as well as at runtime.

title: Closures and Collections - the World After Eight
summary: The introduction of closures will bring new idioms to Java programming.  Collections in particular will be managed very differently, with stream-oriented processing and lazy evaluation becoming the norm for many applications.  Collections connected by these streams will offer new "parallel views" - implementations that will make optimal use of highly-concurrent hardware.  It's going to be a different world after Java8!

title: Fast UIs for the mobile web
summary:
One of the great features of the modern web is that sites work on any device with a browser. This session will focus on creating UIs for the cross-device web. We will cover building web sites that support multiple device form factors (responsive and non-responsive approaches), discuss single page sites and some of the layout features in modern mobile browsers and do a deep dive into multi-touch input on the web. Finally, we'll show some of the awesome new mobile debugging tools in Chrome and Chrome for Android to make your mobile websites super fast.
Outline :
- Supporting multiple devices
- Building fast single page UIs
- Multi-touch input
- Mobile web development flow
